urn:contentItem:5KW0-6C01-DXH2-61PW-00000-00Still Too Early to Declare the Recession is Over in the United States; U.S. Supreme Court Again Waived Police Powers Against Suspects' Rights; Iran Hostage Crisis During the '80s Refuses to Fade Away; Boris Yeltsin to Arrive in Washington Next Thursday; President Bush: No Child in America Should Be At Risk to Deadly Diseases in the 1990s. Aired 8-9p ET.1991-06-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:10ZLexisNexisPRIME NEWS8:00 PM ESTNEWSInternational100401CN.V99Still Too Early to Declare the Recession is Over in the United States; U.S. Supreme Court Again Waived Police Powers Against Suspects' Rights; Iran Hostage Crisis During the '80s Refuses to Fade Away; Boris Yeltsin to Arrive in Washington Next Thursday; President Bush: No Child in America Should Be At Risk to Deadly Diseases in the 1990s. Aired 8-9p ET.Bernard Shaw, Steve Young, Susan Rook, Anthony Collings, Carl Rochelle, Dan Rutz, Rick Sallinger, Terry Keenan, Dan Rutz, Jack Germond, David Broder, Nick Charles, Flip Spiceland, Larry King

It is still too early to declare the recession over, but signs today that it may be bottoming out and turning around. The U.S. Supreme Court has again waived police powers against suspects' rights and come down on the side of police. One of the darkest periods in recent U.S. foreign policy, the Iran hostage crisis refuses to fade away. Boris Yeltsin is scheduled to arrive in Washington next Thursday, and he'll come as the first popularly elected president of the Russian Republic. In medical news, President Bush is joining the drive to make sure all children are immunized against childhood diseases such as measles.

ANNOUNCER: This is CNN's PRIME NEWS, taking the time to examine world events, issues, and newsmakers. With Bernard Shaw in Washington and Susan Rook in Atlanta.

BERNARD SHAW, CNN HOST: Thanks for joining us.

We began with the United States economy still too early to declare the recession over, but signs today that it may be bottoming out and turning around. Retail sales up in May, new claims for unemployment benefits down a fourth straight week. The figures point to one conclusion, the American consumer, the driving force of the economy, is spending money again. Our business correspondent, Steve Young, reports.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVE YOUNG, CNN BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: In one key sign the recession is ending, retail sales rose 1 percent in May. The third retail sales increased in the past four months. Apparel sales were especially strong because of good weather and momentum gained from the economic recovery.

ROBERT BARBERA, LEHMAN BROTHERS CHIEF ECONOMIST: The decline for consumers' spending on goods was deeper than any recession but one, 1974, '75. Consumers really did take a big step back. So their return really in February, March and a bit in May is welcomed but is certainly to be expected with that kind of sharp reversal.

YOUNG: But wholesale prices nudge up six tenth of a percent surprising most economists because it's the biggest gain in over seven months. The increases were sparked by energy price hikes of almost 2.5 percent, largely on gasoline price increases of more than 5 percent. Home heating oil and natural gas prices continue to decline. There was also a steep 4 percent jump in tobacco prices.

Financial markets have been reacting to the news with a decline in stock prices, that's because interest from bonds is becoming more competitive with returns from stocks. But if the recession bounce back, turns out to be weak, bond prices again will go up and yields will go down. The government cranks out another round of figures Friday on inflationary pressures at the retail, the consumer level.

Steve Young, CNN Business News, New York.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAW: And now the state of the American dream owning a home. Today, the federal government confirm what many Americans already know. Recession or not, it is getting harder and harder. In fact, the Census Bureau finds 57 percent of American households cannot afford a median priced home with a 30-year mortgage. 15 percent cannot afford even the least expensive home.

SUSAN ROOK, CNN HOST: The U.S. Supreme Court has again waived police powers against suspects' rights and come down on the side of police. The Court ruled Thursday that under certain circumstances, a criminal suspect may be questioned without his lawyer present. CNN's Anthony Collings has details.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANTHONY COLLINGS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: When police arrest a suspect, they must read him his Miranda rights. But a suspect's rights have limits, the Supreme Court says. A 63 rulings has a jailed suspect represented by a lawyer in one case may be questioned about another crime without the lawyer present. Writing for the majority, Justice Antonin Scalia said that barring some police questioning of a suspect who would asked for a lawyer would seriously impede effective law enforcement. Conservative experts welcome the decision to give police more power.

ALAN SLOBODIN, WASHINGTON LEGAL FOUNDATION COUNSEL: It's a good thing. I think it's another development by the Supreme Court where they're recognizing realities of how the criminal justice system is swung too far in favor of criminal defendants.

COLLINGS: Liberal Justice John Paul Stevens in dissent accused the court majority of swinging too far the other way. He said today's decision is ominous because it reflects a preference for an inquisitorial system. The decision favoring police came coincidentally on the 25th anniversary of the Supreme Court's landmark Miranda decision. It required police to make sure that suspect's rights against self-incrimination are upheld. But the current conservative-dominated Supreme Court has issued a series of opinions limiting those rights.

Last March, in throwing out the murder conviction of an Arizona man, the Court ruled that while his confession was coerced illegally, some coerced confessions can still be admitted in evidence if there is enough other evidence to convict. The High Court this year also permitted suspects to be held for 48 hours without a warrant. It has expanded search powers of police and limited appeals by inmates of death row.

PAUL ROTHSTEIN, WASHINGTON LEGAL FOUNDATION: The Supreme Court has an approach these days which says that if there's any room in earlier decisions to go against the criminal defendant, we will seize that opportunity and go against the criminal defendant.

COLLINGS: In its latest ruling that a lawyer doesn't always have to be present during questioning, the Supreme Court says it is not weakening the Miranda rights of a suspect. Liberals don't agree but it is increasingly clear that in this court, the liberals no longer call the shots.

Anthony Collings, CNN, at the Supreme Court.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROOK: Still ahead on PRIME NEWS, some former hostages asked Congress to investigate a nagging question about the release of U.S. hostages held in Iran. (Inaudible) not just take lives, it takes jobs, friends. We'll show you how some people with the disease are coping. And talk about a historic document. Last summer it cost four dollars now, we'll show what a piece of history goes for these days. Stay tuned.

ROOK: One of the darkest periods in recent U.S. foreign policy, the Iran hostage crisis refuses to fade away. For 444 days, 52 Americans were held hostage in the U.S. embassy in Tehran. Their dramatic release occurred just moments after Ronald Reagan was sworn in as president in 1981. Now, several of the former hostages are calling on Congress to investigate allegations that their release was delayed for political reasons. CNN's Carl Rochelle has more.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CARL ROCHELLE, CNN CORRESPONDENT: While the world watched, 52 Americans counted the days they were held hostage by Iran. Now, more than 11 years later, eight of the 52 have written Congress asking for help. They want to know if there is any truth to reports that they were part of an arms deal with Iran, they kept them hostage until after the 1980 presidential election.

MOORHEAD KENNEDY, FORMER HOSTAGE: We are not concluding that something happened. We are simply saying that there is evidence that something might have happened of such a serious nature that it should be investigated right away.

BARRY ROSEN, FORMER HOSTAGE: It is not appropriate to say there is insufficient proof until there's been an official investigation. The question of whether there is evidence of any wrongdoing must be answered by an unbiased bipartisan congressional investigation with full subpoena power. Unless this happens, speculation and unanswered questions will erode public confidence in our electoral system.

ROCHELLE: Gary Sick, a former aide to President Carter focused attention on the question. He charge the Reagan campaign had made a deal with Iran to hold the hostages until after the election in return for military equipment. Sick said George Bush, then running for vice president may have gone to Paris to help arrange the deal. GARY SICK, FORMER CARTER AIDE: There really is no doubting at all in my mind that there were meetings between the Republican campaign and the Iranians in the course of the 1980 elections to discuss the question of the hostages.

ROCHELLE: Some Democrats have initiated their own investigation into the matter but Republicans aren't convinced there was any wrongdoing.

REP. DAN BURTON, (R) INDIANA: It's a fishing expedition. I think it's very, very political and it would be a waste of the taxpayers' money in my opinion to have an investigation of this.

ROCHELLE: Former President Reagan denies there was any deal with Iran but even Sick admits he has found no smoking gun but may never be able to prove his allegations.

The White House responded to this latest barrage by releasing the text of a letter President Bush showed last month to Moorhead Kennedy in which Mr. Bush emphatically denied any involvement.

Carl Rochelle, CNN, Washington.

ROOK: As Carl Rochelle just mentioned, former Carter administration official Gary Sick says George Bush when he was vice president may have been involved in a hostage delay deal with Iran. Mr. Bush has strongly denied that allegation. His chief of staff repeated the President's position to CNN just a short while ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN SUNUNU, WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF: President Bush has been unequivocal in his comments that there was nothing of the nature that has been described but if Congress or anybody who wants to investigate this, we have no problem with that. The President is comfortable with the fact that nothing he knew of, not the descriptions given by the hostages.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Would you endorse a congressional investigation?

SUNUNU: Well, Congress has to decide what it wants to do. We have absolutely no problem if they make that choice.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROOK: John Sununu was interviewed on CNN's "The World Today"

SHAW: The White House responded Thursday to General Norman Schwarzkopf statements that military intelligence during the Gulf War was lacking. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater says the President felt the information was excellent. Wednesday, the general compliant to a congressional committee, some of the data were out of date. The Pentagon has conceded there were intelligence related problems, including differences between various United States intelligence agencies.

Boris Yeltsin is scheduled to arrive in Washington next Thursday, and he'll come as the first popularly elected president of the Russian Republic. With a landslide victory behind him, Yeltsin has a mandate from the people to pursue his radical reforms. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev said before the election he would cooperate with the winner.

In other developments, the people of Leningrad unexpectedly voted to restore the city's original name of St. Petersburg, in effect turning their backs on the founder of the Soviet state Nikolai Lenin.

ROOK: Stay with us for these stories. Swimming against the tide of AIDS discrimination. You'll see how some people with this disease are working to change public attitudes.

Also, ahead on Prime News, we'll tell you what's hot in space as the Columbia crew get set to return to earth. You'll see what's going on in a border town for bombings and death have become a routine part of everyday life. And later, we'll see what strategy and what candidates might win for the Democrats in '92.

SHAW: In medical news, President Bush is joining the drive to make sure all children are immunized against childhood diseases such as measles. In doing so, Mr. Bush is echoing the call of his Health and Human Services secretary.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEORGE W. BUSH, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: And in the 1990s, no child in America should be at risk to deadly diseases like diphtheria, polio, or the one that Lou was stressing here today, measles.

LOUIS SULLIVAN, HHS SECRETARY: As a nation, we cannot be satisfied until all our children are properly vaccinated. But we have to work harder, making the process of immunization more accessible. We must act now to avoid slippage.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAW: Dr. Sullivan is dispatching HHS SWAT teams to six U.S. cities to look for ways to improve immunization programs. Democratic Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts is critical of the government plan and he calls it a road show that would involve solving the problem of inadequate vaccination. Evidence of the problem, in the last two years, more than 100 people died of measles out of 45,000 cases. Officials say, at least half of those cases involve preschool children who were not vaccinated.

ROOK: A top U.S. health official suggest a Florida dentist may have spread the AIDS virus through contaminated dental instruments or equipment. Dr. David Acer died of AIDS. It has been confirmed, five of his patients were infected with similar strains of the AIDS virus. The top AIDS official with the Centers for Disease Control says it's doubtful Dr. Acer spread the virus through blood in all five cases. The official believes the dentist practice may have been particularly unsafe. However, CDC investigators say, they may never know exactly how the five patients were infected.

SHAW: And tonight's news from Medicine Part Nine of our continuing series on AIDS, the second decade. CNN's Dan Rutz explores the other worries aside from health that people with AIDS must confront each day.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAN RUTZ, CNN MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: Most people who carry the virus linked to AIDS are well enough to work, but often worried sick they'll be fired.

SCOTT JORDAN, AIDS VIRUS CARRIER: But in fact, when they found out, that is exactly what happened.

RUTZ: Scott Jordan's new job is with a firm where all the employees are AIDS carriers.

JORDAN: There's a lot of mental anguish that goes along with being sick and I think it's important that you have a purpose to get up for in the morning.

RUTZ: A doctor started the multitasking systems company in New York City to help out her patients and prove that people with AIDS make good workers. Dr. Linda Laubenstein works from a wheelchair herself.

LINDA LAUBENSTEIN, NEW WORK UNIVERSITY DOCTOR: And they should be no reason why the average individual can't work in the average kind of work setting without -- they're being a danger to either the employer or the employee.

RUTZ: MPS copies documents and prepares mass mailing. Most of the 36 employees work part-time. The manager hopes eventually to turn a profit.

EDWARD PETERS, MULTITASKING SYSTEMS, INC. STAFF: We are of essence and we certainly have to have various business principles that any business has.

RUTZ: The American Civil Liberties Union feels people with AIDS should not be restricted to jobs that cater especially to them.

WILLIAM RUBENSTEIN, ACLU PROFESSOR: So the first cut for someone with HIV disease should be that they should be able to stay on as long as possible wherever they are working already.

RUTZ: The Americans with Disabilities Act bans most discrimination against people with AIDS but hold little power over attitudes. Ronald Webeck's St. Petersburg, Florida neighbors know he has AIDS.

GAIL SCHONEBOOM, RONALD WEBECK'S NEIGHBOR: Well, I would say a couple of years ago when I first met him there were people at our pool who would get out at the pool when he got in.

MARLA HUGH, RONALD WEBECK'S NEIGHBOR: I remember when people used to feel that way about people who had cancer. People always hid that fact.

RUTZ: Webeck feels the people around him have learned enough in recent years not to be afraid.

RONALD WEBECK, AIDS VICTIM: I don't have to fight an element that a lot of other people are fighting, I think, which is maybe prejudice. And I've never really had to experience that. So it's made my life much nicer and much easier.

RUTZ: But distrust is growing between doctors and patients. New concerns about the risk of AIDS transmission either way spark debate over mandatory AIDS testing. The Centers for Disease Control has yet to issue guidelines, but it's clearly torn between the concerns of the worried well and of healthcare workers who could lose their jobs.

JAMES CURRAN, CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL DOCTOR: But I think we want make recommendations to protect the public, to educate the profession, and to try to stem overreaction by including far too many procedures or far too many people.

RUTZ: The rights of the infected whether they work in medicine or industry have throughout the AIDS epidemic been an important consideration in public health policy, more so than fears, the experts regard as irrational.

There is more to all this than just holding a job for a paycheck or to escape boredom. Doctors find for many people, going to work is good therapy.

Dan Rutz, CNN, New York.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROOK: Officials in Los Angeles say a police helicopter experienced engine trouble just minutes before it crashed in a ball of flames. Three people were killed in the crash. Two officers in the chopper and one person on the ground. Several cars and a duplex were burned. Witnesses say the chopper was shaking just before it clip a light pole and slammed into a parking lot across the street from a daycare center. No children were injured.

SHAW: The space shuttle Columbia crew spent part of its last day in space doing a mundane household task. The astronauts were awakened early to fix two overheated refrigerator so they could save blood and urine samples collected during the nine day voyage. Then it was time to pack up for the trip home. Columbia scheduled to return to earth Friday at 11:40 a.m. Eastern time.

Pictures taken from Columbia provided a glimpse of Mount Pinatubo's continuing volcanic eruptions in the Philippine. Today, the volcano blew a cloud of ash and plume as nearly five miles into the air. The latest eruption sent thousands more running heading for evacuation centers. So far, more than 50,000 people, including many from a nearby U.S. air base have evacuated the area. The Pentagon is declining comments on reports nuclear arms are stored at the base.

ROOK: Northern Ireland has been erupting with religious and political violence for years. Now, there is hope that a meeting set for Monday may lead to peace. Catholic and Protestant political leaders will sit down for long-awaited talks on the future of the British run province. From Northern Ireland, CNN's Rick Sallinger reports from a place where Catholics and Protestants lived side by side with death.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RICK SALLINGER, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Castlederg, nestled in the hills. It's as pretty as a picture, but some of the pictures in this border town aren't nearly so nice. This is where a terrorist murder of a Protestant took place. Here a bomb exploded on Mother's Day last year, damaging dozens of homes. The Catholic Irish Republican Army has been blamed.

JAMES EMERY, TOWN COUNCILOR: Over the last 20 years you see this town is being bombed so much, pretty used with it. It is a great detriment of course maybe to people like you and the tourists who come here. They tend to shy away from Castlederg. But we kind of -- it's normal and sadly we have the kind of -- it's normal.

SALLINGER: Normal, it all looks very normal on the surface but look closer. What is normal for Castlederg is a sign of a heavily armed policeman with a bullet proof vest. They must constantly watch their backs. The police station is like a fortress, cars that passed by are checked for weapons and explosives.

Castlederg has a distinction of being the most bomb border town in Northern Ireland. 75 explosions have shaken this community over the past 20 years, but the violence hasn't ended there.

There have been 24 killings, 23 victims were Protestants. The cemetery is filled with headstones marked, murdered by terrorists. William Pollock, age 27, Norman McKinley, age 32, Heather Kerrigan, 20 years old. That's Heather on the right as a bridesmaid at this wedding. Since then, the groom and best man were also killed by the IRA, not one gunman has been apprehended.

CANON WALTER QUILL, CHURCH OF IRELAND RECTOR: Up until now when a Protestant has been murdered, scores of Roman Catholics come under suspicion. Now if we could apprehend the terrorists, and hopefully that they would be from outside the community, it would end that suspicion from the local people.

SALLINGER: While the British flag flies over the town, it is the flag of Ireland waving in the breeze in this Catholic neighborhood. Portraits of three IRA martyrs are on a house and a Merel (ph) encourages early allegiance to that outlawed organization.

How are Catholics treated here?

PATRICK DEVLIN, CATHOLIC RESIDENT: Very badly. You should be here couple of weeks ago. There's allegedly a small blast down the road. SALLINGER: He says the police got all Catholics in the neighborhood out of bed in the middle of the night regardless of age. Castlederg is just a mile from the border with the Republic of Ireland. That makes it a convenient target for the IRA to carry on its war seeking a united Ireland.

EDWARD TURNER, DISTRICT COUNCIL PRESIDENT: As far as the bombings are concerned, quite a number of these have taken place by 500 pine bomb, 600 pine bomb, 1,000 pine bomb of explosives loaded into the back of a vehicle with some description and driven across.

SALLINGER: He is calling for more border security. Because Turner is the district council president, he is accompanied by a bodyguard wherever he goes. And he rides in a bulletproof car. The divisions in this community of 6,500 are as vivid as the colors of the neighborhood curves, Protestant and Catholic. What's harder to see is the progress being made in relations here. Pat O'Loughlin sees it, he's a Catholic shop owner in Castlederg.

PAT O'LOUGHLIN, CATHOLIC BUSINESSMAN: I don't have customers in my shop, we have suffered greatly through terrorism and yet they would come in and do business with me from all sides of any other day.

SALLINGER: His friend across the street is Protestant businessman Samuel Crawford.

SAMUEL CRAWFORD, PROTESTANT BUSINESSMAN: And you have to love Tequila to survive, have good relationship with all of them, people of the state.

QUILL: We're matured enough to know that we share this place together and we all condemned terrorism. And we want peace to prosper here in Castlederg.

SALLINGER: The clergy has started a program of interdenominational activities called "Bridge Building" to try and convince two communities deeply divided by murders, bombings, and religion, that they must live together as one in order for there to be peace.

Rick Sallinger, CNN, Castlederg, Northern Ireland.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAW: Coming up on PRIME NEWS. The New York Stock Exchange stays open. It's the first step toward round-the-clock trading.

ROOK: Among our top stories on PRIME NEWS, the U.S. government reports retail sales rose 1 percent last month. Some analysts say it's further evidence the economy is bouncing back. But there is negative news on the inflation front. Wholesale prices jumped to surprising six tenths of a percent in May, force stop by hikes in gas and tobacco prices.

In a 63 ruling, the U.S. Supreme Court gives police more leeway in questioning certain suspects. The court says, a jail suspect represented by a lawyer in one criminal case may be questioned about another crime without the lawyer present.

And eight U.S. citizens once held hostage in Iran say, they want to know for sure if their release was delayed for political gain. They're asking Congress to investigate allegations that the Reagan- Bush campaign struck a deal with Iran to hold the Americans until after the 1980 presidential election.

SHAW: The Federal Communications Commission is planning to give local officials a voice in setting prices for about 60 percent of the nation's cable T.V. systems. Under current rules, just about all systems are exempt, but local governments have been complaining that current rules allow cable rates to keep going up. Today's action will permit local governments to regulate prices in markets with fewer than six over the air stations or no competing cable system.

ROOK: A few hours ago, the New York Stock Exchange did something it'd never done before. It stayed open after 4:00. The idea pumped up the exchanges sagging trading volume. But as CNN's Terry Keenan reports, the idea hasn't quite caught on just yet.

TERRY KEENAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: The first day of after-hours trading on the New York Stock Exchange wasn't much different from any other. At 4:00, the floor cleared, traders headed home, and trading in most stocks came to a halt. With little action there was took place here on brokerage trading floors where handful of traders were on hand to take orders.

THOMAS GALLAGHER, OPPENHEIMER & CO. HEAD TRADER: Well, there's not a lot of response. Most people kind of -- going to wait and see how it goes and see whether or not it's worthwhile being involved in it. We did have a few orders both from our retail and from our institutional efforts and it was very little indeed.

KEENAN: Also, the mere 2.3 million shares traded in the after hours sessions, less than 2 percent of the regular hours total, and most of it to institutions. Still, the NYSE which is counting on the extra hours to help regain lost volume was optimistic.

RICHARD GRASSO, NYSE PRESIDENT: Well, I think what we've done is take a very small step in the direction of continuous trading for big board listed securities.

KEENAN: Whether that's to happen, traders say the big board will have to get more aggressive by offering something they can already get somewhere else.

One problem may be a bad sense of timing. According to traders only about 30 percent of all the exchange trades take place after the New York Stock Exchange closes. The other 70 percent occur in the morning and half hour before trading begins.

Terry Keenan, CNN Business News, New York.

(END VIDEO CLIP) SHAW: Ahead on PRIME NEWS, CNN Political Analyst David Broder and Jack Germond examine presidential campaign '92. And later, sweet home Chicago, the Bulls returned from Los Angeles and we'll have the latest in sports.

SHAW: The presidential election is less than 17 months away. Democratic Party Chairman Ron Brown is convening a meeting of heavy hitters in Virginia over the next two days, to plan a strategy they hope will dislodge George Bush in 1992. Among these desperate Democrats most of the party leadership, major fundraisers, and prospective Democratic candidates in 1992.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

RON BROWN, DNC CHAIRMAN: This is a meeting which will bring together party leaders, prospective candidates, and major supporters of the party to share notes, to share ideals, to talk about the values and goals of the Democratic Party, to talk about a strategy and plan to capture the White House in 1992. We intend to elect a Democrat president of United States. In order to do that, we have to change the way we do our business. We have to get off to an early start as far general election, campaign planning, as far as research, and polling, and focus groups, and message testing. And in effect, getting our act together for the general election campaign.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAW: Joining us to assess the politics and the prospects for the Democratic Party next year, two veteran observers. Washington Post Political Columnist David Broder and in Los Angeles, Jack Germond of the Baltimore Sun. Both now analyst for CNN's political coverage right through the '92 presidential campaign.

Before we start, the Democrats are smiling a bit this week going into the big meeting in Middelburg, a new internal poll shows President Bush's reelection numbers are only at 46 percent compared to his popularity ratings that are well into the 70s. And that President Bush is vulnerable on domestic and economic issues.

Jack, in thinking about 1992, in thinking about where we stand now, can the Democrats attack George Bush in terms of strong suit, weak suit?

JACK GERMOND, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST: Well, the -- I think what happened Bernie is, we reach the point where the Democrats now if you hold a mirror up to the mouth of the party at does cloud up, I mean, the party is alive. And I think that there's two reasons for this is, one is there are some candidates who are acting aggressive, Rockefeller and Tom Harkin particularly. But the other reason is they think that Bush, as this poll would suggest, is vulnerable for his disinterest, of lack of interest on domestic concerns. And that is what sort of invigorated the party, more out of Washington I say than in Washington.

SHAW: David, your thoughts.

DAVID BRODER, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST: I think that the poll offers him some comfort but not a whole lot, Bernie. During the Reagan years, you may recall that often on issue questions, and issue after issue, the voters said that they like the position the Democrats were taking better than the Reagan position but they saw Ronald Reagan as a strong leader, they saw the Democrats as a weak and confused party and they weren't about to make the trade. Unless and until the Democrats come up with a candidate who looks as if he could even approach George Bush in terms of that strength of leadership, I don't think they're a real serious threat to George Bush.

SHAW: So just as Reagan, his security blanket, Bush has his, Jack?

GERMOND: Well, it's very difficult to look at any of these figures in the abstract, but David made the right point. The question is can the Democrats produce a candidate who was personally forceful enough to have some say about what the agenda is if he allows President Bush to control the agenda in '92 as candidate Bush control than in '88. It doesn't make any difference what the poll show back and win the election. If they got a strong figure that controls the agenda, makes them talk about their subjects then they have a shot.

SHAW: What about the economy and its status?

BRODER: Well the economy has clearly got to be the Democrat's strong suit. It's not that today, even though we've been in a recession, the Democrats don't have the kind of commanding lead as the party best able to deal with the economy that they've had in the past. So, just saying that the economy is in trouble as it has been for the past year by itself does not elect the Democrats to the White House.

GERMOND: It's also, Bernie, there's a lot of risk in the Democrats or the party out of power in any case relying on the economy. The economy has a habit of turning up right before a presidential election and taking the issue away. But that doesn't take away from other issues that are related to the economy. I think particularly the healthcare, for example.

SHAW: You know, I'm wondering about this Middelburg, Virginia meeting. David Broder, George Bush is at four years or four-year lead on the Democrats but shouldn't this meeting have been held before now?

BRODER: Maybe, but it's hard for the opposition party to get its act together and Ron Brown is accurate in saying that if he can begin to put together a general election campaign plan 16 months in advance of election day he would be far ahead of the schedule in the past. This meeting is an effort by Ron Brown to deal himself and the Democratic National Committee into the 1992 campaign, because the money that the taxpayers give to presidential candidates to finance their campaigns goes to that candidate as an individual and his personal campaign committee. Often, the party organization is left on the sidelines in the presidential campaign. Ron Brown is trying to change that pattern by getting the party into the planning early. He's going to have a battle on his hands to make it work. GERMOND: You know, there are lot of things. The fact is that the Democrats, what they have done in the last few campaigns, if they start from scratch with a great cloud of cosmic dust the day after they nominate the presidential candidate at the convention. What Brown is saying essentially is he wants to raise money now to do the things that have to be done as a foundation for a camping far ahead of the campaign and it will be the same thing essentially no matter who you nominate, whether you nominate a liberal or a conservative or whoever, they will all want the same sort of spade work than anything.

BRODER: But that's not realistic, Jack, because the campaign will be very different if it's a liberal or if it's a conservative.

GERMOND: Well, it wouldn't be different in terms of identifying issues where the other guy is vulnerable. It wouldn't be different in terms or negative research or targeting new Democrats, that kind of thing.

SHAW: You mentioned the word vulnerable, George Bush believes the Democrats are vulnerable, the Democrats believe he is vulnerable. Last night on the White House South Lawn, Bush, in effect, took the campaign to them, Marlin Fitzwater said you might consider the remarks made at the White House last night, the beginning of the '92 campaign. Let's listen to an excerpt of what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BUSH: I wasn't asking the Congress to deliver a hot pizza in less than 30 minutes. That would be revolutionary for Congress. I only asked for two pieces of legislation in 100 days and it's now clear that neither will be on my desk by Friday. And look, I'm disappointed, but frankly I'm not surprised. American people don't understand the complications and the inaction and the bickering, particularly when so many do understand what it takes to solve problems in their own neighborhoods commitment, compassion and courage.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAW: Opening salvo '92 race for the White House. Your reaction, gentlemen.

GERMOND: Sure sounds like a ...

BRODER: Bernie, this is one part of it. What we can see now is a three-part Bush re-election campaign strategy. What you heard last night was beating up on Congress and sharpening the issue with the Democrats. We saw that a week earlier on the specific issue of civil rights or quotas as the Republicans would have.

The second piece is pride and patriotism and that of course is keyed to the celebration of the U.S. and Allied victory in the Persian Gulf War. And the third part of it is George Bush as mister nice guy and I think the lead piece there would be the man who's trying to improve our schools, working with Secretary of Education Lamar Alexander, getting out into local communities, trying to help people do something they want done.

GERMOND: Yeah, that the -- it is quite clear that this goes back to this question of the (inaudible) by the minute, Bernie, about agenda setting. If George Bush is allowed to do things, for example setting that 100-day deadline for these two bills to be passed and to get away with it, the Democrats will never get off their backs to get into the ball game. But that is not necessarily assured if there is a right kind of a candidate.

SHAW: Gentleman, in the few seconds we have left, if you voted three fingers on your hands, among the Democrats who's first hottest?

BRODER: This week, I think Tom Harkin is probably the hottest candidate. He is not at all known nationally, Senator from Iowa. He is really talking the language that the liberal labor part of the Democratic Party loves to hear.

SHAW: Second hottest?

BRODER: Jack?

GERMOND: Well, I mean, you have one of those situation where Democrats are going have a pet rock every month which is what happened last time.

BRODER: Is that pet Rockefeller, is that -- is pet rock is Rockefeller?

GERMOND: I think right now those who were showing the most interest, the most formidable is potentially is Rockefeller.

SHAW: OK.

GERMOND: I think he has the right issue in healthcare, and I think he has the -- some of the kind of celebrity that sort of transcends the usual labels.

SHAW: On that note from Jack Germond, we thank you, we thank David Broder in Washington. Now, back to Susan.

ROOK: And still to come on PRIME NEWS, tragedy hits the opening round of the U.S. Open Golf Championship. And what's the value of the copy of the Declaration of Independence $4 or millions of dollars. When we return, we'll tell you the going price set at a New York auction.

ROOK: The 39 Paris air show open Thursday to the thunder of supersonic jet fighters swooping overhead. During the next nine days, hundreds of aircraft will be put on display, everything from a single pilot helicopters to the stealth fighter. Paris Air Show is the world's largest showcase for aviation and aerospace technology. Salesmanship is the name of the game. Aviation firms from around the world will be trying to find as many buyers as possible in what's considered a depressed market for aircraft.

SHAW: Now with a sports report we go back to Atlanta and Nick Charles.

NICK CHARLES, CNN SPORTS REPORTER: The U.S. Open golf tournament started today in Chaska, Minnesota, but anything achieved by the players on the course was vastly overshadowed by the tragedy that struck there. An intense thunder cell moved in on the course and six spectators seeking shelter under the tree were struck by lightning. Rescue workers rushed to the scene, one man was fatally injured. He died of cardiac arrest and has not yet been identified pending notification of family.

16 calling out in the action, Billy Andrade, his nice looking approach sails over the green into the water. Andrade with two eights on the back nine, that's the toughest open course. Now, out of the sand, Jeff Sluman to the bottom of the cup. That's the fourth hole, we go to the 10th, Nolan Henke. It'll break right and it'll break perfectly right. His sixth birdie of the day on the way to being five under par. The lightning and bad weather has held up play and they're still trying to complete the first round, Nolan Henke so far, the leader on a tragic first day of the U.S. Open.

Well the city of Chicago sure find a way to cure the midweek workweek blast. They celebrated championship that was 25 years in the making. The Chicago Bulls came home with their first NBA championship today thanks to a five-game romp over Lakers that they put the finishing touches on last night in Los Angeles. Thousands of fans jammed O'Hare International Airport today to give the Bulls the red carpet welcome but only a few were allowed into the terminal to greet the returning heroes.

While most Chicagoan celebrated quietly, some took to the streets to party last night. Police estimated 10,000 people stopped traffic in Rush Street which runs to the heart of the nightlife district. However, things got out of hand elsewhere and a 115 were arrested for isolated looting on the Westside near Chicago Stadium. At least two people were shot during the post game rivalry. But despite the problem, Chicago Mayor Richard Daley called the championship the best thing to happen in the city in a long time. The Bulls will be toasted by the city tomorrow at a special victory celebration beginning at noon in Grant Park.

Well overshadowed but not forgotten was the baseball game in Chicago today and the Cubs won that beating the visiting San Francisco Giants in a dynamic finish. The Cubs were clinging to a one run lead when the Giants loaded the bases of one out the ninth and Mike Kingery lofted a fly to shallow right field, Andre Dawson playing the center field knew the runner on third could challenge his arm, and Tony Perezchica did. And Dawson fired a bullet that shot down the runner, completed the double play and finished off the Giants beautifully.

We'll have a lot more baseball coming up at 11:30 Eastern time, including a look at the Minnesota Twins trying to win their 12th straight game. Also a fine look back at a memorable match up that may never come our way again, Magic Johnson and Michael Jordan. Well I see you at 11:30 Eastern time for that.

Now, though PRIME NEWS continues back in Washington with Bernard Shaw. SHAW: Thanks, Nick, we've get a match up that goes back millions of years. There's new evidence to support one theory of what killed dinosaurs. The theory, dust and debris stirred up by an asteroid crashing into the earth caused a climate change so great the dinosaurs could not adapt and they died. It's believed this happened about 64 million years ago. Scientists now say test and pieces of melted glass found in Haiti backup the theory. It's a type of glass that an asteroid collision would form and those tests show it's also about 64 million years old.

ROOK: Tough, I think that's neat. Well the weather is often a mystery, let's check it out, Flip Spiceland is the expert.

FLIP SPICELAND, CNN WEATHER FORECASTER: And as Nick told you in his sports report, it's been an absolutely horrendous day weather-wise in the upper Midwest. This, a satellite loop indicates the building of the thunderstorms starting in the early afternoon and ending in the evening hours. Watch how they just grow here in the upper Midwest not only in Minnesota but North and South Dakota down into Nebraska too. They are still under the gun. There are still severe thunderstorm watches and tornado watches in effect in this area of the country. I'll give you a graphic display of those in just one moment.

But before we get away from the satellite photograph I want to show you how the thunderstorms built across the South too and also here throughout the Rockies. Watch them pop up here. Look at that, they just popped up in late afternoon hours due to the heat and humidity.

Now, let's take a look at our CNN color radar summary, severe thunderstorm watches of the boxes here in light blue. This is a tornado watch. You can see a bad storm sail here in North Dakota within the tornado watch. You see a bad storm sail here in the area of Minneapolis-St. Paul suburbs, just to the north of them.

A look now at the predicted high-temperature for tomorrow would be another hot one in the Midwest with 90s reaching as far north as northern Iowa. The only cool weather would be here in the Northwest. We'll see some place with high zone in the 50s. Our forecast weather map for tomorrow indicates that thunderstorms are once again possible here in the upper Midwest as the warm humid air comes in behind this and the cooler air comes in from the west behind this.

Right now, take a look at specific forecast for cities around the nation for tomorrow.

Now back to Bernard Shaw in Washington.

SHAW: Thank you, Flip. Good to see you.

When PRIME NEWS returns another big tech at Southern Bays of New York, not Van Gogh, this time it's Jefferson and company.

SHAW: A first printing of the Declaration of Independence sold for a record $2.4 million more than twice pre-auction estimates. The 215- year-old document, one of just two dozen copies known to exist was the featured item at Southern Bays Americana auction. And there's declaration report was found stuffed inside the frame of a $4 painting. It still is a good buys as Thursday's winning bidder Atlanta investor Donald Scheer.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD SCHEER, DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE BUYER: I think it's bargain particularly what's going on in the world today. I think this is a living document. The words in this document are the words that knock down the Berlin Wall, that freed Poland, and probably elected Boris Yeltsin yesterday in Russia. I think these words are -- is alive today as they were when they were penned in 1776.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAW: Yeah, and they say Mr. Scheer's copy of the declaration is in almost perfect condition. And that concludes this edition of PRIME NEWS. I'm Bernard Shaw in Washington.

ROOK: We'll see you in one hour, I'm Susan Rook at CNN Center in Atlanta. "Larry King Live" is next.

Larry, what's coming up tonight?

LARRY KING, LARRY KING LIVE HOST: We're going to meet some people with incredible stories to tell about self abuse and recovery. And we're going to meet the wonderfully talented Larry Hagman. All ahead on "Larry King Live" next on CNN, don't go away.

urn:contentItem:609H-MS31-JCSC-J0WP-00000-00Stimulus checks, but not as many2020-07-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:10ZLexisNexisNEWSStimulus checks, but not as manyBERNIE BECKER

Programming announcement: Our newsletters are evolving. Morning Tax will continue to publish daily for POLITICO Pro subscribers, but starting on July 13th will consolidate to a weekly newsletter for all others. There will be no changes to the policy newsle... Programming announcement: Our newsletters are evolving. Morning Tax will continue to publish daily for POLITICO Pro subscribers,...

Programming announcement: Our newsletters are evolving. Morning Tax will continue to publish daily for POLITICO Pro subscribers, but starting on July 13th will consolidate to a weekly newsletter for all others. There will be no changes to the policy newsle...

Programming announcement: Our newsletters are evolving. Morning Tax will continue to publish daily for POLITICO Pro subscribers, but starting on July 13th will consolidate to a weekly newsletter for all others. There will be no changes to the policy newsletters available to POLITICO Pro subscribers. To continue to receive Morning Tax daily, as well as access POLITICO Pro’s full suite of policy tools and trackers, get in touch about a Pro subscription. Already a Pro subscriber? Learn more here. Quick Fix — Baby steps on the next coronavirus package: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell floated the idea of a stricter income cap on a second round of stimulus checks. — Oh, there were takes on this: A foundation of Grover Norquist's Americans for Tax Reform, with its longstanding goal of shrinking the size of government, was among the groups that accepted Paycheck Protection Program loans. — Margrethe Vestager, Silicon Valley’s bane from Brussels, still has Big Tech in her sights. A message from H&R Block: H&R Block supports small businesses: With millions of small businesses served by H&R Block and Wave, and our network of franchisees who are small business owners in their communities, we understand the vital role of small businesses in local economies. Visit our coronavirus small business resource center for more. WELCOME BACK to Morning Tax, where we were definitely here for The Washington Tax Extenders football team joke — with the caveat that only it really lands with a limited audience. (Though, have to say: Pretty darn good engagement on that tweet!) Almost a century of looking for the next best thing: Today marks 92 years since the Chillicothe Baking Company (of Chillicothe, Mo.) became the first to offer sliced bread. Need a break from the at-home sourdough? Send us tips and feedback. Email: [email protected], [email protected], [email protected] and [email protected]. You can also reach us on Twitter at @aaronelorenzo, @berniebecker3, @tobyeckert, @brianfaler, @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Tax. Driving the Day WHAT’S NEXT? There certainly doesn’t seem to be any sprint toward reaching a fourth or fifth (depending on your definition) Covid-19 relief measure, with McConnell also saying on Monday while back in Kentucky that Senate Republicans would release a new proposal once they return to Washington in two weeks — which would give Congress about two more workweeks to figure something out before expanded unemployment insurance runs out. But the majority leader did sound pretty onboard with another round of stimulus checks, as NBC News reported, something that House Democrats also approved in their latest coronavirus package back in May, and that the White House has become more vocal in supporting. McConnell’s marker — suggesting those checks should be limited to those making around $40,000 a year — also came as no surprise to Democrats, who have been hearing Republicans say that the next Covid-19 legislation should be more targeted for awhile now. There’s clearly still some fleshing out needed there — for instance, would that $40,000 be for single filers? And if so, what’s the cut-off for married couples? (Stimulus checks phased out completely at $99,000 and $198,000 in the CARES Act.) In any event, it suggests that Republicans are consolidating behind the idea of sending direct payments to a smaller universe of taxpayers, if still a pretty large chunk of families. More Covid-19 odds and ends: McConnell also specifically pointed out how the pandemic has dragged down key parts of the tourism industry, like hotels and restaurants — another area where both President Donald Trump and other GOP officials have been talking about offering aid. Interestingly enough, the chief executive of Tripadvisor, Stephen Kaufer, said over the weekend that a tax incentive for vacationers — one of the ideas that’s out there, and one that hasn’t gotten great reviews from experts — wouldn’t make much of a difference. “What's best for the travel industry, at least my opinion, is really getting the pandemic under control. And that isn't about a tax credit for someone to take a vacation, it's really about leadership from our federal government, from the state governments, from local governments,” Kaufer said on CBS’ “Face the Nation.” More Sunday show: Labor Secretary Eugene Scalia reiterated the Trump administration’s interest in a payroll tax cut on “Fox News Sunday,” even though the White House is on something of an island with that desire. And finally: Here’s another group hoping for help from the next Covid-19 measure — barbershops and beauty salons, lots of which are owned by minorities and/or women and can’t offer takeout like restaurants. The Professional Beauty Association is seeking the same kind of incentive currently available to restaurants, which can get a tax credit for payroll taxes paid on customer tips, as Bloomberg Tax’s Kaustuv Basu noted. HAPPENING TOMORROW AT 12 PM EDT - HOW IS MAYOR FRANCIS SUAREZ APPROACHING THE COVID-19 SPIKE IN MIAMI? A rapid spike in coronavirus cases has forced Miami to scale back reopening plans. What will come next? Join POLITICO Nightly author Renuka Rayasam and Miami Mayor Francis Suarez for a conversation about the next steps, including plans to handle the virus' resurgence, measures that will take shape when schools reopen, and how a city reliant on tourism can recover from the devastation wrought by the pandemic. REGISTER HERE. THEY WERE DOWN WITH PPP: The ATR affiliate received between $150,000 and $350,000 from PPP, according to data released on Monday by the Treasury Department and Small Business Administration. Of course, Norquist has long fought for lower taxes while railing against federal spending — he once famously said he hoped to shrink the government down to a size that it could be drowned in a bathtub. In a statement, ATR said the money was for its foundation, a related 501c(3) organization that it said had been “badly hurt” by the lockdown, and the loan allowed it to “maintain its employees without laying anyone off.” ATR also noted in the statement that it did not oppose creating the PPP because it was “compensation for a government taking during the shutdown.” But also of course: That didn’t stop the charges of hypocrisy from flowing in. (Among the other groups to get a PPP loan: The Ayn Rand Institute.) “So much for his disdain for federal assistance,” as Elise Bean, a former Senate tax investigator, put it. “Instead, his organization is now a poster child showing how PPP funds are going to those who don’t need the money but are well connected — here, an anti-tax group that reports losses year after year but has never gone out of business.” Others noted that Norquist signed on to a letter imploring Washington to stop pouring on the spending after the CARES Act was passed — something that would, for instance, make life more difficult for states and localities that are also trying to stave off layoffs. And yet: Hypocrisy accusations aside, most everyone seems to agree that the ATR foundation used the program exactly as policymakers intended. Also of note: There are still PPP funds left over, so the foundation didn’t box out another company or organization for the money. Another good question: Might it have been better for the government’s bottom line for the foundation to take the loan, instead of laying off employees who then would have gotten expanded unemployment insurance? Around the World SHE’S BACK: Vestager is starting to lay out a new regulatory agenda aimed at fostering more competition in the tech field, dealing with issues like companies’ liabilities for their content. But on the tax front, the big issue in Brussels is still a bloc-wide digital tax now that the global Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development process is on the skids. And Vestager remains a full-throated supporter of that idea: “So many businesses have to work very hard to make a profit, and from that profit to then pay taxes,” she said, via The Wall Street Journal. “They should not be met with competitors for capital, skilled employees and customers who do not contribute to society. More OECD: Watch out for this — as our colleagues in Europe noted, the OECD is considering decoupling Pillar One (dealing with tax base issues) and Pillar Two (seeking a global minimum tax), and could put that idea in front of G-20 finance ministers in the coming weeks. That’s basically what Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin called for when he threw the talks into upheaval last month, but it’s also not something that may go over well among other negotiators. WINNERS PLAY THE LONG GAME: Now more than ever, it's essential to look ahead to how society will thrive in the future. "The Long Game" is a newsletter designed for executives, investors and policymakers leading that conversation. Sustainability starts in your inbox; engage with the sharpest minds on our biggest challenges, from pandemics to environmental justice, climate change to renewable energy, inequality, and the future of work. Subscribe today for a nuanced look at these problems and possible solutions. Around the Nation IT’S ON: The Seattle City Council cleared a new tax on big businesses that’s expected to raise some $200 million a year for housing and other priorities, The Seattle Times reported. It’s the latest effort by the council to squeeze more revenue out of Amazon and other companies paying high salaries in the city. Mayor Jenny Durkan has supported previous measures to tax big companies, but has expressed concerns about the new bill that would tax businesses based on how many employees make at least $150,000 a year. A message from H&R Block: H&R Block launches more resources and services for small businesses: Small businesses are at the heart of communities across the country, and they’ve been hit hard by the pandemic. That’s why H&R Block is helping with new resources and services. Visit our coronavirus small business resource center for updates on government assistance programs and available aid for small business owners, and check out Wave Money, a first-of-its-kind, all-in-one small business banking and bookkeeping solution, with no fees and instant access to your money. Together, we will help America’s small business community survive, reopen and thrive once more.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:549H-21F1-DYTG-J1D6-00000-00Stimulus helped some stocks soar2011-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:10ZLexisNexisPg. ARCStimulus helped some stocks soar

By Tim Mullaney

Special for USA TODAY

As Congress and the White House launch investigations into renewable-energy loan guarantees made to companies such as Solyndra under the 2009 stimulus bill and related legislation, a USA TODAY analysis shows that a series of public companies that got help have soundly beaten the stock market and most venture-capital funds raised in 2008.

With debate raging in Washington about whether government can effectively pick winners and losers in a fast-changing economy, the data shed light on how well the Obama administration did the two major jobs that venture capital performs in a high-tech economy -- helping investors make money and bringing new technology to market. Skeptics have pointed to former Obama economics adviser Lawrence Summers' comment in a 2009 e-mail that "government is a crappy VC" to argue that the $787 billion stimulus measure was packed with waste.

About $100 billion of stimulus funding was earmarked for technology spending, according to tech consulting firm International Data Corp. Two-thirds was for energy technology, and most of the rest will subsidize doctors' adoption of electronic medical-records (EMR) software. At USA TODAY's request, IDC identified major beneficiaries of that spending to examine whether the money helped companies grow and bring technologies to market.

The analysis covered more than 45 companies that are public or have registered for initial public offerings, including most leading makers of electronic medical-records software and electric cars, and a small selection of the 5,000-plus companies and local government agencies that got clean-energy stimulus grants. Separately, USA TODAY looked at the recipients of all 38 completed or pending loan guarantees under the Energy Department's three major financing programs, including well-known public companies such as Ford, Southern Cos. and NRG, not on IDC's list. In all, the included companies, or their customers, are to receive more than two-thirds of the technology funding.

So far, the legislation has sparked adoption of electronic medical-records software and nurtured an electric-car industry that will sell at least 20,000 cars this year. At least 19 companies have gone public or filed for IPOs after getting stimulus money, from Solazyme's $21.8 million grant to build a pilot biofuels refinery to a $1.6 billion loan guarantee letting BrightSource Energy build the world's biggest solar-generation plant of its kind, according to securities-disclosure filings.

The stimulus has helped spark an 82(PERCENT) gain in the stocks of 11 health care technology companies since President Obama took office and a 263(PERCENT) gain in the three public companies that took $7.8 billion of federal financing to build next-generation vehicle factories. It contributed to a 79(PERCENT) jump in stocks of the four leading energy-efficiency companies identified by IDC, including diversified companies such as Johnson Controls and Honeywell. Companies involved in developing smart electric grids, nine big tech firms that are also in many other businesses, have risen 54(PERCENT).

All these match or exceed the 51(PERCENT) gain in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and beat the 4.9(PERCENT) average annual gain in venture funds raised in 2008, according to Cambridge Associates. The big exception is that the five solar-power companies and advanced-battery manufacturers on IDC's list have fallen 70(PERCENT). Similarly, among the loan-guarantee recipients examined by USA TODAY, solar-power related companies such as Solyndra and energy-storage companies such as Beacon Power, which filed for bankruptcy reorganization Oct. 31, have fared the worst.

The impact is filtering into the real economy, too.

Solazyme's algae-based jet fuel powered its first United Airlines flight on Nov. 7. More than 40(PERCENT) of doctors now use electronic medical records, up from 29(PERCENT) two years ago, including 75(PERCENT) of those working in groups of more than 25 physicians, according to research firm SK&A. More electric cars are hitting the road, with Fisker Automotive's $95,900 luxury sedan reaching U.S. stores this month, as Tesla Motors gears up to supply batteries for Toyota's electric RAV4 SUVs, in addition to launching its Model S sedan next year.

Even a venture capitalist who cautioned the White House about its public support for Solyndra says the stimulus overall was still a good idea.

"The government has been a better VC than a certain number of people on the Street," said Steve Westly, a former California state controller and Obama fundraiser whose venture firm backed Tesla and biochemicals company Amyris, which each got aid. Westly sent a well-publicized e-mail to Obama aide Valerie Jarrett, trying to persuade the White House not to have the president visit Solyndra.

Getting some flak

The stimulus' technology-boosting plan sparked a firestorm when Solyndra defaulted on its federal loan in August. The Republican National Committee on Nov. 9 lumped the programs with the collapse of investment bank MF Global amid Europe's debt crisis as evidence of the administration's financial mismanagement. "This is a classic case of waste, fraud and abuse," House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton, R-Mich., said in August. Department of Energy spokesman Damien LaVera declined to make senior officials available for comment.

The success or failure of the stimulus is about more than stock prices. The number of permanent jobs created or saved in the government's loan guarantee programs is about 40,000, plus several thousand more construction jobs. More than three-fourths of the permanent jobs are at Ford. The government owns stock in few of the companies it backs, meaning others reap the gains. In most others, Washington's skin in the game is only the company's ability to repay loans that the government makes or guarantees.

Furthermore, stimulus funding isn't the only reason many companies that received it have prospered. General Electric's $210 million of stimulus revenue is less than one-tenth of 1(PERCENT) of sales, spokesman Andrew Williams said. Likewise, Dell and IBM have cashed in on smart-grid development or health records upgrades and been boosted much more by the broader recovery. Even at a smaller company such as Solazyme, stimulus aid was far less than the $280 million it raised in venture capital and IPO funding.

Still, government bridged a bond-market gap that has lingered since the 2008 financial panic, said Scott Sandell, a partner at New Enterprise Associates (NEA), the nation's largest venture firm.

"Across all the clean-tech sectors we invest in, there has been a tremendous paucity of capital at any stage of a company's development where there's any risk," said Sandell, whose firm backs Fisker, which got a $529 million loan guarantee to retrofit an ex-General Motors plant in Delaware. "Trust me, it's been a barren landscape."

A leading IPO analyst concurred, saying the stimulus built market confidence in companies such as Tesla, helping them attract IPO investors and corporate partners.

"The government money was a platform, and a few of them like Tesla used that and flew off on their own," said Francis Gaskins, editor of IPO Desktop. "Many of them looked at the government money as a way to do things they might have done anyway."

Healthy gains

The clearest connection between the stimulus and the economy might be in health care software, in which the boost in companies' value far exceeds the amount spent so far in a five-year program costing up to $30 billion. Together, the gain in value of companies such as McKesson, Cerner and Athenahealth since the stimulus bill was proposed is at least $20 billion.

The stimulus has paid about $100 million so far to clients of Cerner, the largest maker of electronic medical-records(EMRs) software, said Piper Jaffray analyst Sean Wieland. Given Cerner's 20(PERCENT) market share, that translates into $500 million in extra annual sales for the industry, which may double as lower Medicare reimbursements, also part of the stimulus law, kick in for doctors who don't use EMRs by 2015, he said.

"This really did accelerate adoption," said Jeff Townsend, chief of staff at Kansas City, Mo.-based Cerner, whose stock-price value is up 194(PERCENT) or $6.5 billion, since January 2009. Cerner's new-software sales rose 26(PERCENT) in the first nine months of 2011 vs. 2010's pace of 16(PERCENT). He said extra spending will add to growth, as doctors upgrade their systems and connect them to each other.

That spending has lifted nearly all health information technology stocks. Allscripts Healthcare Solutions, an EMR company whose CEO Glen Tullman raised money for Obama in 2008, has seen shares rise 134(PERCENT). Rival Athenahealth, which supplies Internet-based medical-billing and EMR services as a cheaper alternative to software, has doubled since mid-2010.

The question is whether the spending was efficient, says Athenahealth CEO Jonathan Bush, who has donated to Mitt Romney's presidential campaigns and is former president George W. Bush's cousin. He says Washington could have spurred adoption of cheaper, more flexible technology such as his through regulatory changes without subsidizing software.

"We're a beneficiary of stimulus spending, but we'd be doing even better without it," said Bush, whose company benefitted from the administration's decision to have Medicare reimburse doctors for regularly using EMRs, favoring pay-as-you-go Internet business models such as Athena's, rather than paying for software purchases up front. "What you really needed was hundreds of cloud-based companies innovating."

By government standards, the health care stimulus was fairly disciplined, Townsend contends. Doctors aren't reimbursed for software until they show they're routinely using it for work such as prescribing medications, he said. While knitting together networks owned by different doctors and hospitals will take time, data-sharing is essential to contain overall health care spending, he said.

Getting it out there

The energy stimulus is more controversial. More than 5,000 grants totaling $34.6 billion and 38 loans and loan guarantees totaling an additional $35.9 billion have been approved. But $11.3 billion of loan deals haven't closed and just $19.2 billion of the grant money has been spent, according to Energy Department data.

Energy stimulus produced the best-known stimulus failure, Solyndra. A congressional panel is investigating whether politics tainted Solyndra's loan review, and plans to probe other guarantees.

Also struggling is A123 Systems, which won a $249.1 million grant to build a Michigan factory for electric-car batteries. Its stock has fallen 83(PERCENT) since its 2009 IPO. A123, which lost $172.8 million for the first nine months of 2011, said it will break even by 2013, excluding taxes, interest and non-cash accounting charges.

Another loan-guarantee recipient, Beacon Power, filed for bankruptcy protection Oct. 30.

Not all the money is for high-risk deals. More than $10 billion in loans are scheduled for two nuclear plants, both backed by utilities with investment-grade credit. Another $8.3 billion has been loaned to Ford, Nissan, Tesla and Fisker to develop fuel-effective vehicles. Almost $6 billion went to Ford to develop new versions of models that sell 2 million units annually.

In each guarantee, the government will only lose money if the borrower defaults.

The $13 billion-plus for solar loans is divided between $1.82 billion for plants to manufacture equipment for newer technologies, including Solyndra; and more than $11 billion to build solar-power generation plants, mostly using existing methods. Loans to solar farms are safer, as those deals include long-term contracts for utilities to buy electricity produced at projects such as BrightSource's $1.6 billion Ivanpah, Calif., facility, said Lux Research analyst Andrew Soare.

Investors have already made big returns on companies in several DOE projects. Tesla raised venture capital at $7.53 a share in May 2009, got its loan guarantee that June, went public at $17 last year and now is worth $32.60 a share, or $3.4 billion. Ford is up fivefold, driven by a global auto recovery.

The loan "lets us get to where we can make mass-market electric vehicles," said Diarmuid O'Connell, Tesla's vice president of business development. He said taxpayers also win if electric cars trim U.S. oil imports. "For either economic or policy reasons, you have to do what's next," he said.

If anything, the industry has been held back recently because U.S. loan guarantees are hard to get or come with red tape, Sandell said. A better offer from China's government helped persuade NEA-backed solar-cell maker Suniva to build a factory in Asia rather than Michigan, he said. KiOR, which is developing wood-based ethanol substitutes, deferred its application for a $1.1 billion guarantee to finance refineries in Mississippi until 2012, although the program's funding is in limbo.

"It may never close," Vinod Khosla, a VC who controls a 72(PERCENT) voting stake in KiOR , said in a September interview with The Daily, Rupert Murdoch's iPad newspaper. KiOR went public in June, after winning a tentative loan-guarantee commitment, making an 11-fold gain on pre-IPO shares. "If you can get an (ExxonMobil) or a Chevron to work with you, why go through the federal government?"

The volatile stock market will help determine the success or failure of the stimulus, whether measured by gains in market value or jobs created, said NEA's Sandell, a frequent donor to Democratic politicians.

Start-ups that go public create 90(PERCENT) of their jobs post-IPO, he said, citing a study commissioned by the National Venture Capital Association. It will take years before the full impact of stimulus-funded companies is apparent, while Solyndra-like mistakes typically reveal themselves quickly, he said.

"If it succeeds, it will succeed because a handful of companies produced extraordinary results," said Sandell. "The lemons always show up first. That's the story of the venture capital business."

--
