urn:contentItem:549F-0PV1-JC8N-K46M-00000-00Stimulus helped some stocks soar;Technology in health, energy sectors saw big gains2011-11-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:10ZLexisNexisMONEYPg. 1BStimulus helped some stocks soarTechnology in health, energy sectors saw big gainsTim Mullaney

As Congress and the White House launch investigations into renewable-energy loan guarantees made to companies such as Solyndraunder the 2009 stimulus bill and related legislation, a USA TODAY analysis shows that a series of public companies that got help have soundly beaten the stock market and most venture-capital funds raised in 2008.

With debate raging in Washington about whether government can effectively pick winners and losers in a fast-changing economy, the data shed light on how well the Obama administration did the two major jobs that venture capital performs in a high-tech economy -- helping investors make money and bringing new technology to market. Skeptics have pointed to former Obama economics adviser Lawrence Summers' comment in a 2009 e-mail that "government is a crappy VC" to argue that the $787 billion stimulus measure was packed with waste.

About $100 billion of stimulus funding was earmarked for technology spending, according to tech consulting firm International Data Corp. Two-thirds was for energy technology, and most of the rest will subsidize doctors' adoption of electronic medical-records (EMR) software. At USA TODAY's request, IDC identified major beneficiaries of that spending to examine whether the money helped companies grow and bring technologies to market.

The analysis covered more than 45 companies that are public or have registered for initial public offerings, including most leading makers of electronic medical-records software and electric cars, and a small selection of the 5,000-plus companies and local government agencies that got clean-energy stimulus grants. Separately, USA TODAY looked at the recipients of all 38 completed or pending loan guarantees under the Energy Department's three major financing programs, including well-known public companies such as Ford, Southern Cos. and NRG, not on IDC's list. In all, the included companies, or their customers, are to receive more than two-thirds of the technology funding.

So far, the legislation has sparked adoption of electronic medical-records software and nurtured an electric-car industry that will sell at least 20,000 cars this year. At least 19 companies have gone public or filed for IPOs after getting stimulus money, from Solazyme's $21.8 million grant to build a pilot biofuels refinery to a $1.6 billion loan guarantee letting BrightSource Energy build the world's biggest solar-generation plant of its kind, according to securities-disclosure filings.

The stimulus has helped spark an 82% gain in the stocks of 11 health care technology companies since President Obama took office and a 263% gain in the three public companies that took $7.8 billion of federal financing to build next-generation vehicle factories. It contributed to a 79% jump in stocks of the four leading energy-efficiency companies identified by IDC, including diversified companies such as Johnson Controls and Honeywell. Companies involved in developing smart electric grids, nine big tech firms that are also in many other businesses, have risen 54%.

All these match or exceed the 51% gain in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and beat the 4.9% average annual gain in venture funds raised in 2008, according to Cambridge Associates. The big exception is that the five solar-power companies and advanced-battery manufacturers on IDC's list have fallen 70%. Similarly, among the loan-guarantee recipients examined by USA TODAY, solar-power-related companies such as Solyndraand energy-storage companies such as Beacon Power, which filed for bankruptcy reorganization Oct. 31, have fared the worst.

The impact is filtering into the real economy, too.

Solazyme's algae-based jet fuel powered its first United Airlines flight on Nov. 7. More than 40% of doctors now use electronic medical records, up from 29% two years ago, including 75% of those working in groups of more than 25 physicians, according to research firm SK&A. More electric cars are hitting the road, with Fisker Automotive's $95,900 luxury sedan reaching U.S. stores this month, as Tesla Motors gears up to supply batteries for Toyota's electric RAV4 SUVs, in addition to launching its Model S sedan next year.

Even a venture capitalist who cautioned the White House about its public support for Solyndra says the stimulus overall was still a good idea.

"The government has been a better VC than a certain number of people on the Street," said Steve Westly, a former California state controller and Obama fundraiser whose venture firm backed Tesla and biochemicals company Amyris, which each got aid. Westly sent a well-publicized e-mail to Obama aide Valerie Jarrett, trying to persuade the White House not to have the president visit Solyndra.

Getting some flak

The stimulus' technology-boosting plan sparked a firestorm when Solyndradefaulted on its federal loan in August. The Republican National Committee on Nov. 9 lumped the programs with the collapse of investment bank MF Global amid Europe's debt crisis as evidence of the administration's financial mismanagement. "This is a classic case of waste, fraud and abuse," House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton, R-Mich., said in August. Department of Energy spokesman Damien LaVera declined to make senior officials available for comment.

The success or failure of the stimulus is about more than stock prices. The number of permanent jobs created or saved in the government's loan guarantee programs is about 40,000, plus several thousand more construction jobs. More than three-fourths of the permanent jobs are at Ford. The government owns stock in few of the companies it backs, meaning others reap the gains. In most others, Washington's skin in the game is only the company's ability to repay loans that the government makes or guarantees.

Furthermore, stimulus funding isn't the only reason many companies that received it have prospered. General Electric's $210 million of stimulus revenue is less than one-tenth of 1% of sales, spokesman Andrew Williams said. Likewise, Dell and IBM have cashed in on smart-grid development or health records upgrades and been boosted much more by the broader recovery. Even at a smaller company such as Solazyme, stimulus aid was far less than the $280 million it raised in venture capital and IPO funding.

Still, government bridged a bond market gap that has lingered since the 2008 financial panic, said Scott Sandell, a partner at New Enterprise Associates (NEA), the nation's largest venture firm.

"Across all the clean-tech sectors we invest in, there has been a tremendous paucity of capital at any stage of a company's development where there's any risk," said Sandell, whose firm backs Fisker, which got a $529 million loan guarantee to retrofit an ex-General Motors plant in Delaware. "Trust me, it's been a barren landscape."

A leading IPO analyst concurred, saying the stimulus built market confidence in companies such as Tesla, helping them attract IPO investors and corporate partners.

"The government money was a platform, and a few of them like Tesla used that and flew off on their own," said Francis Gaskins, editor of IPO Desktop. "Many of them looked at the government money as a way to do things they might have done anyway."

Healthy gains

The clearest connection between the stimulus and the economy might be in health care software, in which the boost in companies' value far exceeds the amount spent so far in a five-year program costing up to $30 billion. Together, the gain in value of companies such as McKesson, Cerner and Athenahealth since the stimulus bill was proposed is at least $20 billion.

The stimulus has paid about $100 million so far to clients of Cerner, the largest maker of electronic medical-records (EMR) software, said Piper Jaffray analyst Sean Wieland. Given Cerner's 20% market share, that translates into $500 million in extra annual sales for the industry, which may double as lower Medicare reimbursements, also part of the stimulus law, kick in for doctors who don't use EMRs by 2015, he said.

"This really did accelerate adoption," said Jeff Townsend, chief of staff at Kansas City, Mo.-based Cerner, whose stock-price value is up 194% or $6.5 billion, since January 2009. Cerner's new-software sales rose 26% in the first nine months of 2011 vs. 2010's pace of 16%. He said extra spending will add to growth, as doctors upgrade their systems and connect them to each other.

That spending has lifted nearly all health information technology stocks. Allscripts Healthcare Solutions, an EMR company whose CEO Glen Tullman raised money for Obama in 2008, has seen shares rise 134%. Rival Athenahealth, which supplies Internet-based medical-billing and EMR services as a cheaper alternative to software, has doubled since mid-2010.

The question is whether the spending was efficient, says Athenahealth CEO Jonathan Bush, who has donated to Mitt Romney's presidential campaigns and is former president George W. Bush's cousin. He says Washington could have spurred adoption of cheaper, more flexible technology such as his through regulatory changes without subsidizing software.

"We're a beneficiary of stimulus spending, but we'd be doing even better without it," said Bush, whose company benefitted from the administration's decision to have Medicare reimburse doctors for regularly using EMRs, favoring pay-as-you-go Internet business models such as Athena's, rather than paying for software purchases up front. "What you really needed was hundreds of cloud-based companies innovating."

By government standards, the health care stimulus was fairly disciplined, Townsend contends. Doctors aren't reimbursed for software until they show they're routinely using it for work such as prescribing medications, he said. While knitting together networks owned by different doctors and hospitals will take time, data-sharing is essential to contain overall health care spending, he said.

Getting it out there

The energy stimulus is more controversial. More than 5,000 grants totaling $34.6 billion and 38 loans and loan guarantees totaling an additional $35.9 billion have been approved. But $11.3 billion of loan deals haven't closed and just $19.2 billion of the grant money has been spent, according to Energy Department data.

Energy stimulus produced the best-known stimulus failure, Solyndra. A congressional panel is investigating whether politics tainted Solyndra's loan review, and plans to probe other guarantees.

Also struggling is A123 Systems, which won a $249.1 million grant to build a Michigan factory for electric-car batteries. Its stock has fallen 83% since its 2009 IPO. A123, which lost $172.8 million for the first nine months of 2011, said it will break even by 2013, excluding taxes, interest and non-cash accounting charges.

Another loan-guarantee recipient, Beacon Power, filed for bankruptcy protection Oct. 30.

Not all the money is for high-risk deals. More than $10 billion in loans are scheduled for two nuclear plants, both backed by utilities with investment-grade credit. Another $8.3 billion has been loaned to Ford, Nissan, Tesla and Fisker to develop fuel-effective vehicles. Almost $6 billion went to Ford to develop new versions of models that sell 2 million units annually.

In each guarantee, the government will only lose money if the borrower defaults.

The $13 billion-plus for solar loans is divided between $1.82 billion for plants to manufacture equipment for newer technologies, including Solyndra; and more than $11 billion to build solar-power generation plants, mostly using existing methods. Loans to solar farms are safer, as those deals include long-term contracts for utilities to buy electricity produced at projects such as BrightSource's $1.6 billion Ivanpah, Calif., facility, said Lux Research analyst Andrew Soare.

Investors have already made big returns on companies in several DOE projects. Tesla raised venture capital at $7.53 a share in May 2009, got its loan guarantee that June, went public at $17 last year and now is worth $32.60 a share, or $3.4 billion. Ford is up fivefold, driven by a global auto recovery.

The loan "lets us get to where we can make mass-market electric vehicles," said Diarmuid O'Connell, Tesla's vice president of business development. He said taxpayers also win if electric cars trim U.S. oil imports. "For either economic or policy reasons, you have to do what's next," he said.

If anything, the industry has been held back recently because U.S. loan guarantees are hard to get or come with red tape, Sandell said. A better offer from China's government helped persuade NEA-backed solar-cell maker Suniva to build a factory in Asia rather than Michigan, he said. KiOR, which is developing wood-based ethanol substitutes, deferred its application for a $1.1 billion guarantee to finance refineries in Mississippi until 2012, although the program's funding is in limbo.

"It may never close," Vinod Khosla, a VC who controls a 72% voting stake in KiOR, said in a September interview with The Daily, Rupert Murdoch's iPad newspaper. KiOR went public in June, after winning a tentative loan-guarantee commitment, making an elevenfold gain on pre-IPO shares. "If you can get an (ExxonMobil) or a Chevron to work with you, why go through the federal government?"

The volatile stock market will help determine the success or failure of the stimulus, whether measured by gains in market value or jobs created, said NEA's Sandell, a frequent donor to Democratic politicians.

Start-ups that go public create 90% of their jobs post-IPO, he said, citing a study commissioned by the National Venture Capital Association. It will take years before the full impact of stimulus-funded companies is apparent, while Solyndra-like mistakes typically reveal themselves quickly, he said.

"If it succeeds, it will succeed because a handful of companies produced extraordinary results," said Sandell. "The lemons always show up first. That's the story of the venture capital business."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XFD-95S1-F11P-X3GS-00000-00StockBeat: Sonos Soars, Analyst Says It Hits All the Apple Notes2019-11-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisStockBeat: Sonos Soars, Analyst Says It Hits All the Apple Notes

Investing.com -

Investing.com – Sonos surged on Wednesday as one Wall Street analyst said the audio company could be next on the shopping list for big tech firms, with Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) touted as a potential suitor.

With its push into connected home efforts, which needs improvement, Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) would "materially" benefit from making a play for Sonos, said D.A. Davidson analyst Thomas Forte. Sonos (NASDAQ:SONO) rose 5%.

The spotlight on smaller hardware makers rose to the fore less than a week ago, when Google (NASDAQ:GOOGL) bought wearables company Fitbit in a $2.1 billion deal. Apple was also rumored to be circling but was not prepared to cut as big a check as Google did for the wearables company.

Sonos, however, hits all the right notes for Apple to take notice, boasting many similarities such as high product quality and design acumen. Sonos can also charge a premium given its superior brand status, according to Forte.

"Just as Fitbit fills a void for Google when it comes to healthcare-related data, acquiring Sonos could materially advance Apple's connected home efforts (an area we believe it needs improvement and where its own product, the HomePod, was a disappointment)," he added.

But there could be one hitch to a potential Apple-Sonos deal – regulation.

The regulatory powers have grown wary of big tech's growing influence and may not be eager to rubber-stamp a deal, Forte suggested.

Sonos is up 45% for the year so far.

value.Title: Stock futures flat in overnight trading as investors eye Big Tech testimony, Fed decision
value.Overview: Stock futures were little changed in overnight trading on Tuesday as investors await a congressional hearing on antitrust in Big Tech as well as the Federal Reserve's latest policy decision. Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose just 10...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G1-19H1-F07F-8199-00000-00Stock futures flat in overnight trading as investors eye Big Tech testimony, Fed decision2020-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisNEWSStock futures flat in overnight trading as investors eye Big Tech testimony, Fed decisionYun Li

Stock futures were little changed in overnight trading on Tuesday as investors await a congressional hearing on antitrust in Big Tech as well as the Federal Reserve's latest policy decision. Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose just 10...

Stock futures were little changed in overnight trading on Tuesday as investors await a congressional hearing on antitrust in Big Tech as well as the Federal Reserve's latest policy decision. Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose just 10 points. ...

Stock futures were little changed in overnight trading on Tuesday as investors await a congressional hearing on antitrust in Big Tech as well as the Federal Reserve's latest policy decision. Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose just 10 points. The S&P 500 futures were flat and the Nasdaq 100 futures gained slightly. The busiest week of corporate earnings rolled on after the bell on Tuesday. Starbucks swung to a loss during its fiscal third quarter, but the world's largest coffee chain raised forecast for the current quarter, sending shares up more than 4% in extended trading. Shares of Advanced Micro Devices popped more than 8% after the chipmaker posted better-than-expected quarterly earnings and issued an upbeat guidance. Investors will assess more results from Boeing, General Motors and General Electric before the bell Wednesday, while Qualcomm and PayPal are among the companies reporting after the close Wednesday. Chief executives of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google-parent Alphabet will testify before the House Antitrust Subcommittee at noon Wednesday following a yearlong probe into their anti-competitive practices. Investors will look for insights on how the Big Tech is handling antitrust challenges from regulators with the authority to break them up. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve will conclude its two-day policy meeting Wednesday and is set to release a statement at 2 p.m. ET. Chairman Jerome Powell will have a press conference at 2:30 p.m. ET. The central bank is expected to keep interest rate unchanged at near zero to support the economy still struggling with the coronavirus pandemic. On Tuesday, the Fed announced it would extend its emergency lending programs through the remainder of 2020. "Markets continue to expect ultra-accommodative policy from the Fed, and the Fed is unlikely to disappoint at this meeting," Bill Callahan, investment strategist at Schroders, said in an email. "Given that we are still squarely in the center of the pandemic, the only question for investors is just how dovish the Fed will be." In other news, Eastman Kodak soared nearly 40% in extended trading Tuesday after President Donald Trump announced a deal to work with the photography pioneer to produce ingredients in generic drugs.

urn:contentItem:5TNH-DVD1-JBHT-D15F-00000-00Stock Kick Off November with Broad Rally; Spotlight on the Midterms; 4 Days Until the Midterms; Google Employees Protest; Alibaba Ahead of Earnings2018-11-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisStock Kick Off November with Broad Rally; Spotlight on the Midterms; 4 Days Until the Midterms; Google Employees Protest; Alibaba Ahead of EarningsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much. Good morning, everybody. We will see you in a little while. Girls, thank you. I'm Maria Bartiromo.

Happy Friday, everybody. It is Friday, November 2nd.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Major market moves this morning, Apple shares sliding today, week revenue guidance last night on the announcement that it will no longer provide unit sales. That's stock down better than five percent right now. The technology giant at risk of losing that $1 trillion market valuation.

The other big story for the markets, of course today, the Jobs Report. October Jobs Report will be out in two and a half hours, the expectation calls for jobs of 190,000 added to the economy last month, month of October. And the unemployment rate is expected to hold steady at 3.7 percent.

We are taking a look at what that means for the midterm elections now just four days away.

We are taking a look at the rally at the open this morning. Meanwhile, despite the drag from Apple shares, stocks are expected to open big. Up 200 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, up 17 points on the S&P 500, and higher by 10 and a quarter points on the NASDAQ this morning.

This after the major indices yesterday posted their third day of gains in a row, it was a pretty good day at the close yesterday.

Take a look, up 264 points for the Dow Industrials. That was better than one percent yesterday, finishing near the highs of the day.

The NASDAQ up one and three-quarters percent, that was 128 points higher yesterday.

Checking global markets this morning, we kick it off with Europe. European indices higher across the board, FT-100 up two-thirds of one percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris up better than one percent, and the DAX Index in Germany up better than one percent as well.

In Asia overnight, markets higher across the board, best performer there, China. Actually, Korea, KOSPI Index up three and a half percent, but China also very strong up 2.7 percent on the Shanghai Composite.

On the earnings rank, we will hear from oil giants and Dow Components. ExxonMobil and Chevron today. Plus Alibaba, also set to report.

We will have those numbers and analysis, give us a little window into what's going in Chinese consumer as well.

China trade, of course, in focus. President Trump speaking with China's president, Xi Jinping yesterday, showing progress in the trade dispute.

As soon as that was announced yesterday, markets did turn around. We got some firmness when we heard that there was progress on the China deal.

Here's what IAC Chairman, Barry Diller, told me about China's trade practices

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARRY DILLER, CHAIRMAN, IAC: Their trade practices have to change. And us, being tough-minded about it, I think it's sensible. I think us being outrageous and excessive about it is dangerous.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest this morning. More from Barry Diller as well on technology and what's been happening with tech stocks, all those stories coming up this Friday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal's Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Bench Mark Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly.

Great to see you this morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: Look who's back two days in a row?

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Yes, love it. Love it.

FREEMAN: Yes, so exciting. I'm sorry you had to impose this on your viewers again, but --

BARTIROMO: I'm so happy you're back. Yes. It's great.

FREEMAN: -- I'm going to be here for a little while. The -- you know, I don't think the President said it was fantastic, but he did say it was good and nice talking to President Xi Jinping, so --

MCDOWELL: Very good.

FREEMAN: -- let's hope this is a step toward resolution of the trade dispute.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's right. And when we heard that they had the phone call, it actually did help markets yesterday.

MCDOWELL: Right. Take --

FREEMAN: Yes, and I --

BARTIROMO: Big boost.

FREEMAN: I think that's a lot of what you're seeing in the futures here as well.

MCDOWELL: And on Apple's side, it's not just the revenue forecast for the December quarter, it's also the fact that they're -- they are no longer going to break out device unit sales in any future financial results.

So basically, Apple is telling investors, "You're going to get a lot less information from us about what is going on with the company, with sales of our devices," and that's why the stock down five percent.

But Apple was only down three percent in the month of October when Amazon was in a bear market losing 20 percent of its value.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point, yes.

MCDOWELL: We talked about that yesterday morning.

So, again, revenue is a problem and then when any company says, "Oh, by the way, we're going to give you less information --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- that's not --

BARTIROMO: That's what happened to --

MCDOWELL: That's what happens to the stock.

BARTIROMO: That's what happened to Oracle a couple of weeks ago. I mean - - and a lot of the analysts who have said that they said that they weren't going to break out cloud revenue and these specific lines within the cloud revenue, less transparency, you know, and so that's one thing.

So we're going to know less about how the company makes --

FREEMAN: But the revenue and the earnings are good.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: It's just the outlook.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

FREEMAN: And then that's -- we have seen that with a lot of these companies, where the numbers are fine, it's the future and the concern, and maybe some of it is going away now with this discussion on China.

KELLY: But --

MCDOWELL: Amazon --

BARTIROMO: And which is the issue. Which is the issue. Are we going to see growth slowdown in the future? And what we're hearing, as far as these revenue expectations, is, yes, things will slow down with the growth.

MCDOWELL: The midpoint of the revenue forecast for the holiday quarter from Apple is just a three percent gain year over year.

That is for a company at this valuation, Apple being cheaper than other tech names, but that's still lackluster, quite frankly.

KELLY: Yes. I mean I think it's important to note that they're not going to be announcing unit sales and that's because they actually missed on unit sales this time.

Sixty percent of their revenue comes from iPhone sales.

I mean, that is it. And so if they're missing on those numbers now and then they're not going to give them in the future, that's uncertainty for investors, especially because the biggest important market, which President Trump's going to be talking to Xi Jinping, is China.

We saw the revenues come down from 21 percent the previous quarter to 18 percent and they're continuously slowing down over there.

That's the most important market for growth.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: And that's what Dan Niles pointed out, that, look, are we really going to see people pony up a thousand dollars for an iPhone X in China when you know that things are slowing down there?

And he also mentioned the inventories, when you check on inventories at Apple as well coming up.

Also joining the conversation this morning, my exclusive interview with Barry Diller. He is Chairman of InterActive/IAC, and Expedia Group. Don't miss what he has to say about markets and technology, and really where the growth is going forward.

All that is coming up.

But first, our top story this hour. Apple shares under pressure despite a earnings report. Earnings per share of $2.91 a share.

Revenue 61.9 billion -- as you see earnings revenue, $62.9 billion on revenue on earnings of $2.91 a share.

Apple stock is down better than five percent right now, as you can see. The stock is down as investors worry about that guidance.

The company's decision to stop reporting unit sales for the products, seeing it as sign of potentially slow sales growth.

Joining us right now is Mahoney Asset Management CEO, Ken Mahoney. Ken, it's good to see you.

KEN MAHONEY, CEO, MAHONEY ASSET MANAGEMENT: Great to be back again.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

Let me just point out that it is also Jobs Friday.

MAHONEY: Yes.

FREEMAN: Whoo, whoo, whoo, whoo, whoo.

BARTIROMO: So we will have the Jobs number out in two and a half hours and we're going to talking about that as well.

MAHONEY: Glad to know.

BARTIROMO: But your reaction to the Apple numbers.

MAHONEY: Again, soft numbers. You know, they're really playing around and pushing the envelope when it comes to elasticity of the man. Remember that little textbook phrase?

I mean pushing up prices and see where that demand is, I mean, look, I think the estimates were about $750 a unit to now they came to $793.

But they're really pricing out a lot of households. I mean what is that -- what is that elasticity of the man? Where is that level where you could actually have good margins and also have some good sales?

And I think that's the thing. And also by the way, I think the new offerings are quite confusing to consumers, right? There's the XL's, and G's, and D, like --

BARTIROMO: No --

MAHONEY: Before, it's quite simple, you had a red card to pick, a white card, and a black card color, you know.

KELLY: Right.

MAHONEY: And now we have, like, 19 different choices, so what is the consumer -- where is that kind of sweet spot now for Apple with their iPhone offerings?

MCDOWELL: So the XR is the cheaper of the new model. The X -- I say X, it's 10, it's 10R, 10S, 10S Max, and it's actually the 10R, or the XR, that's gotten the really good reviews and that's the lower price change.

And so that, again, is -- was a concern going into this report.

KELLY: Yes, I think you're bringing up a great point because what happened is they keep increasing their average selling price, but also the parts and components are going down.

So their operating margins are expanding pretty significantly and that's going to be a future headwind because we're not going to see DRAM prices go down even more.

And so I think, when you're talking about pricing power, that's what is going to help companies succeed next year when they can --

MAHONEY: That's right.

KELLY: -- when they can pass along that pricing power.

So what are you seeing for next year and how you're going to be positioning yourself in the markets?

MAHONEY: Yes, look, it's going to be a volatile year. We also have to deal with the headlines, the Fed raising rates at a time when, you know, that's another kind of one of those bugaboos that's going to be out there, right?

So, you know, I feel like the Fed's going to keep raising rates until something breaks, and some things are breaking around us -- housing, we're seeing construction, homebuilders, and so forth.

So I think -- I think investors are becoming nimble. I mean we don't make them day traders, but kind of active when we have these swishes down like we had in February, in April, coming off of a strong January and March.

And now, again, a strong August-September we've had.

So I think we are -- we have a hybrid strategy, basically. Seventy percent long, large cap growth, but also about 30 percent kind of buy the dip, sell the rip, you know, into some of these crazy volatilities.

So I think next year, look, we have a lot -- we have a lot of things to kind of deal with after midterm elections, but at the -- at the end of the day, I think investors can make volatility their friend instead of their foe, is kind of the way we're going to come and play this.

BARTIROMO: But are you saying you are expecting a slowdown in the coming couple of years?

MAHONEY: I think so. Again, some specific interest rate sensitive industries, again, home builders, again they bounce a little bit, we wouldn't be there.

BARTIROMO: Well, what about the broad economic --

MAHONEY: All those and --

BARTIROMO: -- growth? I mean we're talking about 4.2 percent growth for the second quarter, 3-1/2 percent for the --

MAHONEY: 3.5, yes.

BARTIROMO: -- third quarter. Do you see economic growth slowing down?

MAHONEY: Oh, yes, absolutely. Yes, it's definitely slowing down 4.1.

BARTIROMO: OK.

MAHONEY: But, again, the point is the Fed keep raising rates here, it's going to slow a lot of things.

And we're seeing already, by the way. If you look at the real estate market, especially in the metro area here, you're starting to see some softness, so it is having impact, these higher interest rates.

FREEMAN: So if the President, best-case scenario here, gets a deal quickly with China, not predicting this, but if Xi Jinping says, "OK, we'll respect property rights and lower trade barriers," you're thinking that doesn't give the market much of a bump because the focus stays on interest rates or it does?

MAHONEY: Look, look, look, we saw, since Monday, you know, look, we had a whipsaw kind of -- bungee market, we were up 350 points.

The President said, "Hey, we're going to add some more trade tariffs in China in case we don't get a deal," and the market fell out of bed again.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MAHONEY: So he knows his words are tied into his algorithms that trade offered us.

FREEMAN: Right.

MAHONEY: So, the tariffs are really important. Look, we heard from 3M, Caterpillar, even Apple last night, talk about the uncertainty because of China trade.

So, that definitely helps out. But, again, I think 4.1 may be your peak GDP, quite frankly, and 3-1/2 of, you know --

KELLY: No.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I was going to -- I would point out, the Apple stock, until through yesterday, was still up 31 percent year to date.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And one big concern is the iPhones and the imports of Apple goods made in China have not been hit with any tariffs by this government yet.

But it looks like if something doesn't get resolved by the end of the year, iPhones will get hit with tariffs, and then you have to factor in the worry that the Chinese government retaliates against Apple.

MAHONEY: Right.

MCDOWELL: Retaliates in terms of China as a sales market, but also as a manufacturing hub for Apple, so there's a lot of concern.

It would be a huge, huge boost for the stock potentially if the U.S. could get something done with China on trading.

MAHONEY: It's important, too, because this has been going on for about a year now.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

MAHONEY: Versus protecting aluminum and steel industries now, we have some of the other industries aching from this.

So at the end of the deal, you know, we've been playing Liar's Poker. My 50 billion, your hundred billion, my 50 billion, my hundred -- you know, at this point, we really should get a deal here, right?

BARTIROMO: But he's got -- this administration has got to push back on China. Don't forget what we heard yesterday and this was just one company and this is just one issue and that is from Steve Ballmer.

MAHONEY: Right,

BARTIROMO: Former CEO of Microsoft.

MAHONEY: Microsoft, yes.

BARTIROMO: That 90 percent of the -- of the companies in China use the Microsoft operating platform and only one percent pay for it.

MAHONEY: Right.

BARTIROMO: And that equates to $10 billion to Microsoft.

MAHONEY: No, I remember back in --

BARTIROMO: Lost profit --

MCDOWELL: But the --

BARTIROMO: -- that goes to China because they're stealing it.

MAHONEY: Right.

MCDOWELL: But I started the week by talking about this and the Journal writes about it today. The better China strategy is what we've seen them going after, Fujian Jinhua Integrated Circuit Company, which has been accused of stealing technology intellectual property from Micron.

That's what this administration has done. We hit the Chinese company for allegedly stealing those secrets.

The Journal writes about it, calling it a better China trade.

MAHONEY: Well you -- well --

BARTIROMO: And I don't disagree.

MCDOWELL: Rather than -- rather than blunderbuss Paris.

BARTIROMO: And we should have -- and I --

MAHONEY: Yes, well --

BARTIROMO: And I don't disagree, we should have pushed back on ZTE as well.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

MAHONEY: That's right.

KELLY: Yes, and we did. We actually imposed some fines --

BARTIROMO: But then he came back.

KELLY: -- because he was skirting sanctions. Right. But I think the important thing to note here is that it's not just American companies and the American government.

We saw, at the World Trade Organization, the Europeans came around with our viewpoints as well and said, actually, they should not be getting a most- favored nation status at the World Trade Organization.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

KELLY: They're still considered an emerging economy, yet they're still skirting regulation.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly.

MAHONEY: Right.

KELLY: So if you even have the Europeans aligned with the Americans, that's going to be saying something. But this goes back --

MAHONEY: Right.

KELLY: -- to what you're talking about, is that even if we get -- do get good growth next year, the dollar's going to get stronger.

MAHONEY: That's right.

KELLY: And the Feds is also going to continue to raise rate because --

MAHONEY: Right.

KELLY: -- they're going to tamper inflations because if parts go up, then inflation's going up.

MAHONEY: Right.

KELLY: So the stronger dollar, I see, is one of the biggest impediments.

MAHONEY: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Are you selling into this rally right now?

MAHONEY: Yes, this morning we will be selling. But, look, from -- yes, from Monday's low -- this is like Friday's, it's been a long month this week, right, guys?

So from Monday's low to this open, it's about a 10 percent move for the NASDAQ.

I think we go back in film, not bearish, but I think we need to break down like we did, we do this bounce, we do a retest, I hope we make higher lows.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MAHONEY: I mean that'd be great technically. But at the end of the day, we were up 10 percent intraday from Monday now through Friday.

I think it takes some shekels, have some -- your powers run away in case we have to go back, or in case next week, the midterm elections don't go the way people think it's going to go, or the China talks don't go the way we think they will go.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MAHONEY: You have some -- you have some -- you have some power drive.

BARTIROMO: So sell into strength? I like that.

MAHONEY: Sell into strength.

MCDOWELL: Sell some shekels.

MAHONEY: That's true.

BARTIROMO: All right. Let's talk jobs for a second. It is Jobs day in America this morning.

Thee October Jobs Report out in two hours, 8:30 a.m. Eastern. Here are the expectations, a hundred and ninety thousand jobs added to the economy in the month of October.

With the unemployment rate holding steady and 3.7 percent. Kevin, what are you expecting from today's Jobs numbers?

KELLY: Uh-hmm. Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: What are you going to be focused on this morning?

KELLY: Yes, I think we're actually going to get a print above 200,000, and one of the reasons why is holiday expectations and needing to fill those seasonal jobs.

And especially after the hurricanes, I'm going to really be looking at the labor participation rate and I think that's the biggest one because we need to see people coming into the labor force if this economy continued to grow and expand.

Because that will lead to productivity for the companies --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

KELLY: -- so they can keep their margins where they're at.

BARTIROMO: Is a good number priced into this market, Ken?

MAHONEY: I don't know. I think today, the market's mostly focused on the trade deal with China.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MAHONEY: And a little bit about Apple.

I mean this is important, but I think it's already a foregone conclusion that the Fed's going to raise rates in December.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MAHONEY: We're going to be watching wage growth very closely.

And to your point, you know, a lot of companies are saying we're having trouble finding employees to grow our business.

KELLY: Yes.

MAHONEY: So this is -- this is an issue. So, participation rate is important.

KELLY: The rate.

MAHONEY: But it -- the wage growth is what the Feds' going to watch closely. So, we have to watch when the Feds' watching to make our decisions.

Look at leisure and hospitality adding 42,000 jobs when it was supposed to take a hit because of Hurricane Michael, especially in Florida. So, it is so strong that people are out there, and they're actually spending their money, they're spending their crumbs that they got from this fiscal policy.

BARTIROMO: Yes, crumbs. Look at this traffic --

KELLY: So, that is a true testament how strong this market is.

BARTIROMO: This -- you're right, this graphic shows the leisure and hospitality up 42,000, but look at service providing. I mean, this is a services economy, we know, but 179,000 jobs created in services, that is -- that is a big number.

MCDOWELL: I just want to remind people, too, when President Barack Obama goes on the campaign trail, and continuously tries to take credit for this economy, it was only for a brief spurt but for the most part during his eight years in office, we never had three percent wage growth in this country.

BARTIROMO: No.

MCDOWELL: We never had an economy that any calendar year grew at three percent. It was the Federal Reserve that kept you propped up and deregulation and the government burden that kept the lid on growth.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that was eight years -- eight years.

FREEMAN: But it's also -- it's kind of fun, though, watching President Obama and his former economic advisers sort of diverging here, where he's saying, isn't it great? I built that. And they're saying he's not so great. It's not so great.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You didn't build that. You didn't build that. Donald Trump built that.

FREEMAN: But it's harder -- it's harder to say it's not so great. So, I think we can expect may be he's going to want to claim even more.

POMBOY: That should be his new tagline, Donald Trump. That's genius. He didn't build that, I built that.

BARTIROMO: That's right. Let's get a check on markets. Gerri Willis is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange this morning with some early reaction. And Gerri, we got a pretty good showing with the Dow Industrials this morning. It's what we were expecting anyway.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, that's right, Maria. And I've been talking to traders all morning. Pre-number, post-number, they're speaking with one voice, and what they're saying is here comes the Fed. You know, this is pointing to a very strong economy, you're seeing this wage growth kicking up 3.1 percent. I was told before the number came out, if we got 190,000 to 230,000 more jobs for the month that that would be good, that would be solid. 250, that's going to make traders do start thinking about is this economy overheating and what they worry about, rates go higher, that takes money out of market, that's how they interpret it.

Number two layer here that people are talking about and concerned about in today's market, what they're happy about, frankly, is this discussion of China trade, this idea that there are going to be more China talks. They love that. It's on everybody's mind down here. But for this report, it makes them think that that idea that maybe the Fed would stop or slow or pause, maybe not because this is very good news about the economy. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Yes, Gerri, I'm glad you mentioned China because, Lisa Erickson, yesterday in the middle of the day, we learned that the President had spoken with President Xi in China, and markets definitely moved on that. What was your sense of what went on yesterday in markets, and how are you expecting this market to trade given what we've learned this morning?

ERICKSON: Well, trade market -- the trade issues are certainly a big overhang, and in fact, that's one of the key things that we're monitoring as well, of course, in addition to what's going on in the growth picture and also with the Fed. But I think, basically, there's been a lot of volatility because people are not certain what's going to happen. And so, when you get some positive headlines like you did yesterday, the market is going to trade up on that. You know, as far as the market reaction going out, I think that basically, this is going to settle in potentially for some more volatility. Again, now that the market is seeing that there may be more of a case for the Fed to continue on a trajectory of raising rates, that does raise the bar. It does race the competition for equities. And in addition, people are needing to see those growth numbers to continue to come through.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ERICKSON: So, again, I think the fundamental picture is balanced. We are seeing positives in both the macropicture and as well as corporate earnings, but you've got this offset with a little bit more competition. So, it's going to be important to watch that outlook going forward.

BARTIROMO: Stephanie, what are you going to be watching from here to get a sense of where things go now? What are your most important metrics?

POMBOY: Well, the thing I'm watching most closely is the corporate credit market, specifically what's happening with spreads. You know, when you see the 10-year backing up on numbers like this morning, do corporate yields follow suit? And you know, what we've seen in October is that the spreads have been winding out where people are starting to price in greater risk in the corporate bond market.

PAYNE: Let me ask you about the junk bond market because that's -- have been sort of a red flag, isn't it?

POMBOY: You know, it went from first to worst in October. It was the top performing credit market all year, and then it flipped and people couldn't get away from it fast enough, but that's how it is with high yield. You know, it's called junk for a reason. And people then reacquaint themselves with the definition of junk, and realize, you know, maybe I'm not going to get repaid on this debt. The interesting thing is that you also have half of what's categorized as investment grade that is just one rung above that junk threshold. So, it wouldn't take much of an increase in rates to push half of the investment-grade universe into that bottom bucket.

That's what I'm worried about because the spillover to the stock market is going to be huge, you know, obviously, companies borrowed like crazy to fund their buyback and dividend programs. That have been a key support for the stock market. I mean, I think the number one buyer of equities has been the corporate sector, not retail investors, not --

BARTIROMO: Right. Which is why -- which is why Kevin Kelly thinks once the corporations get out of earnings and once companies start buying back their stock, we're going to see this rally rip.

POMBOY: Assuming they have the money with which to do that, you know, Apple --

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: Well, they -- well, they do. Stephanie, they have over a trillion --

POMBOY: -- buybacks rather than using that --

KELLY: Stephanie, they have the money, over a trillion dollars.

POMBOY: -- a mountain of cash. Not every company does.

BARTIROMO: Go ahead, Kevin.

KELLY: Oh, I was going to say, they over a trillion dollars of stock buybacks that are going to occur actually over the next year. So, you're - - and you're going to see it start taking hold now.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KELLY: You know, it's going to be pretty interesting is that Apple is going to come out and start buy back a lot of their stock at these prices. So, that's going to lend an underlying bid because they've been blacked out for the last month.

BARTIROMO: Right. And that'll help -- that'll help Apple certainly and the broader market. Jon Hilsenrath, before you go, I know you got a job -- your final number and reaction to this number before you go.

HILSENRATH: Very strong start to the fourth quarter. A lot of analysts have been forecasting that the economy was going to slow down in the fourth quarter. This is a sign that it's still ripping.

BARTIROMO: All right, Jon, we'll see you soon. Thanks so much for your insights this morning. Jon Hilsenrath, always a pleasure.

HILSENRATH: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: More from this all-star panel on the October jobs' report after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, the October jobs number is out, the economy added 250,000 jobs last month that top the economists' expectations. The unemployment rate holding steady at a 49-year low of 3.7 percent. We want to go right now, it's the final jobs' report before the midterm elections, we want to go to one of the elections' most pivotal states, Arizona. Hillary Vaughn is live this morning in Phoenix with more. Hillary, good morning to you.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, good morning, Maria. This is one of the closest Senate races in the country right now. Democrat Congresswoman Kyrsten Sinema is running against Republican Congresswoman Martha McSally to fill Jeff Flake's Senate seat. And the latest Fox News poll has both candidates in a dead heat, both of them polling with 46 percent of voter support. This migrant caravan, though, that is headed towards the U.S.-Mexico border is a local issue here in this border state. We caught up with Democrat Kyrsten Sinema yesterday at a Get Out To Vote event with veterans. Sinema, a former anti-war protester has come under fire for her anti-military rhetoric in the past. And I asked her if she will support the military men and women headed to the U.S. border in her home state to stop this migrant caravan from crossing over.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KYRSTEN SINEMA (D), SENATORIAL CANDIDATE, ARIZONA: It's not new for us to have military deployment to the border to provide a support role for our Customs and Border Patrol agents who were down there. So, we wish them well and tell them to stay hydrated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Former fighter pilot and Republican Martha McSally spent the day stomping with the President's son, Donald Trump, Jr. to rally support headed into election day. McSally tells me that Democrats are to blame for this migrant caravan and crisis at the border. And she says it's her mission, if elected, to close loopholes in the system that allow migrants to exploit U.S. immigration law.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MARTHA MCSALLY (R), SENATORIAL CANDIDATE, ARIZONA: Border security is national security. They will be coming to bases in my district that I represent in Arizona, and our communities are going to welcome them as they continue to serve and sacrifice to keep our country safe.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Maria, the Green Party candidate just dropped out yesterday and that could be a game changer in a neck-and-neck race. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Hillary, wait, did Sinema just say stay hydrated to the military?

VAUGHN: Yes. And when I told McSally that, she had the same reaction, she laughed.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Hillary, thank you. Hillary Vaughn. Kevin Kelly, Joanie Courtney, Lisa Erickson, thank you so much for joining us. Invaluable insights from all of you, we so appreciate it. We got this panel on set as we continue with just a few minutes left. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We got a big weekend this weekend. Stay with me tonight, Maria Bartiromo's "WALL STREET" 9:00 p.m. Eastern. More of my exclusive interview with Barry Diller. And then I'll see you on Sunday morning on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" Fox News Channel --

END

urn:contentItem:5W2X-79P1-DY0W-40HG-00000-00Stock Kick Off November with Broad Rally; Spotlight on the Midterms; 4 Days Until the Midterms; Google Employees Protest; Alibaba Ahead of Earnings2018-11-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisStock Kick Off November with Broad Rally; Spotlight on the Midterms; 4 Days Until the Midterms; Google Employees Protest; Alibaba Ahead of EarningsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much. Good morning, everybody. We will see you in a little while. Girls, thank you. I'm Maria Bartiromo.

Happy Friday, everybody. It is Friday, November 2nd.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Major market moves this morning, Apple shares sliding today, week revenue guidance last night on the announcement that it will no longer provide unit sales. That's stock down better than five percent right now. The technology giant at risk of losing that $1 trillion market valuation.

The other big story for the markets, of course today, the Jobs Report. October Jobs Report will be out in two and a half hours, the expectation calls for jobs of 190,000 added to the economy last month, month of October. And the unemployment rate is expected to hold steady at 3.7 percent.

We are taking a look at what that means for the midterm elections now just four days away.

We are taking a look at the rally at the open this morning. Meanwhile, despite the drag from Apple shares, stocks are expected to open big. Up 200 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, up 17 points on the S&P 500, and higher by 10 and a quarter points on the NASDAQ this morning.

This after the major indices yesterday posted their third day of gains in a row, it was a pretty good day at the close yesterday.

Take a look, up 264 points for the Dow Industrials. That was better than one percent yesterday, finishing near the highs of the day.

The NASDAQ up one and three-quarters percent, that was 128 points higher yesterday.

Checking global markets this morning, we kick it off with Europe. European indices higher across the board, FT-100 up two-thirds of one percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris up better than one percent, and the DAX Index in Germany up better than one percent as well.

In Asia overnight, markets higher across the board, best performer there, China. Actually, Korea, KOSPI Index up three and a half percent, but China also very strong up 2.7 percent on the Shanghai Composite.

On the earnings rank, we will hear from oil giants and Dow Components. ExxonMobil and Chevron today. Plus Alibaba, also set to report.

We will have those numbers and analysis, give us a little window into what's going in Chinese consumer as well.

China trade, of course, in focus. President Trump speaking with China's president, Xi Jinping yesterday, showing progress in the trade dispute.

As soon as that was announced yesterday, markets did turn around. We got some firmness when we heard that there was progress on the China deal.

Here's what IAC Chairman, Barry Diller, told me about China's trade practices

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARRY DILLER, CHAIRMAN, IAC: Their trade practices have to change. And us, being tough-minded about it, I think it's sensible. I think us being outrageous and excessive about it is dangerous.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest this morning. More from Barry Diller as well on technology and what's been happening with tech stocks, all those stories coming up this Friday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal's Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Bench Mark Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly.

Great to see you this morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: Look who's back two days in a row?

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Yes, love it. Love it.

FREEMAN: Yes, so exciting. I'm sorry you had to impose this on your viewers again, but --

BARTIROMO: I'm so happy you're back. Yes. It's great.

FREEMAN: -- I'm going to be here for a little while. The -- you know, I don't think the President said it was fantastic, but he did say it was good and nice talking to President Xi Jinping, so --

MCDOWELL: Very good.

FREEMAN: -- let's hope this is a step toward resolution of the trade dispute.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's right. And when we heard that they had the phone call, it actually did help markets yesterday.

MCDOWELL: Right. Take --

FREEMAN: Yes, and I --

BARTIROMO: Big boost.

FREEMAN: I think that's a lot of what you're seeing in the futures here as well.

MCDOWELL: And on Apple's side, it's not just the revenue forecast for the December quarter, it's also the fact that they're -- they are no longer going to break out device unit sales in any future financial results.

So basically, Apple is telling investors, "You're going to get a lot less information from us about what is going on with the company, with sales of our devices," and that's why the stock down five percent.

But Apple was only down three percent in the month of October when Amazon was in a bear market losing 20 percent of its value.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point, yes.

MCDOWELL: We talked about that yesterday morning.

So, again, revenue is a problem and then when any company says, "Oh, by the way, we're going to give you less information --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- that's not --

BARTIROMO: That's what happened to --

MCDOWELL: That's what happens to the stock.

BARTIROMO: That's what happened to Oracle a couple of weeks ago. I mean - - and a lot of the analysts who have said that they said that they weren't going to break out cloud revenue and these specific lines within the cloud revenue, less transparency, you know, and so that's one thing.

So we're going to know less about how the company makes --

FREEMAN: But the revenue and the earnings are good.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: It's just the outlook.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

FREEMAN: And then that's -- we have seen that with a lot of these companies, where the numbers are fine, it's the future and the concern, and maybe some of it is going away now with this discussion on China.

KELLY: But --

MCDOWELL: Amazon --

BARTIROMO: And which is the issue. Which is the issue. Are we going to see growth slowdown in the future? And what we're hearing, as far as these revenue expectations, is, yes, things will slow down with the growth.

MCDOWELL: The midpoint of the revenue forecast for the holiday quarter from Apple is just a three percent gain year over year.

That is for a company at this valuation, Apple being cheaper than other tech names, but that's still lackluster, quite frankly.

KELLY: Yes. I mean I think it's important to note that they're not going to be announcing unit sales and that's because they actually missed on unit sales this time.

Sixty percent of their revenue comes from iPhone sales.

I mean, that is it. And so if they're missing on those numbers now and then they're not going to give them in the future, that's uncertainty for investors, especially because the biggest important market, which President Trump's going to be talking to Xi Jinping, is China.

We saw the revenues come down from 21 percent the previous quarter to 18 percent and they're continuously slowing down over there.

That's the most important market for growth.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: And that's what Dan Niles pointed out, that, look, are we really going to see people pony up a thousand dollars for an iPhone X in China when you know that things are slowing down there?

And he also mentioned the inventories, when you check on inventories at Apple as well coming up.

Also joining the conversation this morning, my exclusive interview with Barry Diller. He is Chairman of InterActive/IAC, and Expedia Group. Don't miss what he has to say about markets and technology, and really where the growth is going forward.

All that is coming up.

But first, our top story this hour. Apple shares under pressure despite a earnings report. Earnings per share of $2.91 a share.

Revenue 61.9 billion -- as you see earnings revenue, $62.9 billion on revenue on earnings of $2.91 a share.

Apple stock is down better than five percent right now, as you can see. The stock is down as investors worry about that guidance.

The company's decision to stop reporting unit sales for the products, seeing it as sign of potentially slow sales growth.

Joining us right now is Mahoney Asset Management CEO, Ken Mahoney. Ken, it's good to see you.

KEN MAHONEY, CEO, MAHONEY ASSET MANAGEMENT: Great to be back again.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

Let me just point out that it is also Jobs Friday.

MAHONEY: Yes.

FREEMAN: Whoo, whoo, whoo, whoo, whoo.

BARTIROMO: So we will have the Jobs number out in two and a half hours and we're going to talking about that as well.

MAHONEY: Glad to know.

BARTIROMO: But your reaction to the Apple numbers.

MAHONEY: Again, soft numbers. You know, they're really playing around and pushing the envelope when it comes to elasticity of the man. Remember that little textbook phrase?

I mean pushing up prices and see where that demand is, I mean, look, I think the estimates were about $750 a unit to now they came to $793.

But they're really pricing out a lot of households. I mean what is that -- what is that elasticity of the man? Where is that level where you could actually have good margins and also have some good sales?

And I think that's the thing. And also by the way, I think the new offerings are quite confusing to consumers, right? There's the XL's, and G's, and D, like --

BARTIROMO: No --

MAHONEY: Before, it's quite simple, you had a red card to pick, a white card, and a black card color, you know.

KELLY: Right.

MAHONEY: And now we have, like, 19 different choices, so what is the consumer -- where is that kind of sweet spot now for Apple with their iPhone offerings?

MCDOWELL: So the XR is the cheaper of the new model. The X -- I say X, it's 10, it's 10R, 10S, 10S Max, and it's actually the 10R, or the XR, that's gotten the really good reviews and that's the lower price change.

And so that, again, is -- was a concern going into this report.

KELLY: Yes, I think you're bringing up a great point because what happened is they keep increasing their average selling price, but also the parts and components are going down.

So their operating margins are expanding pretty significantly and that's going to be a future headwind because we're not going to see DRAM prices go down even more.

And so I think, when you're talking about pricing power, that's what is going to help companies succeed next year when they can --

MAHONEY: That's right.

KELLY: -- when they can pass along that pricing power.

So what are you seeing for next year and how you're going to be positioning yourself in the markets?

MAHONEY: Yes, look, it's going to be a volatile year. We also have to deal with the headlines, the Fed raising rates at a time when, you know, that's another kind of one of those bugaboos that's going to be out there, right?
