And I think this just bolsters that.

Longer term, however, I think the thing that we're going to be -- want to be thinking about is whether that does reinforce the tendency of the Fed to even potentially become more hawkish. As long as we continue to get tight numbers in the labor market, certainly, you want to going to continue on that rising rate path. And the other problem potentially presents is the fact that it could actually widen the divergence with the economies overseas because as rates go up and the dollar goes up, that can put pressure on those overseas dollar borrowers.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a really good point. Actually, I've got to get your opinion, Stephanie, on this. But first, Dagen, you nailed it on wages. Go ahead.

MCDOWELL: Stuart is gone but Stuart is wrong. Stu, this is a blowout report. Charles made a face when Stuart said that. Quite frankly, I don't mean to throw you under the bus --

PAYNE: It was (INAUDIBLE) that's all.

MCDOWELL: 250,000 jobs is a blowout. Wages growing in this country north of three percent. That is something that we haven't seen since the early term -- first term of Barack Obama, of President Obama, April of 2009. This is a blowout. The fact that you now have the three-month average job growth outpacing the average for the last year, shows an economy to quote James Freeman, at a higher growth plain, a higher growth plateau. This is awesome.

BARTIROMO: Yes, go ahead, James.

FREEMAN: Yes, given how difficult it's been for firms to find new workers, 250k new jobs is big. And really, as we talk about the elections, Republicans make their closing argument, the President has delivered, at least to this point, what he promised. The manufacturing rival, the economic revival he promised in 2016 is well underway. 32,000 jobs added in manufacturing, 30,000 in construction, a lot of good news in this report.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but let's go bring us back down to earth, Stephanie, because look at the 30-year yield right now at 3.4 percent. Look at the 10-year at 3.1 percent. What does this mean for the Federal Reserve?

POMBOY: (INAUDIBLE) I mean, I think Lisa's point is well-taken, and that is, if anything, this keeps Powell on his track or maybe more aggressive, and we have this on January 1, where kiwi and basically globally, we've had still expanding central bank liquidity throughout this year, even as the Fed has been tightening its balance sheet. That ends next year, alongside the (INAUDIBLE) of the tax cut effect, and most importantly -- and The Wall Street Journal has an article on this today -- corporate interest expense is going to start to move up sharply because they have almost a billion -- sorry, almost a trillion dollars in debt, $780 billion in debt that rolls next year at these higher interest rates, that's going to be the real headwind. The profits are the number one input into employment growth. So, I think this is a great report, no question about it. But is this as good as it gets past the old Milwaukee, you know, guys, this is as good as it gets.

BARTIROMO: Isn't that what Jon Hilsenrath wrote the other day in The Journal, what if this is as good as it gets? Jon, weigh in here?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, this report is solid from beginning to end. It's just great news across the labor market. The thing that I would point to that especially encouraging in here is that the labor force participation rate picked up. What that suggests is that we're getting workers coming in from the sidelines because wages are picking up, and there are so many job opportunities out there. You know, I wrote a story earlier this week saying that, you know, the private sector is expecting a slowdown, you don't see it in these numbers, it's a very good report.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but Charles -- I mean, just what Jon just said, I mean, a 3.7 percent unemployment rate, 49-year low, as new people are coming in shows confidence in the jobs market, shows confidence in the economy.

PAYNE: This is an amazing -- this is an amazing number. And, you know, we could talk about it two ways, Main Street and Wall Street. For Main Street's point of view, this is amazing. Participation up, wages are up, dirty fingernail jobs, good producing jobs, manufacturing which we said would never come back to this country, keeps blowing them away. Even the composition of this, so you've got 2,000 retail jobs, but instead, people are getting jobs in transportation and warehouses. Amazon and those places are creating these fulfilment centers.

BARTIROMO: They need vehicle --

PAYNE: They pay more than retail. So, even the composition of the numbers, some people will say, well, these are about the same numbers President Obama had in his last year. Numbers are the same, but the composition, it's changing to higher paying jobs which I think is also important.

BARTIROMO: Kevin Kelly, I'm coming to you in a second with your analysis on this market because the market has given up some gains here. I want to get your take on why we're losing some steam here. But first, Joanie Courtney, identify for us where are the jobs right now for those people who want to get in the jobs market, where should they be looking?

JOANIE COURTNEY, PROFESSIONAL DIVISION PRESIDENT, EMPLOYBRIDGE: Yes, Maria, it is such a strong jobs market. You know, there are 7.1 million openings across the United States, and they are both in blue collar and white collar opportunities. So, you've got engineering, accounting and finance, health care is very strong, but we also have manufacturing and logistics, construction. There's so many opportunities in the market. So, the best part about this report to me is definitely the labor participation rate, seeing more people come back into the job market because wages are moving, and there are opportunities. Overall, I mean, this is one of the best job reports we have seen in the last couple of years.

BARTIROMO: One of the best jobs reports that we've seen in the last couple of years, you say, just four days away from the midterm elections. You wonder what that's going to could for voters, and yet, markets are off of the highs. Kevin Kelly, explain.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Yes, one of the reasons why the markets are off the highs is you're starting to see that yields are going up, so that goes back to the financing costs. So, that's been the story for the last, you know, few months. When the 10-year treasury goes up, you see equities take a hit because it's one of their largest input costs. So, if you think about the input costs we're talking about today, jobs, right, wages are going up. Charles hit the nail on the head. Listen, we've got transportation in warehousing jobs 25,000. That's where e-commerce jobs are. We need over 452,000 workers in distribution centers this year and next year just to meet e-commerce demand, 16 percent year-over-year growth in that field alone.

So, you're seeing retail jobs come down. Last month, we actually lost 18,000 on that. So, you have -- you have an equity market that is worried about rising wages, you have an equity market that's worried about rising costs of capital that impacts their margins. That's why you're seeing guidance whether it's, you know, all the companies on the industrial side, even technology, talking about next year's revenues and profits, going to be lower than this year's.

MCDOWELL: One thing I would add, Maria, because we focus so much on the numbers, but these numbers today back up the way that people are feeling in this country. That with consumer confidence, we can talk about the polls, and how people more concerned about health care and the tax reform, and the tax cuts aren't connecting with voters.

BARTIROMO: Great point.

MCDOWELL: But consumer confidence is at an 18-year high. And it was strong, even in the month of October as the market is selling off, and people have told me from the rural -- around the rural communities that I grew up in, for the first time in over a decade, people can find full-time jobs, they can find full-time work and they don't feel like that they're trying to scrape here and scrape there, and are living -- I mean, worried about paying their bills every month.

BARTIROMO: How about -- and higher wages, too.

MCDOWELL: Right. And so, you are finding work, full-time work, and in -- as to Charles's point, better-paying positions, if you're switching jobs, and I think that that is really resonating and you see -- market be dammed, whatever investors are worried about on Wall Street, God bless them, but this is just great news for all Americans.

PAYNE: They're worried about Jay Powell.

MCDOWELL: Right, exactly.

BARTIROMO: They're worried about Jay Powell.

(CROSSTALK)

PAYNE: I'll let you add to this, I just want to point to people, I think October was started by a speech (INAUDIBLE) made on October 3rd where he said the Fed didn't know where neutral was and that they would certainly overshoot. The market fell off a cliff, and it hasn't -- and that to me was the scariest moment of the entire month.

POMBOY: The comment I was going to make on the back of what Dagen was saying is that, you know, this is a positive thing. I'm going to, you know, (INAUDIBLE) my umbrella for a minute, and what we're seeing with the wage growth is now consumers will be able to shift from relying on central bank created asset inflation to fund their retirements and their current commutation with actual good old-fashioned wage growth. This is the way it's supposed to be. It's a positive development. And it comes in my view, at a good time, because that asset inflation story is coming to an abrupt end, home price inflation has already slowed a lot, and I think the stock market and the corporate bond market are going to follow suit.

FREEMAN: I could not agree more. And I think maybe this is optimism.

(LAUGHTER)

FREEMAN: But what -- but this -- what we're seeing --

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: What we're seeing is a real economy which gives us a chance to make the transition back to normal. The policy makers, the central bankers of the last decade left us with this enormous challenge to unwind all of this money that they put into the economy because the tax and regulatory burdens wouldn't let the economy grow, they tried to conjure prosperity forcing all of this money in. This report is more evidence that the real economy is reasserting itself and we might be able to break this transition --

KELLY: Can I just bring up a point about this economy and how healthy and strong it is? Look at leisure and hospitality adding 42,000 jobs when it was supposed to take a hit because of Hurricane Michael, especially in Florida. So, it is so strong that people are out there, and they're actually spending their money, they're spending their crumbs that they got from this fiscal policy.

BARTIROMO: Yes, crumbs. Look at this traffic --

KELLY: So, that is a true testament how strong this market is.

BARTIROMO: This -- you're right, this graphic shows the leisure and hospitality up 42,000, but look at service providing. I mean, this is a services economy, we know, but 179,000 jobs created in services, that is -- that is a big number.

MCDOWELL: I just want to remind people, too, when President Barack Obama goes on the campaign trail, and continuously tries to take credit for this economy, it was only for a brief spurt but for the most part during his eight years in office, we never had three percent wage growth in this country.

BARTIROMO: No.

MCDOWELL: We never had an economy that any calendar year grew at three percent. It was the Federal Reserve that kept you propped up and deregulation and the government burden that kept the lid on growth.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that was eight years -- eight years.

FREEMAN: But it's also -- it's kind of fun, though, watching President Obama and his former economic advisers sort of diverging here, where he's saying, isn't it great? I built that. And they're saying he's not so great. It's not so great.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You didn't build that. You didn't build that. Donald Trump built that.

FREEMAN: But it's harder -- it's harder to say it's not so great. So, I think we can expect may be he's going to want to claim even more.

POMBOY: That should be his new tagline, Donald Trump. That's genius. He didn't build that, I built that.

BARTIROMO: That's right. Let's get a check on markets. Gerri Willis is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange this morning with some early reaction. And Gerri, we got a pretty good showing with the Dow Industrials this morning. It's what we were expecting anyway.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, that's right, Maria. And I've been talking to traders all morning. Pre-number, post-number, they're speaking with one voice, and what they're saying is here comes the Fed. You know, this is pointing to a very strong economy, you're seeing this wage growth kicking up 3.1 percent. I was told before the number came out, if we got 190,000 to 230,000 more jobs for the month that that would be good, that would be solid. 250, that's going to make traders do start thinking about is this economy overheating and what they worry about, rates go higher, that takes money out of market, that's how they interpret it.

Number two layer here that people are talking about and concerned about in today's market, what they're happy about, frankly, is this discussion of China trade, this idea that there are going to be more China talks. They love that. It's on everybody's mind down here. But for this report, it makes them think that that idea that maybe the Fed would stop or slow or pause, maybe not because this is very good news about the economy. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Yes, Gerri, I'm glad you mentioned China because, Lisa Erickson, yesterday in the middle of the day, we learned that the President had spoken with President Xi in China, and markets definitely moved on that. What was your sense of what went on yesterday in markets, and how are you expecting this market to trade given what we've learned this morning?

ERICKSON: Well, trade market -- the trade issues are certainly a big overhang, and in fact, that's one of the key things that we're monitoring as well, of course, in addition to what's going on in the growth picture and also with the Fed. But I think, basically, there's been a lot of volatility because people are not certain what's going to happen. And so, when you get some positive headlines like you did yesterday, the market is going to trade up on that. You know, as far as the market reaction going out, I think that basically, this is going to settle in potentially for some more volatility. Again, now that the market is seeing that there may be more of a case for the Fed to continue on a trajectory of raising rates, that does raise the bar. It does race the competition for equities. And in addition, people are needing to see those growth numbers to continue to come through.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ERICKSON: So, again, I think the fundamental picture is balanced. We are seeing positives in both the macropicture and as well as corporate earnings, but you've got this offset with a little bit more competition. So, it's going to be important to watch that outlook going forward.

BARTIROMO: Stephanie, what are you going to be watching from here to get a sense of where things go now? What are your most important metrics?

POMBOY: Well, the thing I'm watching most closely is the corporate credit market, specifically what's happening with spreads. You know, when you see the 10-year backing up on numbers like this morning, do corporate yields follow suit? And you know, what we've seen in October is that the spreads have been winding out where people are starting to price in greater risk in the corporate bond market.

PAYNE: Let me ask you about the junk bond market because that's -- have been sort of a red flag, isn't it?

POMBOY: You know, it went from first to worst in October. It was the top performing credit market all year, and then it flipped and people couldn't get away from it fast enough, but that's how it is with high yield. You know, it's called junk for a reason. And people then reacquaint themselves with the definition of junk, and realize, you know, maybe I'm not going to get repaid on this debt. The interesting thing is that you also have half of what's categorized as investment grade that is just one rung above that junk threshold. So, it wouldn't take much of an increase in rates to push half of the investment-grade universe into that bottom bucket.

That's what I'm worried about because the spillover to the stock market is going to be huge, you know, obviously, companies borrowed like crazy to fund their buyback and dividend programs. That have been a key support for the stock market. I mean, I think the number one buyer of equities has been the corporate sector, not retail investors, not --

BARTIROMO: Right. Which is why -- which is why Kevin Kelly thinks once the corporations get out of earnings and once companies start buying back their stock, we're going to see this rally rip.

POMBOY: Assuming they have the money with which to do that, you know, Apple --

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: Well, they -- well, they do. Stephanie, they have over a trillion --

POMBOY: -- buybacks rather than using that --

KELLY: Stephanie, they have the money, over a trillion dollars.

POMBOY: -- a mountain of cash. Not every company does.

BARTIROMO: Go ahead, Kevin.

KELLY: Oh, I was going to say, they over a trillion dollars of stock buybacks that are going to occur actually over the next year. So, you're - - and you're going to see it start taking hold now.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KELLY: You know, it's going to be pretty interesting is that Apple is going to come out and start buy back a lot of their stock at these prices. So, that's going to lend an underlying bid because they've been blacked out for the last month.

BARTIROMO: Right. And that'll help -- that'll help Apple certainly and the broader market. Jon Hilsenrath, before you go, I know you got a job -- your final number and reaction to this number before you go.

HILSENRATH: Very strong start to the fourth quarter. A lot of analysts have been forecasting that the economy was going to slow down in the fourth quarter. This is a sign that it's still ripping.

BARTIROMO: All right, Jon, we'll see you soon. Thanks so much for your insights this morning. Jon Hilsenrath, always a pleasure.

HILSENRATH: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: More from this all-star panel on the October jobs' report after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, the October jobs number is out, the economy added 250,000 jobs last month that top the economists' expectations. The unemployment rate holding steady at a 49-year low of 3.7 percent. We want to go right now, it's the final jobs' report before the midterm elections, we want to go to one of the elections' most pivotal states, Arizona. Hillary Vaughn is live this morning in Phoenix with more. Hillary, good morning to you.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, good morning, Maria. This is one of the closest Senate races in the country right now. Democrat Congresswoman Kyrsten Sinema is running against Republican Congresswoman Martha McSally to fill Jeff Flake's Senate seat. And the latest Fox News poll has both candidates in a dead heat, both of them polling with 46 percent of voter support. This migrant caravan, though, that is headed towards the U.S.-Mexico border is a local issue here in this border state. We caught up with Democrat Kyrsten Sinema yesterday at a Get Out To Vote event with veterans. Sinema, a former anti-war protester has come under fire for her anti-military rhetoric in the past. And I asked her if she will support the military men and women headed to the U.S. border in her home state to stop this migrant caravan from crossing over.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KYRSTEN SINEMA (D), SENATORIAL CANDIDATE, ARIZONA: It's not new for us to have military deployment to the border to provide a support role for our Customs and Border Patrol agents who were down there. So, we wish them well and tell them to stay hydrated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Former fighter pilot and Republican Martha McSally spent the day stomping with the President's son, Donald Trump, Jr. to rally support headed into election day. McSally tells me that Democrats are to blame for this migrant caravan and crisis at the border. And she says it's her mission, if elected, to close loopholes in the system that allow migrants to exploit U.S. immigration law.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MARTHA MCSALLY (R), SENATORIAL CANDIDATE, ARIZONA: Border security is national security. They will be coming to bases in my district that I represent in Arizona, and our communities are going to welcome them as they continue to serve and sacrifice to keep our country safe.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Maria, the Green Party candidate just dropped out yesterday and that could be a game changer in a neck-and-neck race. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Hillary, wait, did Sinema just say stay hydrated to the military?

VAUGHN: Yes. And when I told McSally that, she had the same reaction, she laughed.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Hillary, thank you. Hillary Vaughn. Kevin Kelly, Joanie Courtney, Lisa Erickson, thank you so much for joining us. Invaluable insights from all of you, we so appreciate it. We got this panel on set as we continue with just a few minutes left. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We got a big weekend this weekend. Stay with me tonight, Maria Bartiromo's "WALL STREET" 9:00 p.m. Eastern. More of my exclusive interview with Barry Diller. And then I'll see you on Sunday morning on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" Fox News Channel --

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60RS-F3M1-JBSS-S1F2-00000-00Stock market bloodbath: Dow and Nasdaq plummet in the worst day since June2020-09-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisStock market bloodbath: Dow and Nasdaq plummet in the worst day since JuneNEW YORK (CNN Business)

NEW YORK (CNN Business) -- It was a wild day on Wall Street. The Nasdaq Composite tumbled nearly 5% and the Dow fell more than 800 points, as investors made a dash for the exits following a streak of record-setting days over the past several weeks.

It was the worst day for stocks since June.

Stocks erased all their gains after a huge bout of exuberance Wednesday, when the S&P 500 --- the broadest measure of Wall Street --- and the Nasdaq hit yet another record high. The Nasdaq had also climbed above 12,000 points for the first time in history Wednesday.

But it didn't stick. Thursday was the Nasdaq's largest one-day decline from a record high in its history, according to Bespoke Investment Group.

All three major indexes finished the day sharply lower. The Nasdaq closed down nearly 5%, and the S&P fell 3.5%, while the Dow finished 2.8%, or 808 points, lower.

So, what happened?

For one, the Nasdaq has been outperforming the other two major stock indexes --- the Dow and the S&P 500 --- for months. The rally has been going on for long enough that investors are now taking profit.

Even so, the Nasdaq remains up nearly 28% in 2020, still far outpacing its counterparts. The Dow, which only recently turned positive for the year, is back in the red.

"Although there is no single driver for the weakness, it seems as if investors all of a sudden realized how overbought stocks are and sold. Someone yelled fire in a crowded theater and everyone left at once," said Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist for LPL Financial, in emailed comments.

But there are also technical reasons for Thursday's decline: As US-China relations sour, investors are moving money out of tech, which could get hit the hardest from a potential increase in tariffs.

"The Nasdaq is getting hit hard with the continued rotation into cyclicals and expectations big-tech will ultimately pay the cost to a further deterioration with US-Chinese relations," said Ed Moya, senior market analyst at Oanda.

Stocks in cyclical sectors are expected to perform better as the economy is recovering.

The Big Tech companies such as Amazon, Google and Microsoft, all of which are part of the Nasdaq, have become the safe-haven investment of the summer. But investors have beginning to wonder when the rally will run out of steam, either because of increased regulation or because the economy as a whole picks up enough to void the need for safety picks altogether.

"It's a bit of a wake-up call, which isn't the worst thing in the world. Markets go up and down," JJ Kinahan, chief market strategist at TD Ameritrade, told CNN Business.

Tech stocks were among Thursday's worst performers.

Given the summer rally, it's "perfectly normal," to see tech stocks readjusting a bit, Detrick said.

But even investors who are still faithful to their safe tech holdings have reason to be a little concerned: Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious diseases, told CNN Thursday that a Covid-19 vaccine by October remained "unlikely," though it was possible.

Making matters worse, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said late Wednesday that "the cooperative spirit we had in March and April" on Capitol Hill has "dissipated as we move closer and closer to the election." This doesn't bode well for Congress agreeing on another stimulus bill, which the market has been hoping for.

value.Title: Stock market bloodbath: Dow and Nasdaq plummet in the worst day since June
value.Overview: It was a wild day on Wall Street. The Nasdaq Composite tumbled nearly 5% and the Dow fell more than 800 points, as investors made a dash for the exits following a streak of record-setting days over the past several weeks. It was the worst day for stocks si... It was a wild day on Wall Street....

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60RY-2X31-F07F-812V-00000-00Stock market bloodbath: Dow and Nasdaq plummet in the worst day since June2020-09-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisNEWSStock market bloodbath: Dow and Nasdaq plummet in the worst day since June

It was a wild day on Wall Street. The Nasdaq Composite tumbled nearly 5% and the Dow fell more than 800 points, as investors made a dash for the exits following a streak of record-setting days over the past several weeks. It was the worst day for stocks si... It was a wild day on Wall Street....

It was a wild day on Wall Street. The Nasdaq Composite tumbled nearly 5% and the Dow fell more than 800 points, as investors made a dash for the exits following a streak of record-setting days over the past several weeks. It was the worst day for stocks si...

It was a wild day on Wall Street. The Nasdaq Composite tumbled nearly 5% and the Dow fell more than 800 points, as investors made a dash for the exits following a streak of record-setting days over the past several weeks. It was the worst day for stocks since June. Stocks erased all their gains after a huge bout of exuberance Wednesday, when the S&P 500 — the broadest measure of Wall Street — and the Nasdaq hit yet another record high . The Nasdaq had also climbed above 12,000 points for the first time in history Wednesday. But it didn’t stick. Thursday was the Nasdaq’s largest one-day decline from a record high in its history, according to Bespoke Investment Group. All three major indexes finished the day sharply lower. The Nasdaq closed down nearly 5%, and the S&P fell 3.5%, while the Dow finished 2.8%, or 808 points, lower. So, what happened? For one, the Nasdaq has been outperforming the other two major stock indexes — the Dow and the S&P 500 — for months. The rally has been going on for long enough that investors are now taking profit. Even so, the Nasdaq remains up nearly 28% in 2020, still far outpacing its counterparts. The Dow, which only recently turned positive for the year , is back in the red. “Although there is no single driver for the weakness, it seems as if investors all of a sudden realized how overbought stocks are and sold. Someone yelled fire in a crowded theater and everyone left at once,” said Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist for LPL Financial, in emailed comments. But there are also technical reasons for Thursday’s decline: As US-China relations sour, investors are moving money out of tech, which could get hit the hardest from a potential increase in tariffs. “The Nasdaq is getting hit hard with the continued rotation into cyclicals and expectations big-tech will ultimately pay the cost to a further deterioration with US-Chinese relations,” said Ed Moya, senior market analyst at Oanda. Stocks in cyclical sectors are expected to perform better as the economy is recovering. The Big Tech companies such as Amazon, Google and Microsoft, all of which are part of the Nasdaq, have become the safe-haven investment of the summer . But investors have beginning to wonder when the rally will run out of steam , either because of increased regulation or because the economy as a whole picks up enough to void the need for safety picks altogether. “It’s a bit of a wake-up call, which isn’t the worst thing in the world. Markets go up and down,” JJ Kinahan, chief market strategist at TD Ameritrade, told CNN Business. Tech stocks were among Thursday’s worst performers. Given the summer rally, it’s “perfectly normal,” to see tech stocks readjusting a bit, Detrick said. But even investors who are still faithful to their safe tech holdings have reason to be a little concerned: Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious diseases, told CNN Thursday that a Covid-19 vaccine by October remained “unlikely,” though it was possible. Making matters worse, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said late Wednesday that “the cooperative spirit we had in March and April” on Capitol Hill has “dissipated as we move closer and closer to the election.” This doesn’t bode well for Congress agreeing on another stimulus bill, which the market has been hoping for.

And even investors who are still faithful to their safe tech holdings have reason to be a little concerned: Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious diseases, told CNN Thursday that a Covid-19 vaccine by October remained “unlikely,” though it was possible. Making matters worse, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said late Wednesday that “the cooperative spirit we had in March and April” on Capitol Hill has “dissipated as we move closer and closer to the election.” This doesn’t bode well for Congress agreeing on another stimulus bill, which the market has been hoping for.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TT9-YSC1-JCBB-K538-00000-00Stock Market Correction Back As Apple, Target, Crude Oil Tumble: Weekly Review2018-11-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisNEWSStock Market Correction Back As Apple, Target, Crude Oil Tumble: Weekly ReviewIBD STAFF

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Biz01-review-112318-newscom.jpg

The stock market correction is back on as the Nasdaq undercut October lows with the S&P 500 index and Dow Jones also down sharply. Apple (AAPL) continued to hit new lows, but selling was broad-based. Target (TGT), Kohl's (KSS) and Ross Stores (ROST) plunged on earnings and guidance, continuing a recent tumble for the retail sector. Black Friday lured shoppers early Friday, though retailers offer ongoing holiday deals before and after, online and in stores. Energy stocks reeled as crude oil prices plunged to 52-week lows.

[ibd-display-video id=2385970 width=50 float=left autostart=true]

Stock Market Correction Revived

With the Nasdaq composite knifing below October lows, the other major averages suffering major losses and leading stocks struggling, the short-lived market uptrend failed and a new or revived stock market correction is underway. The Dow Jones lost 4.4%, the Nasdaq 4.3% and the S&P 500 3.8%. Apple and software stocks were among the big tech losers. Retailers plunged amid another fresh earnings reports and guidance. Crude oil prices plunged to 52-week lows, rocking energy stocks.

Target Misses, Kohl's Guidance Disappoints

Discount giant Target's (TGT) earnings and sales missed third-quarter estimates, with higher costs related to handling digital orders squeezing margins. Kohl's (KSS) earnings and sales topped but the value department store chain's raised guidance was below analysts' consensus. Target stock fell 15% and Kohl's 12%.

Ross Stores, TJX Cautious On Holidays

Off-price heavyweights TJX (TJX) and Ross Stores (ROST) reported mixed Q3 results and cautious holiday-quarter guidance. T.J. Maxx parent TJX reported adjusted EPS of 54 cents, below estimates, while a 12% revenue gain to $9.83 billion topped. Ross Stores edged past EPS views while sales grew 7% to $3.35 billion, just missing. Freight costs and pay hikes weighed on results. Ross says it is up against its "toughest sales comparisons from 2017" and expects fierce competition. TJX stock tumbled 11% and Ross stock 16%.

Foot Locker Sprints On Earnings

Athletic apparel and shoe retailer Foot Locker (FL) came out ahead of analyst forecasts, with profit up 9% to 95 cents a share and sales declining only 0.5% to $1.86 billion. Same-store sales rose 2.9%, ahead of estimates for 2% comps. The stock gapped up 15% Wednesday as shares continue to consolidate. Wedbush says Foot Locker's position is improving as it "remains a top destination for sneakerheads and a strong partner for multiple brands, including Nike."

Apparel Retailers Report Earnings

Urban Outfitters (URBN) easily exceeded views as profit shot up 71% to 70 cents and sales grew 9% to $974 million. Comparable sales also topped. Shares rose modestly Tuesday. L Brands (LB) beat Q3 views and raised full-year profit outlook but shares plunged as the Victoria's Secret parent halved its annual dividend to $1.20. Meanwhile, Gap (GPS) cut its full-year profit guidance and is mulling closing hundreds of stores as Gap and Old Navy same-store sales underperformed expectations. But Gap, which slightly beat Q3 views, saw its stock rebound Wednesday and Friday from a 14-month low.

Best Buy Gives Muted Holiday Outlook

The consumer electronics retailer beat Wall Street's targets for its fiscal third quarter ended Nov. 3. But it came up short with its holiday-quarter outlook. Best Buy (BBY) blamed its guidance miss on the fact that this year's fiscal fourth quarter has one less week than the same quarter last year. The retailer expects same-store sales growth to be flat to up 3% in the January quarter. CEO Hubert Joly said Best Buy is promoting many "exciting products" this year including big-screen TVs, smart speakers, security cameras, streaming devices and video games.

Chip Stocks Disappoint On Guidance

Chip-gear maker Brooks Automation (BRKS) topped fiscal fourth-quarter views, but guided well below consensus for the current quarter. Chipmaker Analog Devices (ADI) beat Q4 views for its fiscal fourth quarter, but gave weak EPS guidance. Micron Technology (MU) fell on reports that it is one of several memory chipmakers that China's antitrust regulators are probing for possible anticompetitive activity. Nvidia (NVDA) rebounded from an 18-month low as Citron Research turned positive on the graphics chipmaker.

Crude Oil Plunges

U.S. crude futures plunged to 52-week lows Tuesday as the stock market correction resumed, with energy groups big losers. President Donald Trump pressured Saudi Arabia on Twitter to keep oil prices down as OPEC's de facto leader weighs a production cut. America will "remain a steadfast partner of Saudi Arabia" despite reports that the CIA has concluded Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman was aware of, and perhaps responsible for, the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. U.S. crude inventories rose for a ninth straight week, though gasoline stockpiles fell and crude production was flat week-over-week. Cimarex Energy (XEC) will buy Resolute Energy (REN) for $1.6 billion, including debt, to expand its acreage in the Permian Basin. The deal will add 35,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day to Cimarex production.

Housing Activity Sluggish

The National Association of Home Builders' homebuilder sentiment gauge tumbled 8 points in November, to 60, the lowest point in two years. Weekly mortgage applications to buy a home fell 5% vs. a year earlier amid interest rate and affordability concerns. Existing-home sales rose 1.4% in September to a seasonally adjusted rate of 5.22 million, the first monthly gain in six months. Sales fell 5.1% vs. a year earlier. October housing starts rose 1.5% to a 1.228 million annualized pace, fueled by a jump in multifamily units. But they fell 2.9% vs. a year earlier. Separately, Lowe's (LOW) earnings topped views, but the home improvement chain cut full-year sales and same-store sales guidance.

JD.com Hits Record Low As Growth Slows

Three China e-commerce companies checked in with third-quarter reports. JD.com (JD) reported revenue grew 25% to $15.3 billion, the slowest growth since its May 2014 IPO. JD founder and CEO Richard Liu, briefly arrested in Minneapolis in August on a rape claim, is stepping away from managing the core e-commerce business. Shares hit a record low. Pinduoduo (PDD) soared as the 2018 IPO reported a 700% revenue gain to $491 million with a smaller-than-expected per-share loss. Baozun (BZUN), which helps Western brands sell online in China, reported better-than-expected earnings with revenue up 25% to $161.7 million. Shares popped Wednesday but were little changed for the week.

News In Brief

Car industry legend Carlos Ghosn was arrested in Japan on charges that he underreported his compensation for years. Ghosn built Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi into the world's biggest car alliance. Japan's Nissan (NSANY) removed Ghosn as chairman but France's Renault declined to oust him as chair or chief executive, highlighting apparent alliance strife. Ghosn had been pushing for a full Renault-Nissan merger. Nissan stock, already battered by slumping sedan sales, hit a multiyear low.

Boeing (BA) canceled a call with airlines over last month's Lion Air 737 Max crash amid reports that the aerospace giant didn't disclose to pilots safety issues with the newest Max. It's now planning meetings in various places with airlines and conference calls this coming week. Also, South Korea's Jeju Air Co. ordered 40 737 Max 8 jets, valued at $4.41 billion at list prices. Shares hit a 10-month low on Tuesday.

Medtronic (MDT) on Tuesday reported adjusted earnings of $1.22 per share on $7.48 billion in sales. The medical products giant topped views.

Deere (DE) saw EPS vault 47% to $2.30 on a revenue gain of 17% to $8.34 billion. It still missed lofty expectations, as material cost pressures continued. Deere stock rose 2.4% on Wednesday but fell for the week.

Niu Technologies (NIU) saw revenue jump 86% to $71.81 million. The Chinese electric scooter IPO posted a net loss of 1 cent a share. Niu Tech, which makes moped-like scooters, has its sights on the hot market for shared scooters and bikes.

Computer-aided design software firm Autodesk (ADSK) cheered investors with better-than-expected third-quarter results and fourth-quarter guidance. Shares popped 12% Wednesday but still fell 1% for the week.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:54HT-MG71-JBKM-D2JP-00000-00Stock-market decline takes shine off 2011 IPOs2011-12-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:10ZLexisNexisROP ZONEBusinessPg. A14Stock-market decline takes shine off 2011 IPOsTali ArbelThe Associated PressNew York

NEW YORK This was supposed to be the year that the IPO market fully recovered from the financial crisis, as the economy and global stock markets healed.

Six months into 2011, the market for initial public offerings was stronger than it had been since before the recession. The number of deals seemed on pace for a decade high. IPOs shares were, on average, in the black.

After a strong start, the market for new stock offerings fizzled in 2011 as the prospect of a global slowdown and a prolonged European debt crisis battered financial markets. High-profile Internet companies like Groupon, LinkedIn and Zynga, which went public Friday, attracted attention.

But overall, companies didn't raise as much as they hoped for through IPOs. Main Street investors, who generally don't have access to IPO shares until after they start trading, were likely the biggest losers.

Many companies had to cancel their debuts, delaying paydays for their early investors. More companies withdrew their IPO plans than have since 2008, the depths of the recession, according to IPO investment firm Renaissance Capital.

Negative return

IPOs that went public this year, as a group, lost 13 percent of their value the first negative return since 2008. And about two-thirds of companies that went public this year are trading below their offering price, according to advisory firm IPO Boutique.

"The only way to have played the game this year the way I always play it is to have flipped on day one. Take your profit and move on. People who haven't have been decimated," said longtime IPO investor Scott Sweet, who owns IPO Boutique.

This week, the last before the IPO market shuts down for the year, spotlights 2011 trends. Twelve companies had lined up IPOs, which would have been the busiest week since November 2007. That didn't happen.

Business social network Jive Software and luxury retailer Michael Kors Holdings priced high, sold more shares than expected, and soared on day one. Retail companies like Michael Kors and Dunkin' Donutsparent Dunkin' Brands Groupwere popular with investors this year, as well as tech companies.

Facebook games maker Zynga raised $1 billion Thursday night, in the biggest Internet IPO since Google's 2004 launch. That valued it at $7 billion. But when the company filed to go public in July, market watchers thought the company had potential for a valuation of $20 billion or more.

On Friday, shares closed down 5 percent.

Of the other nine companies slated for the week, three delayed their debuts. Six raised less money than they'd expected. Two of those are already more than 15 percent below their IPO price, giving investors a loss.

Other high-profile tech companies that went public this year have slid from their first-day pops.

Jobs-networking site LinkedIn more than doubled in its debut. While it's still up about 50 percent from its initial price, shares have lost 30 percent from the first trading day. Investors who bought in the first day after trading began have likely lost money.

It's a common story:

? In its January debut, online-content company Demand Media rose 33 percent. It's since dropped 70 percent.

? May: Yandex, the Google of Russia, popped 55 percent. It is down 54 percent since.

? June: Internet radio company Pandora Media rose 9 percent. It has dropped 40 percent since.

? July: Seattle-based real-estate listings website Zillow rose 79 percent, but has fallen 34 percent since.

? November: Groupon rose 31 percent, but has dropped 14 percent since then.

Technology companies that went public in the past 12 months, overall, are down 13 percent, according to Renaissance Capital. Part of that stems from broader market declines. The Standard & Poor's 500 index is down about 8 percent from the end of June.

Daniel Graeber, a journalist and professor from Grand Rapids, Mich., bought 15 shares of Groupon for $30 each the day it went public, hoping the deals company would be the next Google or Amazon.com. Graeber, 38, has lost money so far, but says he's modestly optimistic that shares will recover. And despite his loss and general market doldrums, he says he's intrigued by Facebook.

Market watchers expect more big tech deals next year: Facebook, local reviews site Yelp and online retailer Gilt Groupe. Of the three, only Yelp has filed to go public.

Another IPO bright spot, foreign companies, has faltered. Chinese companies made up more than a quarter of U.S. IPOs in 2010 and led foreign deals in the first half of the year. But those deals have disappeared amid reports of probes by U.S. regulators and a slowdown in the Chinese economy. Online video company Tudou Holdings was the last Chinese company to go public in the U.S. in August. Shares are off 60 percent.

Less cash next year

The global economic uncertainty and poor returns throughout the IPO market may also mean less cash for the 200 companies hoping to go public in 2012.

"They want to get the company public, they'll do a smaller deal," said Frank Maturo, head of cash-equity capital markets for the

Americas at Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch.

LinkedIn and Groupon sold less than 10 percent of their outstanding stock in their IPOs, which is considered a small percent of overall stock to put up for sale in an offering. The small supply helps boost demand for IPO shares.

The IPO declines and weak stock markets may create an opportunity for investors to buy shares more cheaply as companies and bankers rethink prices for shares.

"People haven't made money in the IPO market, people are skeptical. But deals can get done if they get priced right," said IPO analyst Francis Gaskins of IPOdesktop.

<!--body done-->
