urn:contentItem:5J3T-DG01-DY0W-43J6-00000-00Stock Market Discussion; Discussion of Tesla Company Stocks; Comparing Bonuses in Tech and Financial Industry and the Aspect of Public2014-02-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisStock Market Discussion; Discussion of Tesla Company Stocks; Comparing Bonuses in Tech and Financial Industry and the Aspect of PublicLanhamFULL TEXT

MELISSA FRANCIS, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Boy, it is a big day, you know. S&P flirting with record territory right now. Also, oil is rising up. And new emergency rules are moving Bakken Shale via oil train. We're going live to the CME to show you what is happening. And we have got a signature "MONEY" style Wall Street throw down on Tesla, including a referee. Look at that. Plus, Silicon Valley versus Wall Street. RBS is paying out a billion bucks in bonuses. It is causing an outrage. Does anyone care when Google does the exact same thing? Because even when they say it's not, it is always about money.

Oil climbing higher right now as the U.S. government looks to add new emergency regulations around transporting oil via railroads. Over to Fox contributor Phil Flynn at the CME. And Phil, I want to talk about oil, but natural gas is a big mover today. What is going on there?

PHIL FLYNN, THE PRICE FUTURES GROUP: It is. What we're seeing, of course, is the collapsing of the curve of the March and the April mainly on changing weather forecasts. But Melissa, what's also happening I think with the natural gas is people are now trying to predict where we're going to end storage for the entire season. A lot of people are betting we could fall below a trillion cubic feet. Whether we do or not, the big question is if we do, can we get back to full storage before next winter and that is really what's driving the trade right now.

FRANCIS: And this talk about shipping from the Bakken Shale, I mean that was on the front of every paper today. Every oil trader talking about it.

FLYNN: It is. Yeah. And it is going to add to the cost of the barrel of oil. You know, the competition for route space has already been incredible in that type of the world. And because oil was taking all the space, you know, it impacted every market. Even the grains can't get down to the United States because of this. This type of crude, Melissa, I talked to refiners, it is so pure, it is unbelievable. It's almost like it's coming out of the ground refined. And while that is good for the refiners it is very volatile, very dangerous. And they want to check, you know, every barrel that goes in.

FRANCIS: Sure.

FLYNN: What this is going to be. And it's more money. It's going to cost - right now it is costing a couple of dollars a barrel.

FRANCIS: More money and I understand it's going to drive up the price of cookies? How so?

FLYNN: It is. This is an outrage, I know. Right now because rail space has been taken over by the Bakken Shale, there is no room to move grains and oats and, we saw oat prices hit the highest level in five years. It caused a price spike. That means that your cookie price could go up at least 1.5 percent. This is an outrage.

FRANCIS: It's very serious.

FLYNN: I think .

FRANCIS: We eat a lot of cookies in my house, Phil. We're out of time. And that is very serious. Thank you so much for coming on.

FLYNN: I've got you.

FRANCIS: I appreciate it.

FLYNN: Thank you, Melissa.

FRANCIS: From gas to batteries now, Elon Musk and Tesla sending shockwaves on Wall Street today. The carmaker hitting all-time highs after announcing plans to build the world's largest battery factory with a partnership with Panasonic. Not everyone's believer in the battery powered engine that could. Time for another Wall Street throw down. Jeff Reeves of InvestorPlace.com is a Tesla (INAUDIBLE). And Maxfund.com Jonas Max Ferris thinks there are bumpy roads ahead this. Also, a Fox News contributor, Jeff, make the bull case right now for me.

JEFF REEVES, INVESTORPLACE.COM EDITOR: Well, you know, short term, I think Tesla is basically trading on charts and sentiments. So, I'm not going to speculate about the next six weeks. But I think long term Tesla is definitely where it needs to be and we've seen this with a lot of innovative companies where they basically become their brand. You know, electric vehicles are Tesla.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

REEVES: What the Prius did, I meant the Prius was the best-selling car in California. One of the best-selling cars in the world right now. It clearly, it kind of made a lot of strides on the hybrid front. And it hasn't lost that brand. I think if Tesla does this right, it has a huge runway out of it. It just has this bottleneck on production.

FRANCIS: Jonas, it has a bottleneck on production. And Jonas, I mean one of the knocks against it has been, how can they possibly create batteries fast enough to keep up with demand. Well, they're solving that problem. I mean Elon is so smart he goes down and he's like, well, you know, what, I'm going to build my own battery factory, so that I don't have a problem. Why you do not like this, Jonas?

JONAS MAX FERRIS: It sounds like Henry Ford when he put rubber plants in Brazil because he couldn't get rubber fast enough. Look, the guy is a genius. He is a Henry Ford of our generation. I love Tesla. I'd like to own one. But this stock is a problem now. It trades as if they are selling a million cars. And yeah, you can fantasize about it being the word distributed power company with this factory and going into other things like some companies overpriced like Amazon and Apple did, then they took over those markets, but the reality is it's a car company that sold 22,000 cars roughly last year. They have to grow sales 50 percent a year, which is their expectation this year from Elon Musk for a decade or more just to catch up to like BMW or other car companies. And they're already trading at a third of the market value. And so, if they're absolutely perfectly flawless in this execution and everybody has got a Tesla and it's the number one car they then only are going to be worth a little more than they're worth today.

FRANCIS: No, it is pretty crazy. I mean, Jeff, the stock is just so incredibly expensive if you look at the forward P.E., and it's trading at almost 70. You look at something like GM, it's trading at seven. Coke, 16. Google 20. BMW, 10. Why is Tesla worth almost 70 times its forward P.E.?

REEVES: Well, I mean I think you're, looking at Coke is probably the wrong metric there for forward P.E.

FRANCIS: OK, how about GM? How about BMW? How about Google? Google is a tech company.

REEVES: A different car company. I would, I would posit that it is much better for you to look at a company like LinkedIn, or Netflix or Amazon. Companies that have had huge forward P.E.s for a while and yet has had big run-ups in a last year or two. I mean the valuation argument is an old one. And I think that it's very important. You remember that in 2015 the valuation there .

FRANCIS: Old and compelling.

REEVES: It didn't play out that way.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

REEVES: Because right now there is just not a lot of growth options that investors are willing to pay premiums for growth in a company like this.

FRANCIS: Get in there, Jonas.

FERRIS: There is not a lot of growth options is not a good enough reason to pay a ridiculous - It is an old argument, but it's exactly - it's kind of like Amazon played out. If you recall Amazon got really expensive in the late '90s on promise of the future. The stock still fell 90 percent before years later it caught up to that old price. And it actually delivered on promise. It got - it wasn't just books. It became this whole thing where they took over the world. And that might be Tesla's future in ten or 15 years, but you're paying that price today where you might see the stock fall 80 percent over the next ten years before it realizes those dreams way, way down the road.

FRANCIS: OK. We've got to go. Next time you guys have got to get a referee involved. I don't know. Thanks so much.

FERRIS: Thanks.

FRANCIS: Retail stocks are soaring right now. Shares of Abercrombie & Fitch teetering their double-digit gains. Brian Sozzi of Belus Capital just got off conference calls several of the giants going on in the past few hours. He is here on the phone. Brian, let's start with Target. What did you think - what was the best question on that call? What did you learn that we wouldn't know if you weren't on the call?

BRIAN SOZZI, BELUS CAPITAL: Well, one of the first things I learned in that call, Melissa, that Target is bringing mannequins into their store. Kind of goofy, but very interesting. It might actually get people excited on buying clothes at Target again. But one of the most shocking things are - Target is cutting its capital expenditures by $1 billion this year. Now, and that is a serious red flag, because they have not set out (INAUIDBLE) for how much they are going to have to pay for credit card breech. But now you're worrying that Target is going to underinvest in their stores and lose their cool factor compared to Walmart and Target.

FRANCIS: So, you think that the massive data breach, that's evidence of the data breach is having an even bigger impact than people were thinking? I mean if so, then why is the stock soaring right now?

SOZZI: Well, the stock is soaring today because they came out and told us that their same-store sales, is about flat. Now, flat is a lot better than negative in the quarter, but still the company had a long way to improve their sales. And I think over the next couple of months you're going to see Target go on a marketing blitz and promotional blitz to get customers back in the store.

FRANCIS: OK.

SOZZI: They're worried about their profits.

FRANCIS: I want to talk about Abercrombie. Because you were on that call as well. And I'm looking at CISI (ph) is raising its price target on it right now to 45 from 33. What did you hear on the Abercrombie call and how do you feel about that one?

SOZZI: Well, I think tomorrow you will all see more brokers will raise price targeting Abercrombie. Why? And it's probably momentum behind the name. The company is slashing expenses quicker than anybody would have thought. But I do have some (INAUDIBLE) for this call. First of all, traffic is down significantly and remains down significantly in Abercrombie and the domestic stores. Most importantly the European business really didn't have a strong quarter at all. And I'm concerned about that. Because whole - many other retailers are now starting to turn the quarter in Europe.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

SOZZI: Abercrombie is - and still is also lowering prices. No good for me.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Although that stock is on fire today. Those investors are loving it. It is up almost 11 percent. Thanks for hopping off those calls and on to the phone with us, Brian. We appreciate it. Back to work.

SOZZI: Thank you.

FRANCIS: All right, up next: Wall Street versus Silicon Valley. Big bank bonuses enraged so many, but why don't big tech company bonuses cause the same fury? No one cares. They don't pay attention. Banks, they hate it. Tweet me, tell me what you think. Someone is paying out almost a billion dollars. It is today's "Money Talker." And California's mega drought could last 200 years. The true cost of that. More "MONEY" around the scientists behind it coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: It is the battle of the big pay day. While Wall Street executives are scrutinized for their compensation, their Silicon Valley counterparts are given a pass when it comes to massive paychecks. Have you noticed this? The most recent exec bonus bash hitting RBS. Word is it's paying out almost a billion dollars in bonuses. It is today's "Money Talker." And we've got Boyden Global Managing Partner Jeanne Branthover, Wells Fargo chief economist John Silvia, and "The Wall Street Journal" senior writer Spencer Ante. Thanks to all of you for joining us. I don't know if you guys have noticed this, we were talking about this in our meeting. You've got this huge paychecks in Silicon Valley, no one bats an eye. They don't care. Somebody like Eric Schmidt in Google another $100 million just for being chairman. I mean the head - Marisa Mayer, she comes, she signs on, for what was it - $129 million. I'm sure she was leaving things behind at Google. And that's why they did it, but still, no one bats an eye. At the banks, you know, Jamie Dimon, it's your $20 million. Everyone is hysterical. Why is there a double standard?

JEANNE BRANTHOVER, BOYDEN GLOBAL MANAGING PARTNER: Because it's financial services and right now financial services, it's being scrutinized. They want transparency. People feel that they're the reason for the crisis. And so, therefore any money that is being given out is going to be criticized.

FRANCIS: Spencer, is that what it is all about?

SPENCER ANTE, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Well, yeah, you know, Wall Street almost brought the entire global economy to the brink of a global depression.

FRANCIS: But the dot-com bubble burst. I mean that was a disaster.

ANTE: But that was a long time ago.

FRANCIS: That was a long time ago.

(LAUGHTER)

ANTE: That was over a decade. I would say this. I don't think tech executives are being given a free pass.

FRANCIS: Right.

ANTE: They're getting a lot more scrutiny, actually. And it is interesting because I think the new bogey man could be the tech executives because there's rising anger and discontent over inequality in America. And tech executives are taking home the biggest paychecks in the economy now.

FRANCIS: But what is the evidence that it is shifting? I mean, John, are you seeing any of that? Because I saw people protesting outside Jamie Dimon's house. And I don't see them outside Eric Schmidt's house.

JOHN SILVIA, WELLS FARGO CHIEF ECONOMIST: Well, I'd go back to what Spencer had to say. I think a lot of this has perceived value. And when you are talking about someone in the tech area, for example, Facebook or Google, Apple, people perceive that there is value in what they're doing. I think when someone goes to a bank .

FRANCIS: There is not value in what financial services do?

SILVIA: No, I think when someone goes to a bank .

FRANCIS: We all use our credit cards and our ATM and our checking account every single day!

SILVIA: But when you go to a bank there is ATM. And it's not - it is not sexy. It's not interesting. It is just, an ATM.

ANTE: It's financial engineering.

BRANTHOVER: Exactly.

ANTE: That is the reputation. It's financial .

FRANCIS: But you think it is shifting? I mean .

ANTE: I do. Well, if you go to San Francisco, this is the number one issue people are talking about is the one percent. They're protesting Google buses. They're getting bricks thrown at the buses. Tom Perkins, the famous venture capitalist.

FRANCIS: Although he is a conservative.

ANTE: Who caused a huge firestorm when he compared what happened to the google buses to Kristallnacht. OK, so - that is a good example of why tech executives are getting more scrutiny. Not as much as Wall Street. But if they don't .

FRANCIS: They're not going after Cheryl Sandberg. They're not going after Mark Zuckerberg.

BRANTHOVER: But then it is people. You have to understand. Look at everybody's shareholders are looking at where is the future, right? So, right now at least in the executive search world people feel that technology is getting us out of the crisis. Technology is ..

FRANCIS: But who's financing technology?

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: I mean who takes them public.

BRANTHOVER: They don't think. That's in the back .

FRANCIS: Who enables people to pay for those services online?

BRANTHOVER: But you're thinking like the rational business person who looks at financial services and understands it. Most people don't. Most people as you said, they're using their iPads. They're using their phones. They see the value in these companies.

FRANCIS: What do you think, John?

SILVIA: I think it's all comes back to perceived value. I mean that was the story of, you know, "Money Ball", the movie. Some people sat at that table, and didn't understand why you were going to pay this fellow. Other people said hey, here are the numbers. This is why we pay him. And I think it's perceived value that when you're looking at Google, when you look at your iPad, your iPhone, there is value.

BRANTHOVER: Right.

ANTE: I would agree with that. But I would go one step further. I would say, it is actually real value. If you look at the market capitalizations of these technology companies, they are soaring. Facebook is worth almost $200 billion.

SILVIA: You're Wall Street, it is perceived value.

FRANCIS: Correct.

SILVIA: It's what people .

ANTE: It's the value today.

SILVIA: That's value today.

ANTE: It might be less tomorrow.

SILVIA: You got it. Just like a Major League Baseball player.

ANTE: Right. It's been going up.

(CROSSTALK)

ANTE: The fact that these companies are creating value in the market is justifying these large paychecks to a certain extent.

FRANCIS: OK, we've got to go. Thanks, guys.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Great stuff. All right, thanks to all three of you. Some big business winners and losers when it comes to the president's new defense budget proposal. We're looking at possibly the fewest troops since before World War II. And a higher reliance on machines and unmanned drones. Our Rich Edson has the latest breakdown from D.C. How does it break down, Rich?

RICH EDSON, FOX BUSINESS: Well it depends on what you're looking at in the aspect of this. When you talk about fewer troops in the field, you look at the support that goes behind that. A lot of manned vehicles, especially on the ground. Analysts are pointing to perhaps some vehicles produced by Oshkosh, General Dynamics, BAE systems. They're also retiring some specifics, here's the U2 spy-plane, the classic from the Cold War will be retired. The maintenance cost on that will go away for some companies. Also, the littoral combat shift. They scaled back the orders on that one. That hits Lockheed Martin and General Dynamics. Also, two unmanned drones, the Predator and the Reaper that is built by General Atomics. And that will also be scaled back. So, there is specific programs in here, I think, quite generally, anything that's used to support troops are going to get hit in this budget.

FRANCIS: Yeah. So, and who else gets hurt?

EDSON: Well, that is pretty much it from that perspective, especially when you scale that down. As far as the winners are concerned, you know, you look at the other side of it, and you're building more of these technology intense types of weaponry. And that is right in the wheelhouse of companies like Lockheed Martin, and many of the others that we've seen. Boeing is out there developing these types of technologies. And that is why you saw many of these stocks even hitting 52-week highs even during an announcement where the Pentagon is talking about scaling troops down to the smallest size that we've seen in decades.

FRANCIS: Yeah. And how are the contractors taking it?

EDSON: Well, thus far, you know, right now the stock prices are taking it quite well. And there is still a lot more details to come out in this, Melissa. You know, this is just the president's request. We don't get the full request until next week. And then Congress writes the specifics and who knows what happens with that.

FRANCIS: Rich, thank you so much. Always appreciate it.

EDSON: Thanks.

FRANCIS: And get ready because we're going to save you money right now. Doctor Manny is here to tell you how to stop throwing cash in the trash. I swear, you are going to be so surprised when you hear what he says. We were dying over this earlier today. It is incredible.

And why don't people get as angry over bonuses in the tech world as they do in big banks? Is the popular perception fair anymore? We fought it out. Tweet me, and tell me what you think. You've heard the segment. Tell me your response. Do you ever have too much money?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: OK, we're looking at Dow that's basically flat on the session so I wanted to show you Best Buy because some news is just crossing on that. They are announcing that they are going to cut 2,000 managers and you can see that investors there like that. It is trading up about 1.6 percent so far on the session.

All right, chew on this. Americans are literally throwing away more than $160 billion worth of food this year. That is nearly a third of the food that we buy. You may think you know what to eat and what to keep from the expiration dates, but we have got some very surprising stats that will help you keep your cash from going bad. It is time for your "Medical Dollars with Dr. Manny."

So, this is a list of things that you can keep.

DR. MANNY ALVAREZ, FOX NEWS MEDICAL A-TEAM: And we're still overweight.

FRANCIS: After the ..

ALVAREZ: Right. $160 billion thrown in the garbage, and we're still overweight.

FRANCIS: That's because Oreo cookies never go bad. Fritos, never go bad. They last till nuclear war, you don't have to worry about it.

But we're talking about fresh healthy food, eggs. You can keep three to five weeks after the expiration date?

ALVAREZ: And that is correct.

FRANCIS: Are you kidding me?!

ALVAREZ: You can. Listen. If you go to any country, they - look, expiration dates have a purpose, of course, is to keep us safe, to make sure that things don't spoil, so you don't get an infection. But it is also to move merchandise around. I mean you've got a whole supply coming in.

FRANCIS: Say it isn't so?

ALVAREZ: It is so. I know my money. I used to have a deli. I know how these things works. So, a lot of it you really don't have to pay attention a lot to the expiration date.

FRANCIS: Really? So, eggs is not one that I would .

ALVAREZ: If they are properly kept in the refrigerator, three weeks.

FRANCIS: Sandwich meats?

ALVAREZ: Sandwich meats.

FRANCIS: You can ignore it?

ALVAREZ: Nowadays you could keep them before up to two weeks if you want to. And basically, if, especially if the packages, as a lot of these meats that come in vacuum sealed. And again you can keep them for, as long as they are properly refrigerated you can keep them for a long time.

FRANCIS: Bacon, two weeks, after if it is unopened, packaged dinners with the USDA seal. Hotdogs, two weeks after - now, hotdogs - have hotdogs in my fridge that are five years old. That is no good. I thought hotdogs last forever.

ALVAREZ: Are they frozen?

FRANCIS: I mean - aren't they full of preservatives and chemicals anyway?

ALVAREZ: Yeah, but I mean, look, like everything else. It is all about how they are packaged. It is all about how they're processed and it's all about how they're stored. I mean if you find products, for instance, in some grocery stores, there is a lot of light coming through the window you can rest assured that you are eating away nutrients.

FRANCIS: Right. That's it's rotten before you even get out of the store.

ALVAREZ: Exactly. Yeah. If the temperature of the store is inappropriate. There is a lot of things that come into consideration. That is why these numbers come into play, you know, these expiration dates. But again, I don't know where they came from to begin with.

FRANCIS: That's true. There is a list of stuff that you should toss.

ALVAREZ: Absolutely.

FRANCIS: Infant formula. No, that's one - I always feel like that is a manipulation. Because with the infant formula, a lot of it - I mean it's not refrigerated. So .

ALVAREZ: It's not refrigerated, but it's about the nutrients. There is a lot of degradation when it comes from storage.

FRANCIS: OK.

ALVAREZ: And certainly, you don't want to keep that for a long time.

FRANCIS: We say meat here, but we were just talking about hotdogs and packaged goods.

ALVAREZ: But this is fresh meat.

FRANCIS: You're talking about like - steaks.

ALVAREZ: The chicken and all of that. Again, we know about .

FRANCIS: Lettuce and spinach. That is a dangerous one. And people don't realize it. Why is that one you should get rid of?

ALVAREZ: Well, because look how many cases of food poisoning we get from fresh spinach and lettuce.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

ALVAREZ: So again, as the lettuce oxidizes and everything is more embedded, there is more chances for bacteria to grow and that, of course, contaminates the food supply, and ergo you get sick.

FRANCIS: So the eggs. I'm going to keep them for five weeks. I'm going to eat them. And if get sick .

ALVAREZ: You call me.

FRANCIS: I'm coming to find you.

ALVAREZ: No copay.

FRANCIS: I'm going to be furious!

ALVAREZ: That's OK.

FRANCIS: No, I will just eat Fritos instead.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Dr. Manny, thanks so much. Fritos are always safe.

All right. Quick shoutout to Netflix for this one, having a little fun in the drone zone. Playing off Amazon the announcement that drones can start delivering packages, Netflix is touting. It's touting cheek drone to home service. Saying your DVD can be delivered within seconds and adding it to your queue anywhere you are, anywhere. It's going to be amazing to watch for Amazon's response. I can't wait to see that one.

All right. Up next, the mega drought still causing pain in California. Now, a new study says it could last for centuries. This could have a long- term effect on industries out west with ripple effects from coast to coast.

And China's toxic smog is getting even worse. Some experts are drawing similarities to nuclear winter. Find out how one guy is fighting back. "Piles of Money" coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: So word out that IBM could start a major round of layoffs starting today. One analyst is expecting as many as 13,000 job cuts. Charles Payne follows IBM, and Charles, this is one of those stories, you know, I mean, I know part of it is coming from a union inside IBM of workers. There is also an analyst at Bernstein talking about it. Has that rumor feel to it. What do you make of this whole thing?

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: I go to tell you, Melissa, any time we hear about jobs, particularly good jobs, you know, being lost, it's sort of one of these not just a Wall Street story but it's a Main Street story, and that's why it captures everybody's attention. And of course, we're talking Big Blue, IBM. But IBM has had some problems. And this is one of these rumors you can believe, because apparently this union is part of what they call the Systems and Technology Unit. Last report they put out for their last quarter that units of revenues down 26 percent and gross margin went to 38 percent from 44 percent in a year. Obviously there are serious issues there and IBM is probably going to address it this way.

FRANCIS: Yes. And you look at that the stock, I mean, it is trading higher on the day. I mean, obviously, investors looking for a change over there. But you know, interesting story to see how it really plays out.

Charles, thanks so much.

PAYNE: You got it.

FRANCIS: All right.

Over California now with the devastating mega drought is showing no signs of lighting up. This dramatic before and after picture really tells the tale, one scientist thinks the golden state might stay dry for the next two centuries, 200 years.

Joining me now on the phone is climatologist Lynn Ingram who says this phenomena may last 200 years. What makes you think that, Lynn?

LYNN INGRAM, CLIMATOLOGIST (via phone): Hi. Well, we study the past climate, you know, looking back thousands of years and we see these patterns of wet and dry. And we see in the past there were periods of over a century of less than maybe 50 to 60 percent precipitation and so we just kind of think these climate patterns repeat themselves, then we very well could be entering a dryer period.

FRANCIS: And a lot has to do with temperatures in the Pacific Ocean, right? And that it is cooler? Is there anything that could make a turnaround and get warmer again?

INGRAM: Well, it is, you know, it has got to do that itself. Unfortunately, it is just this big body of water that brings where we get all our moisture for precipitation. And so, we are kind at the mercy of the sort of ocean circulation and what sets up these patterns of cooler water off of our coast and. So, all we can do is wait and see if we are going to continue in this dryer period or if things turn around.

FRANCIS: And it is so interesting, because I grew up in California and it is a lot of farmers that are basically out there trying to farm in the desert and they set up this system, this complex aqueduct system to get water around places where there isn't usually water. Are they prepared for this? I mean, if we go in to the two hundred years, is it reasonable to think they can do something, you know, to keep farmers in place and keep people in place?

INGRAM: Right. Well, unfortunately, a lot of these dams and canals were built in the 20th century and that was a relatively wetter century. And so, I think some changes are going to have to be made because we really -- if we are entering an average dryer period, we really can't -- we are not going to have the water, resources that we had before. And also we have been depleting our granddaughter, and that is like water in the bank that we have been using up. And so, we really need to start banking water underground which people are talking about now to prepare.

FRANCIS: It is an important story for all our viewers because we all get so much food and produce and everything else out of California. So it impacts you whether you live in California or not.

Lynn, thank you so much for joining us. We appreciate your insight.

INGRAM: Yes, you are very welcome.

FRANCIS: From the U.S. recorder of the globe money has been flying around world again today.

Starting in northern China where one guy is the first person to sue the government over the country's toxic smog. The fed up president is demanding compensation for the money he spent on safety masks, on an air purifier, an indoor treadmill, since outdoor exercise is no longer an option. Look at that. Would you exercise outside? Looking at these photos you see why he would feel this way. The first is Beijing on a normal clear day. Next to it is how the city looks right now. Look at that just two weeks later. That cannot be healthy.

Moving on to Switzerland, Credit Suisse acknowledging misconduct by a small group of employees that allows some wealthy American clients to stash away billions and un-tax assets. What's wrong with that? City investigators say the bank has been holding up to $12 billion in cash, it is all mine. And more than 22,000 accounts for those U.S. customers and the bank says it is ready to hand over more info on those clients. Chief executive Brady Dugan was on Capitol Hill today to face a grilling by the Senate subcommittee heading to the crow.

And landing in Brazil where sporting goods brand Adidas is withdrawing some of its world cup t-shirts for being too sexy. One shirt had the words looking to score, while another seemed to show the back of a bikini clad woman. Brazil's tourism board asked the company to drop the shirts thinking they promoted, quote, "sexual tourism." Very cheeky, sexual tourism. It sounds interesting.

Up next, who needs the valley when you can head to silicon prairie? I like the sound to that. Find out how one entrepreneur left one of the most successful venture capital firms in the country to help create a tax haven in the Midwest.

At the end of the day it is all about "Money."

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: I'm Cheryl Casone with your FOX Business brief.

U.S. Bank earnings jumped by 17 percent in the fourth quarter. The FDIC reports the banking industry earned $40.3 billion last quarter up from $30.4 billion the previous year. Losses on loans jumped to a seven year low. For all of 2013 banks earned a record $154.7 billion.

Hewlett Packard has won a $32 million cybersecurity contract from the department of homeland security. HP will provide software security to 33 federal civilian government agencies to prevent network vulnerabilities and defense against packers.

New homes sales surge in the month of January by 9.6 percent. That is the fastest pace in 5-1/2 years. According to the commerce department is single-family homes were sold in an annual rate of 468,000 beating analysts' expectations. Sales in the northeast soaring of more than 73 percent.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Move over Silicon Valley, there's a new player in the fight for text tar nets (ph). The Midwest, one venture capital giant is moving away from sunny California and over to Columbus, Ohio. Silicon prairie. I like the name of that.

Joining me now is Drive capital's Mark Kvamme. Thanks for joining us.

You know, when I look the way the capital has distributed, a lot of places is cropping up -- Illinois, big money, Ohio, Western Pennsylvania, and Missouri. What is the attraction? Is there a lot of good labor?

MARK KVAMME, DRIVE CAPITAL: Well, I think is it not just labor. I mean, you got to remember, the over 25 percent of the United States research budget is spent in the Midwest with for fabulous universities like University of Michigan, OSU (ph), Carnegie-Mellon, and northwestern and many others that are minting phenomenal engineers. In the past, those engineers if they wanted to follow what they wanted to do, they had to go to Silicon Valley or go to Boston. What you're seeing now is capital in places like Chicago and Columbus and other places where they can stay and build their dreams.

FRANCIS: Are the governments more friendly? I mean, California is got pretty hostile in terms of visas and tax structure and property prices.

KVAMME: Yes. I mean, it is really crazy. I grew up in Silicon Valley and I lived there, you know, in the 60s, 70s, 80s, 90s and so on. And in fact, there was a report recently about how selling in Palo Alto, there were 1100 square feet with one car garage for its foundation was cracked, roof was leaking from a $1.6 million.

FRANCIS: No, stop it. You are making that up.

KVAMME: No. I am not making that up. And by the way, it was right next to the train tracks. I mean, it is crazy in California right now. Whereas, you know, for $1.6 million in the Midwest, you are going to buy a palace. But it really is not just about that. I mean, what has happened is we had a huge technology shift with the whole invention of cloud computing, you know, Amazon web services and rock space and others, you can actually be an engineer in Columbus, Ohio or Cincinnati or Chicago and not have to worry about the back end technology you had to do in the past to build facebook or Google or these other great companies in Silicon Valley.

FRANCIS: Yes. And a lot of companies out there are ones everybody knows, Group On, Angie's List, Orbits, Scrub Hub, Brain Trick (ph), Career Builder, I mean, one of the companies you are invested in, Farm Logs (ph), went to Silicon Valley and they came back to Michigan. How come?

KVAMME: Well, I mean, basically, (INAUDIBLE), who is the founder there grew up in Michigan, became a computer scientist, went to Silicon Valley because he thought that was where he had to go in the white culminated class, you know, PolyGram. The great incubator this after he got the idea for Farm Lobby, wait a second. All right, my customers are in the Midwest. Why would I be here? Why am I paying engineers as much money as that to pay I am here versus moving back to Michigan, where it is have to a third the cost? So, he moved back to Michigan so he could be close to his customers, close to the great engineering talent that is coming out of places like the Anniversary of Michigan.

FRANCIS: Yes. And Mark, you know what you're talking about, I mean, coming from (INAUDIBLE) capital going over to create Drive Capital. Good luck to you. Thanks for coming on the show.

KVAMME: Well, thank you very much. I really appreciate it.

FRANCIS: The closing bell is just about an hour away. Lots going on in the last hour of trading always. Liz, what do you have coming up in your jammed-pack show?

LIZ CLAMAN, FBN HOST, COUNTDOWN TO THE CLOSING BELL: Let me just start of by saying, you rocket in this show. I tell you. Riveted, I almost came down late.

FRANCIS: We keep the pace going. We keep it going. We got a lot in there.

CLAMAN: And I'm totally with Dr. Manny about expirations dates because my dad was a doctor and he said they are just for the lawyers. Expiration dates are just for the layers.

FRANCIS: Hot dogs you can keep forever -- five, six, ten years. They are still good.

CLAMAN: Exactly.

OK, yes, I know that you know we got new home sales and they have done the complete opposite of what all the other housing numbers of done which have been down. They jumped more than nine percent. It is a big move and it makes you wonder who is really benefiting and we want to know who would benefit for you as far as the owning stock is concerned, we have Farooq Kathwari who is the CEO of Ethan Allen coming up. We going to talk to him about what kind of action he has seen when it comes to sales of Ethan Allen furniture. We are going to ask him what it hottest sellers are and what he sees for the future of the housing market. It is one of those so-called derivative plays. And as we look at what they can put into your home, it is the new home sales that tend to benefit the kinds of companies like Ethan Allen.

I also want to mention everybody is looking and waiting for JCPenney numbers "after the bell" today. Watch out. There is another store chain you need to be watching out for because it may really provide a much worse situation than JCPenney as we will talk about that and more coming up.

FRANCIS: Liz, all right, looks fortunate. Thanks so much.

CLAMAN: Anytime.

FRANCIS: Go get ready. You only have a couple minutes left.

CLAMAN: I'm going.

FRANCIS: All right, up next, with so many airline flights already cancelled this winter, we are going to tell you how to be sure the trip you book actually makes it out. Guess what. It is all about money. There's a formula to is this, you cannot afford to miss it. We will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: OK. I want to show you JCPenney right now because this is the stock that is reporting "after the bell." And you know, analysts are saying that any game here, which is relatively significant up on a percentage basis of almost three percent, is a dead cat bounce. We are looking for revenue to fall slightly year over year but earnings out "after the bell" and right now investors spending ahead of it.

Now for a little fun with spare change and hopefully this helps you from wasting when you book your next trip. The Cancellator, it is real, traveler beware, it might be targeting your next flight. Here to explain his travel expert Mark Murphy.

OK. So the Cancellator is an algorithm that the airlines use and they all use it and it helps them decide which flights to cancel.

MARK MURPHY, FOUNDER, TRAVELPULSE.COM: Absolutely. So, and it is just computer-based, just like the airplanes fly based on computers.

FRANCIS: It is not just weather and they are looking out for safety and we are going to get killed by a snowstorm, they cancelled our flight? It is more complex than that.

MURPHY: Well, there is a lot of things like crew changes. They are moving one crew from let's say Dallas-Fort Worth and they want to get them up to Chicago. So, they are going to make sure that that plane arrives with that crew is going connect with a flight, let's say to London Heathrow.

FRANCIS: So, they would have priority to let them get out before their storm closes? I mean, how did they get priority?

MURPHY: Well, just priority in terms of getting those crews to their next flight or if you're talking about a connection, let's say you are on the connection, if a lot of people on that connection are business travelers, high-yield travelers that are connecting on, that is going to get a priority over, let's say, a flight that will end at that destination with a bunch of leisure travelers which tend to book far in advance and hey much lower price than the average business traveler.

FRANCIS: So, let me get it straight. So there's a delay at the airport and they're trying to figure out which flights they are going to ground and which flight they are going to let get out.

MURPHY: Profit has a big --

FRANCIS: And there is an algorithm in there and it is not just who is waiting the longest.

MURPHY: Correct.

FRANCIS: There's nothing fair about this.

MURPHY: It is all about fare.

FRANCIS: It has to do with are there a lot of business travelers that pay a lot of money that flight goes first?

MURPHY: Yes. There is a lot of factor. This is about any one factor. It is not just the weather, it is not just mechanical delays, it is crews, profitability, it is connections.

FRANCIS: And it is how much people paid.

MURPHY: Of course. Yes, that factors in. It is not the only factor, but it is part of that.

FRANCIS: So now that I know about this how do I game it next time I am booking a flight, I pay more?

MURPHY: You really can't game it, to be frank, because it has so many factors of outside of your control. What you can do is you can be proactive and book with a travel agent. Travel agents book 50 percent of all tickets, 60 percent of all international --.

FRANCIS: Why does it help me if the travel agency?

MURPHY: So let's say you are flying and you are connecting in Dallas, but your flight got the late on the way to Dallas so you are going to miss your connection. The agent is aware of that delay. They are already rebooking you so by the time. So by the time you are on the ground --

FRANCIS: They are now out to lunch having some food?

MURPHY: No, mostly they will found out. A good one, no, they're actively working on your behalf.

FRANCIS: Avoid late in the day flights?

MURPHY: Yes. Because what happens is it goes later in the day, those issues stack up and then it becomes a domino effect and you may not get out. If you take that first flight out of the day, you are much -- have a much better likelihood --

FRANCIS: Can you game which flights there are more business travelers on like if it is a three class plane or if there is no connection? How do you try and figure out which one the big money guys are on?

MURPHY: Rush-hour. Rush hour to airport --

FRANCIS: What is that?

MURPHY: So, you know, 6:00 to 8:00 in the morning, business travelers on the way. 5:00 to 8:00 p.m. they are coming home. So look at those flights that are, you know, a little later in the morning or that very, very first flight in the morning.

FRANCIS: Mark, thank you. Very interesting. I knew there was more to it. It is always all about money.

All right, coming up, you heard it here on FOX Business. It was a scoop. (INAUDIBLE) CEO saying of the Bitcoin exchange is going nowhere. Is the crypto currency about to implode or is this just the inevitable rocky start to something fairly great? We are getting in to the bottom of it.

You can never have too much Bitcoin.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Whether it is on Wall Street or Main Street, here is who is making money today.

Surprisingly anyone who owns Target, the sign or rich stock is popping despite the lackluster earnings report revealing falling sales and it hit to nothing income still, profit came in above estimates. That's enough to please investors. Shares now trading up about seven percent almost, on the day. Good for them. One person making money is the chief executive, Greg Stein. He owns about 1.5 million shares meaning he made about $5.5 million just so far today. Very nice.

Making money from our nation's spying initiative is Boeing. It is getting more than $2 billion to build another 16 long-range maritime spy planes for the Navy. The new spy aircraft will replace an aging fleet which has already been used for more than 40 years. They are based on a version of the 737 there used anti-submarine and anti-war care surveillance work. They are proving to be very popular. Eight have been ordered by the Australian government. Boeing stock right now is down around two-tenths of one percent.

Also making money the California -- did you hear about this? The California couple that may have stumbled upon one of the greatest treasure trove ever to be found in the U.S. The anonymous below was out walking their dog in the backyard when they stumbled on rusty metal cans. The inside, they discovered coins from gold rush era worth more than $10 million. Currency experts have confirmed the coins are authentic and the near mint condition. They plan to sell most of them on Amazon, of all things while others will be displayed in an upcoming exhibit. I bet they are going to have a lot of new friends. I'd like to be their new friend. Those are nice.

Turning to Bitcoin now, the virtual currency having a tough go of it lately. We just got word that Bitcoin derivatives market BTC suspended trading after a key exchange partner Mount Gox has gone dark. Of course, we know Mount Gox has been subpoenaed by federal prosecutors. FOX Business obtained chant logs from exchange CEO Mark Karpeles saying he in exchange are not they're not going anywhere despite the site being offline since yesterday. Is it time for the currency to be regulated?

Massachusetts bank commissioner David Cotney joins me on this one.

Commissioner, thanks for joining me. What do you make of these (INAUDIBLE)? With the CEO saying that they are not going anywhere. What do you read into that?

DAVID COTNEY, MASSACHUSETTS BANK COMMISSIONER: Well, I think in the wake of the shutdown on line of the Mount Gox exchange there are a lot of unanswered questions, both technical and legal and I think that we are all going to look forward to having some of those questions answered in the days ahead.

FRANCIS: I mean, in answering those questions, they obviously just received the subpoena we are talking about that from federal prosecutors. What does that mean? I mean, what are they looking for?

COTNEY: Well, I am sure they are looking for a chain of events to determine whether anything illegal, whether any fraud occurred because there are many people now who are asking, you know, where are their Bitcoin? Where is my money?

FRANCIS: What do you think needs to be done with Bitcoin? I mean, you think it needs more transparency? Do you think it needs more regulation? I mean, what is the answer in your mind?

COTNEY: Well, you know, when I talked to financial institutions, when I talk to consumers, when I talk to businesses, they all want a payment system that is more secure, more real time and less costly. And for the defenders of Bitcoin, they say that this answers many of those. And to that end, state regulators from around the country through the conference of state bank supervisors, we formed a task force to look at these emerging payment issues as well as some of the legacy payments to determine whether this should be further regulated and how they should be regulated. And to folks within the Bitcoin world, many of them even say that to the extent that this can become a more regulated type of transaction that will add to consumer confidence.

FRANCIS: But I guess, I mean, consumer confidence, the whole point of Bitcoin, what makes people feel confident about it is that they want the government out of their business. And inherent to that is a lot of risk and I feel like people who invest and transact in Bitcoin understand there is a risk and it is worth it to them because they don't want the government involve and snooping into what they're doing. What is wrong with that?

COTNEY: Well, there's nothing wrong or illegal per see of this Bitcoin network. But it is important for consumers to know that this is risky, this is not an FDIC insured type of deposit activity.

FRANCIS: But you don't think they know that? I mean, would that enough to satisfy if they said this is very risky. It is not backed. It is not insured. You know, the government is not guaranteeing anything that is going on here, buyer beware. Would that satisfy you if there was that disclosure for every transaction?

COTNEY: Well, and again, disclosure is probably one of the things that we will be looking at to determine what information do consumers need to make some type of informed decision? And if they feel a transaction that may not be backed by any type deposit insurance that may have less protection than that may be the way we go. But we just need to get further information on the best way to ensure that consumers have the information they need.

FRANCIS: Commissioner David Cotney, thanks so much for joining us. We appreciate your time.

COTNEY: Thanks for having me.

FRANCIS: That is all we have got for now. I hope that you are making money today. Tune in tomorrow for my interview with Florida governor Rick Scott. He is making Florida hotbed for startups bringing jobs to the state. That is tomorrow at 2:00 p.m.

Countdown though with Liz Claman starts right now.

END

urn:contentItem:5BMN-SV61-JD2T-F0C9-00000-00Stock Market Discussion; Discussion of Tesla Company Stocks; Comparing Bonuses in Tech and Financial Industry and the Aspect of Public2014-02-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisStock Market Discussion; Discussion of Tesla Company Stocks; Comparing Bonuses in Tech and Financial Industry and the Aspect of Public

MELISSA FRANCIS, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Boy, it is a big day, you know. S&P flirting with record territory right now. Also, oil is rising up. And new emergency rules are moving Bakken Shale via oil train. We're going live to the CME to show you what is happening. And we have got a signature "MONEY" style Wall Street throw down on Tesla, including a referee. Look at that. Plus, Silicon Valley versus Wall Street. RBS is paying out a billion bucks in bonuses. It is causing an outrage. Does anyone care when Google does the exact same thing? Because even when they say it's not, it is always about money.

Oil climbing higher right now as the U.S. government looks to add new emergency regulations around transporting oil via railroads. Over to Fox contributor Phil Flynn at the CME. And Phil, I want to talk about oil, but natural gas is a big mover today. What is going on there?

PHIL FLYNN, THE PRICE FUTURES GROUP: It is. What we're seeing, of course, is the collapsing of the curve of the March and the April mainly on changing weather forecasts. But Melissa, what's also happening I think with the natural gas is people are now trying to predict where we're going to end storage for the entire season. A lot of people are betting we could fall below a trillion cubic feet. Whether we do or not, the big question is if we do, can we get back to full storage before next winter and that is really what's driving the trade right now.

FRANCIS: And this talk about shipping from the Bakken Shale, I mean that was on the front of every paper today. Every oil trader talking about it.

FLYNN: It is. Yeah. And it is going to add to the cost of the barrel of oil. You know, the competition for route space has already been incredible in that type of the world. And because oil was taking all the space, you know, it impacted every market. Even the grains can't get down to the United States because of this. This type of crude, Melissa, I talked to refiners, it is so pure, it is unbelievable. It's almost like it's coming out of the ground refined. And while that is good for the refiners it is very volatile, very dangerous. And they want to check, you know, every barrel that goes in.

FRANCIS: Sure.

FLYNN: What this is going to be. And it's more money. It's going to cost - right now it is costing a couple of dollars a barrel.

FRANCIS: More money and I understand it's going to drive up the price of cookies? How so?

FLYNN: It is. This is an outrage, I know. Right now because rail space has been taken over by the Bakken Shale, there is no room to move grains and oats and, we saw oat prices hit the highest level in five years. It caused a price spike. That means that your cookie price could go up at least 1.5 percent. This is an outrage.

FRANCIS: It's very serious.

FLYNN: I think .

FRANCIS: We eat a lot of cookies in my house, Phil. We're out of time. And that is very serious. Thank you so much for coming on.

FLYNN: I've got you.

FRANCIS: I appreciate it.

FLYNN: Thank you, Melissa.

FRANCIS: From gas to batteries now, Elon Musk and Tesla sending shockwaves on Wall Street today. The carmaker hitting all-time highs after announcing plans to build the world's largest battery factory with a partnership with Panasonic. Not everyone's believer in the battery powered engine that could. Time for another Wall Street throw down. Jeff Reeves of InvestorPlace.com is a Tesla (INAUDIBLE). And Maxfund.com Jonas Max Ferris thinks there are bumpy roads ahead this. Also, a Fox News contributor, Jeff, make the bull case right now for me.

JEFF REEVES, INVESTORPLACE.COM EDITOR: Well, you know, short term, I think Tesla is basically trading on charts and sentiments. So, I'm not going to speculate about the next six weeks. But I think long term Tesla is definitely where it needs to be and we've seen this with a lot of innovative companies where they basically become their brand. You know, electric vehicles are Tesla.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

REEVES: What the Prius did, I meant the Prius was the best-selling car in California. One of the best-selling cars in the world right now. It clearly, it kind of made a lot of strides on the hybrid front. And it hasn't lost that brand. I think if Tesla does this right, it has a huge runway out of it. It just has this bottleneck on production.

FRANCIS: Jonas, it has a bottleneck on production. And Jonas, I mean one of the knocks against it has been, how can they possibly create batteries fast enough to keep up with demand. Well, they're solving that problem. I mean Elon is so smart he goes down and he's like, well, you know, what, I'm going to build my own battery factory, so that I don't have a problem. Why you do not like this, Jonas?

JONAS MAX FERRIS: It sounds like Henry Ford when he put rubber plants in Brazil because he couldn't get rubber fast enough. Look, the guy is a genius. He is a Henry Ford of our generation. I love Tesla. I'd like to own one. But this stock is a problem now. It trades as if they are selling a million cars. And yeah, you can fantasize about it being the word distributed power company with this factory and going into other things like some companies overpriced like Amazon and Apple did, then they took over those markets, but the reality is it's a car company that sold 22,000 cars roughly last year. They have to grow sales 50 percent a year, which is their expectation this year from Elon Musk for a decade or more just to catch up to like BMW or other car companies. And they're already trading at a third of the market value. And so, if they're absolutely perfectly flawless in this execution and everybody has got a Tesla and it's the number one car they then only are going to be worth a little more than they're worth today.

FRANCIS: No, it is pretty crazy. I mean, Jeff, the stock is just so incredibly expensive if you look at the forward P.E., and it's trading at almost 70. You look at something like GM, it's trading at seven. Coke, 16. Google 20. BMW, 10. Why is Tesla worth almost 70 times its forward P.E.?

REEVES: Well, I mean I think you're, looking at Coke is probably the wrong metric there for forward P.E.

FRANCIS: OK, how about GM? How about BMW? How about Google? Google is a tech company.

REEVES: A different car company. I would, I would posit that it is much better for you to look at a company like LinkedIn, or Netflix or Amazon. Companies that have had huge forward P.E.s for a while and yet has had big run-ups in a last year or two. I mean the valuation argument is an old one. And I think that it's very important. You remember that in 2015 the valuation there .

FRANCIS: Old and compelling.

REEVES: It didn't play out that way.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

REEVES: Because right now there is just not a lot of growth options that investors are willing to pay premiums for growth in a company like this.

FRANCIS: Get in there, Jonas.

FERRIS: There is not a lot of growth options is not a good enough reason to pay a ridiculous - It is an old argument, but it's exactly - it's kind of like Amazon played out. If you recall Amazon got really expensive in the late '90s on promise of the future. The stock still fell 90 percent before years later it caught up to that old price. And it actually delivered on promise. It got - it wasn't just books. It became this whole thing where they took over the world. And that might be Tesla's future in ten or 15 years, but you're paying that price today where you might see the stock fall 80 percent over the next ten years before it realizes those dreams way, way down the road.

FRANCIS: OK. We've got to go. Next time you guys have got to get a referee involved. I don't know. Thanks so much.

FERRIS: Thanks.

MURPHY: Well, there is a lot of things like crew changes. They are moving one crew from let's say Dallas-Fort Worth and they want to get them up to Chicago. So, they are going to make sure that that plane arrives with that crew is going connect with a flight, let's say to London Heathrow.

FRANCIS: So, they would have priority to let them get out before their storm closes? I mean, how did they get priority?

MURPHY: Well, just priority in terms of getting those crews to their next flight or if you're talking about a connection, let's say you are on the connection, if a lot of people on that connection are business travelers, high-yield travelers that are connecting on, that is going to get a priority over, let's say, a flight that will end at that destination with a bunch of leisure travelers which tend to book far in advance and hey much lower price than the average business traveler.

FRANCIS: So, let me get it straight. So there's a delay at the airport and they're trying to figure out which flights they are going to ground and which flight they are going to let get out.

MURPHY: Profit has a big --

FRANCIS: And there is an algorithm in there and it is not just who is waiting the longest.

MURPHY: Correct.

FRANCIS: There's nothing fair about this.

MURPHY: It is all about fare.

FRANCIS: It has to do with are there a lot of business travelers that pay a lot of money that flight goes first?

MURPHY: Yes. There is a lot of factor. This is about any one factor. It is not just the weather, it is not just mechanical delays, it is crews, profitability, it is connections.

FRANCIS: And it is how much people paid.

MURPHY: Of course. Yes, that factors in. It is not the only factor, but it is part of that.

FRANCIS: So now that I know about this how do I game it next time I am booking a flight, I pay more?

MURPHY: You really can't game it, to be frank, because it has so many factors of outside of your control. What you can do is you can be proactive and book with a travel agent. Travel agents book 50 percent of all tickets, 60 percent of all international --.

FRANCIS: Why does it help me if the travel agency?

MURPHY: So let's say you are flying and you are connecting in Dallas, but your flight got the late on the way to Dallas so you are going to miss your connection. The agent is aware of that delay. They are already rebooking you so by the time. So by the time you are on the ground --

FRANCIS: They are now out to lunch having some food?

MURPHY: No, mostly they will found out. A good one, no, they're actively working on your behalf.

FRANCIS: Avoid late in the day flights?

MURPHY: Yes. Because what happens is it goes later in the day, those issues stack up and then it becomes a domino effect and you may not get out. If you take that first flight out of the day, you are much -- have a much better likelihood --

FRANCIS: Can you game which flights there are more business travelers on like if it is a three class plane or if there is no connection? How do you try and figure out which one the big money guys are on?

MURPHY: Rush-hour. Rush hour to airport --

FRANCIS: What is that?

MURPHY: So, you know, 6:00 to 8:00 in the morning, business travelers on the way. 5:00 to 8:00 p.m. they are coming home. So look at those flights that are, you know, a little later in the morning or that very, very first flight in the morning.

FRANCIS: Mark, thank you. Very interesting. I knew there was more to it. It is always all about money.

All right, coming up, you heard it here on FOX Business. It was a scoop. (INAUDIBLE) CEO saying of the Bitcoin exchange is going nowhere. Is the crypto currency about to implode or is this just the inevitable rocky start to something fairly great? We are getting in to the bottom of it.

You can never have too much Bitcoin.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Whether it is on Wall Street or Main Street, here is who is making money today.

Surprisingly anyone who owns Target, the sign or rich stock is popping despite the lackluster earnings report revealing falling sales and it hit to nothing income still, profit came in above estimates. That's enough to please investors. Shares now trading up about seven percent almost, on the day. Good for them. One person making money is the chief executive, Greg Stein. He owns about 1.5 million shares meaning he made about $5.5 million just so far today. Very nice.

Making money from our nation's spying initiative is Boeing. It is getting more than $2 billion to build another 16 long-range maritime spy planes for the Navy. The new spy aircraft will replace an aging fleet which has already been used for more than 40 years. They are based on a version of the 737 there used anti-submarine and anti-war care surveillance work. They are proving to be very popular. Eight have been ordered by the Australian government. Boeing stock right now is down around two-tenths of one percent.

Also making money the California -- did you hear about this? The California couple that may have stumbled upon one of the greatest treasure trove ever to be found in the U.S. The anonymous below was out walking their dog in the backyard when they stumbled on rusty metal cans. The inside, they discovered coins from gold rush era worth more than $10 million. Currency experts have confirmed the coins are authentic and the near mint condition. They plan to sell most of them on Amazon, of all things while others will be displayed in an upcoming exhibit. I bet they are going to have a lot of new friends. I'd like to be their new friend. Those are nice.

Turning to Bitcoin now, the virtual currency having a tough go of it lately. We just got word that Bitcoin derivatives market BTC suspended trading after a key exchange partner Mount Gox has gone dark. Of course, we know Mount Gox has been subpoenaed by federal prosecutors. FOX Business obtained chant logs from exchange CEO Mark Karpeles saying he in exchange are not they're not going anywhere despite the site being offline since yesterday. Is it time for the currency to be regulated?

Massachusetts bank commissioner David Cotney joins me on this one.

Commissioner, thanks for joining me. What do you make of these (INAUDIBLE)? With the CEO saying that they are not going anywhere. What do you read into that?

DAVID COTNEY, MASSACHUSETTS BANK COMMISSIONER: Well, I think in the wake of the shutdown on line of the Mount Gox exchange there are a lot of unanswered questions, both technical and legal and I think that we are all going to look forward to having some of those questions answered in the days ahead.

FRANCIS: I mean, in answering those questions, they obviously just received the subpoena we are talking about that from federal prosecutors. What does that mean? I mean, what are they looking for?

COTNEY: Well, I am sure they are looking for a chain of events to determine whether anything illegal, whether any fraud occurred because there are many people now who are asking, you know, where are their Bitcoin? Where is my money?

FRANCIS: What do you think needs to be done with Bitcoin? I mean, you think it needs more transparency? Do you think it needs more regulation? I mean, what is the answer in your mind?

COTNEY: Well, you know, when I talked to financial institutions, when I talk to consumers, when I talk to businesses, they all want a payment system that is more secure, more real time and less costly. And for the defenders of Bitcoin, they say that this answers many of those. And to that end, state regulators from around the country through the conference of state bank supervisors, we formed a task force to look at these emerging payment issues as well as some of the legacy payments to determine whether this should be further regulated and how they should be regulated. And to folks within the Bitcoin world, many of them even say that to the extent that this can become a more regulated type of transaction that will add to consumer confidence.

FRANCIS: But I guess, I mean, consumer confidence, the whole point of Bitcoin, what makes people feel confident about it is that they want the government out of their business. And inherent to that is a lot of risk and I feel like people who invest and transact in Bitcoin understand there is a risk and it is worth it to them because they don't want the government involve and snooping into what they're doing. What is wrong with that?

COTNEY: Well, there's nothing wrong or illegal per see of this Bitcoin network. But it is important for consumers to know that this is risky, this is not an FDIC insured type of deposit activity.

FRANCIS: But you don't think they know that? I mean, would that enough to satisfy if they said this is very risky. It is not backed. It is not insured. You know, the government is not guaranteeing anything that is going on here, buyer beware. Would that satisfy you if there was that disclosure for every transaction?

COTNEY: Well, and again, disclosure is probably one of the things that we will be looking at to determine what information do consumers need to make some type of informed decision? And if they feel a transaction that may not be backed by any type deposit insurance that may have less protection than that may be the way we go. But we just need to get further information on the best way to ensure that consumers have the information they need.

FRANCIS: Commissioner David Cotney, thanks so much for joining us. We appreciate your time.

COTNEY: Thanks for having me.

FRANCIS: That is all we have got for now. I hope that you are making money today. Tune in tomorrow for my interview with Florida governor Rick Scott. He is making Florida hotbed for startups bringing jobs to the state. That is tomorrow at 2:00 p.m.

Countdown though with Liz Claman starts right now.

END
