urn:contentItem:60BN-Y6C1-JCSC-J1PH-00000-00Stock market live updates: Dow futures jump 200 points, vaccine hopes, Big Tech higher2020-07-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisNEWSStock market live updates: Dow futures jump 200 points, vaccine hopes, Big Tech higher

This is CNBC's live blog covering the latest market-moving news. Here's what's happening. Tesla shares up 7% in premarket trading Tesla shares gained nearly 7% during premarket trading on Monday after the automaker said it will cut the starting price of it... This is CNBC's live blog...

This is CNBC's live blog covering the latest market-moving news. Here's what's happening. Tesla shares up 7% in premarket trading Tesla shares gained nearly 7% during premarket trading on Monday after the automaker said it will cut the starting price of it...

This is CNBC's live blog covering the latest market-moving news. Here's what's happening. Tesla shares up 7% in premarket trading Tesla shares gained nearly 7% during premarket trading on Monday after the automaker said it will cut the starting price of its Model Y SUV by $3,000. The move follows price cuts for the company's Model 3, Model X and Model S. Shares of the Elon Musk-led company have gained more than 250% this year, pushing the electric vehicle maker's market value to $286 billion. The stock was set to open at an all-time high on Monday, after closing at a record during Friday's trading session. – Pippa Stevens Analog Devices buying Maxim Integrated in a deal worth nearly $21 billion Semiconductor company Analog Devices said Monday that it will acquire Maxim Integrated for $20.91 billion in stock. In the deal, which is expected to close next summer, Analog Shareholders will own 69% of the combined company, with Maxim shareholders holding the rest. Shares of Analog Devices jumped more than 2% during premarket trading on Monday, while Maxim was up 19%. – Pippa Stevens Coronavirus vaccines get 'fast track' status from FDA Shares of Pfizer jumped around 3% during premarket trading on Monday while BioNTech shares gained 8% after the companies were granted "fast track" status by the FDA for their work on potential Covid-19 vaccines. "The FDA's decision to grant these two COVID-19 vaccine candidates Fast Track designation signifies an important milestone in the efforts to develop a safe and effective vaccine against SARS-CoV-2," said Peter Honig, Senior Vice President of Global Regulatory Affairs at Pfizer, in a statement. "We look forward to continue working closely with the FDA throughout the clinical development of this program, Project Lightspeed, to evaluate the safety and efficacy of these vaccine candidates." - Pippa Stevens Futures higher despite record increase in Covid-19 cases Stock index futures rose on Monday despite a record jump in Covid-19 cases over the weekend. Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 223 points, or 0.8%. The move implied an increase of 244 points at Monday's open. S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq-100 futures each rose about 1%. The move higher comes even as Florida reported 15,299 new cases on Sunday , the highest single-day total for a U.S. state. The Dow and the S&P 500 are coming off their second straight week of gains, while the Nasdaq Composite is coming off its third consecutive higher week. The tech-heavy index closed at a record high on Friday, fueled by gains in names including Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Alphabet. - Pippa Stevens

urn:contentItem:60C7-D5N1-F07F-843N-00000-00Stock market live updates: Dow rises a 4th day, but Amazon weak, Goldman off highs2020-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:11ZLexisNexisNEWSStock market live updates: Dow rises a 4th day, but Amazon weak, Goldman off highs

This is CNBC's live blog covering the latest market-moving news. Follow along below. Stocks cut gains as Big Tech lags The major U.S. stock averages were off their highs in late-morning trading as some of the big tech companies underperformed. The Dow , wh... This is CNBC's live blog covering the latest market-moving news. Follow along below....

This is CNBC's live blog covering the latest market-moving news. Follow along below. Stocks cut gains as Big Tech lags The major U.S. stock averages were off their highs in late-morning trading as some of the big tech companies underperformed. The Dow , wh...

This is CNBC's live blog covering the latest market-moving news. Follow along below. Stocks cut gains as Big Tech lags The major U.S. stock averages were off their highs in late-morning trading as some of the big tech companies underperformed. The Dow , which popped more than 400 points earlier, was up 243 points. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were up 0.8% and 0.3%, respectively. Amazon slid more than 2% while Netflix dropped 1.8%. Alphabet shares dipped 0.6%. Facebook, Microsoft and Apple were up marginally, however. — Fred Imbert Shares of Goldman Sachs off its high Goldman Sachs last traded up 1.3% on Wednesday, coming off its earlier gains of 5.5%. The move lower came after Goldman CEO David Solomon said that trading activity had cooled off in recent weeks after a spike during the second quarter. "We've not seen the same level of activity over the course of the last five or six weeks" he said. The bank said its second-quarter bond trading revenue surged almost 150% to $4.24 billion , and equities trading revenue rose 46% to $2.94 billion. — Yun Li, Hugh Son Morgan Stanley raises price target on Netflix to $575 from $485 Morgan Stanley reiterated its overweight rating on Wednesday morning on Netflix and said that "scale is a strategic advantage" for the streaming giant. The firm raised its price target on the stock to $575 from $485. "Beyond a pull-forward of net additions from consumers being stuck at home will be the combined structural benefits from 1) greater scale and all the operational and financial benefits that brings, 2) an acceleration in engagement growth even in its most mature markets, and 3) pressure on its primary competition for audience time - incumbent TV broadcasters around the world," analyst Benjamin Swinburne said. The company will report second-quarter earnings on Thursday after the bell. Shares of the company are down 5% this week. — Michael Bloom Bank of America expects fundamentals to drive Apple stock higher Bank of American raised its price target on Apple to $410 from $390 on Wednesday morning and said it sees the stock continue on its upward trajectory. "While near term data points are getting more constructive, we also think positioning has a significant role in the near term price action,"analyst Wamsi Mohan said. "We think that investors are viewing AAPL as (1) a liquid investment to weather an uncertain environment, (2) a tech "story" stock with a catalyst of 5G, (3) a large cap tech name relatively less exposed to the regulatory risks (including recent EU tax related litigation win), (4) a beneficiary of passive inflows, and (5) an alternative to low rates," he said. Apple stock is up 3% this week.— Michael Bloom Travel stocks soaring after vaccine news Investors bought travel stocks on Wednesday morning amid renewed optimism for a Covid-19 vaccine. TripAdvisor and Expedia surged 9.4% and 7.8%, respectively, while hotel stock Hilton jumped 6.2%. Casino stocks climbed as well, with MGM Resorts jumping nearly 8%. — Jesse Pound Dow jumps more than 300 points at the open The U.S. market opened sharply higher, with the Dow rising roughly 358 points, or 1.3%, in the opening minutes. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 rose 1.1% and 0.8%, respectively. — Jesse Pound Bank stocks climb after Goldman results Shares of major U.S. banks rose in premarket trading Wednesday on the heels of Goldman's blowout second-quarter results and positive vaccine news from Moderna. Shares of Goldman gained 6%, while Morgan Stanley rose 4.5%. Citigroup , JPMorgan and Wells Fargo , which have already reported their earnings, also moved higher. — Jesse Pound Here are Wednesday's biggest analyst calls of the day: Apple, Moderna, Western Digital, Gap, & more RBC upgraded Gap to outperform from sector perform. Evercore ISI initiated Boston Beer as outperform. Bernstein initiated Western Digital as outperform. Evercore ISI upgraded Wells Fargo to outperform from in-line. JPMorgan downgraded American Express to underweight from neutral. Piper Sandler raised its price target on Moderna to $134 from $100. Needham raised its price target on Apple to $450 from $350. PRO subscribers can read more here . — Michael Bloom Moderna vaccine data 'impresses' Wall Street Goldman said in a note that the data released by Moderna about its vaccine candidate 'impresses' and pointed out that the druge, by one measure, produced a stronger immunity response after 57 days than a sample of patients who had Covid-19. Piper Sandler analysts was also encouraged by the data and raised its price target to $134 per share from $100. The firm said in a note that "based on an assumed price of $75, we could see ~$18 billion in ... revenues" from the vaccine. — Jesse Pound Goldman moving higher after earnings beat Shares of Goldman Sachs rose 4% after strong trading results fueled a better-than-expected second quarter. The bank earned $6.26 a share in the second quarter on revenue of $13.3 billion, which was 41% more than a year ago and Goldman's second-highest quarterly revenue on record. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of $3.78 per share and $9.75 billion of revenue, according to Refinitiv. — Hugh Son, Jesse Pound Reopening stocks surge following vaccine news Shares of embattled airlines and cruise operators jumped in premarket trading as positive results from vaccine trials fed investor optimism about an economic recovery. Shares of American Airlines and United Airlines both surged more than 8%, as did Royal Caribbean and Carnival . — Jesse Pound Market rises following Moderna vaccine data release Positive data from trials of a Covid-19 vaccine candidate from Moderna boosted the market, with the Dow futures up 500 points. Shares of Moderna jumped 18% in premarket trading. The company said on Tuesday night that its drug produced neutralizing antibodies in all 45 patients during an early stage trial . Going by the move in the futures, the S&P 500 will likely go back into the green for 2020. It was down 1% for the year heading into Wednesday. — Jesse Pound

urn:contentItem:5WN7-4001-JCMN-Y1BB-00000-00Stock Market News for Jul 25, 20192019-07-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisStock Market News for Jul 25, 2019Zacks Equity Research

Jul 25, 2019( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) The broader S...00 and tech-heavy Nasdaq reached record highs on Wednesday, riding a rally in semiconductor stocks. Upbeat earnings results and a raised guidance by Teradyne and Texas Instruments confirm that the global slowdown in microchip demand won't be there as long as apprehended. Chip stocks scaled north and touched record highs amid trade war fears. At the same time, investors shrugged of regulatory concerns over Big Tech.

The Dow Jones, however, failed to keep up and posted moderate losses after Boeing and Caterpillar announced discouraging earnings results.The S...00 closed at an all-time high of 3,019.56, after gaining 0.5% on Jul 24. The Nasdaq Composite followed suit, recording a new high of 8,321.50, having banked 0.9%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI) disappointed, shedding 0.3%to close at 27,269.97. The fear-gauge CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) decreased 2% to close at 12.36. Lastly, advancers outnumbered decliners on the NYSE by a 2.08-to-1 ratio.Chip Stocks Rally on Strong Sectoral Earnings So FarJul 24 was a great day for chip-related stocks. Semiconductor companies noted record highs in their stock prices after Texas Instruments Inc.TXN[1] and Teradyne Inc.TER[2] announced their second-quarter earnings. In fact, The PHLX Semiconductor Index (SOX) climbed 3.1% to reach 1,622.02, registering a fresh high since April 24.Texas Instruments reported Q2 earnings of $1.36 per share, which significantly surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.21.The chip maker's revenues of $3.668 billion beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $3.605 billion as well. The company's advancement in product portfolio across its Analog and Embedded Processing segments, capable manufacturing strategies and efficient capital allocation in key areas remain leading factors in its growth.Teradyne's Q2 earnings of 66 cents per share beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 4 cents as well. The company generated $564 million in revenues which easily outpaced the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $538 million. Teradyne's impressive revenues were boosted by growing demand for the System Test business. In addition, rise in 5G infrastructure, networking and memory test spending also pushed revenues higher in the second quarter.You can see the complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here[3].Antitrust Probes into Big TechLate on Jul 23, the Justice Department revealed that its antitrust wing was reviewing if the country's largest technology firms (all FAANGs except Netflix) were participating in anticompetitive practices. Both Republicans and Democrats support the antitrust review.The news, however, did not dampen investor spirit during Wednesday's trading session, as they felt hopeful of a positive outcome from next week's U.S.-China trade talks.Disappointing Q2 Earnings for Boeing and CaterpillarLastly, Dow' lackluster performance on Jul 24 is largely the outcome of The Boeing CompanyBA[4] and Caterpillar Inc.'s CAT[5] quarterly earnings, which failed to meet analyst expectations.While Boeing's earnings of $2.92 per share easily beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.85, its revenues of $15.75 billion for Q2 missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 12.40%. The company's underperformance in the second quarter is largely due to a drop in its commercial airplanes deliveries and the grounding of its 737 Max aircrafts after two fatal crashes.Caterpillar disappointed in both earnings and revenues. Its earnings per share of $2.83 fell behind the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $3.12. Secondly, Caterpillar's revenues for Q2, reported at $14.4 billion missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $14.5 billion as well. The heavy machinery manufacturer suffered losses because of rise in material costs (that comprised of tariffs) and a decline in Chinese demand.Both Boeing and Caterpillar carry a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).Economic DataNew home sales in the United States climbed in June, making the first move up in three months. On Jul 24, the Commerce Department noted that new home sales rebounded 7% in June to an annual rate of 646,000 units (seasonally adjusted).Stocks That Made HeadlinesEquifax Beats Q2 Earnings Estimates, Cuts '19 EPS View[6]Equifax Inc.EFX[7] reported solid second-quarter 2019 results, wherein the company's earnings and revenues surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate. (Read more[8])Varian Earnings and Revenues Surpass Estimates in Q3[9]Varian Medical Systems, Inc.'s VAR[10] third-quarter fiscal 2019 adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $1.32 beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.14. Adjusted EPS also surged 26.9% year over year. (Read more[11])This Could Be the Fastest Way to Grow Wealth in 2019Research indicates one sector is poised to deliver a crop of the best-performing stocks you'll find anywhere in the market. Breaking news in this space frequently creates quick double- and triple-digit profit opportunities.These companies are changing the world - and owning their stocks could transform your portfolio in 2019 and beyond. Recent trades from this sector have generated +98%, +119% and +164% gains in as little as 1 month.Click here to see these breakthrough stocks now >>[12]Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report[13] Equifax, Inc. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WM2-VYT1-DYTD-900D-00000-00Stock Market Pulls Back As Netflix Chilled, Microsoft Beats Facebook Libra Attacked, Chips Hot: Weekly Review2019-07-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisNEWSStock Market Pulls Back As Netflix Chilled, Microsoft Beats Facebook Libra Attacked, Chips Hot: Weekly ReviewIBD STAFF

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/stock-netflix-05-company.jpg

The stock market hit fresh record highs, pulled back amid China trade concerns and weak earnings from Netflix and CSX. JPMorgan Chase and several banks topped earnings views, though net interest margins are a concern. Microsoft, ASML and CrowdStrike delivered strong results. Amazon.com touted a successful Amazon Prime Day, but shares pulled back. Facebook Libra faced critics on Capitol Hill.

Stock Market Holds Near Highs

The stock market pulled back from record highs on some weak earnings reports and China trade concerns. The major indexes rebounded on Fed officials hinting at bigger rate cuts, but policymakers walked back those remarks. Earnings from Microsoft, some chipmakers and others also helped. Ultimately, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite fell more than 1%, their worst weekly losses since late May. The Dow slid 0.6%.

Netflix Dives On Big Subscriber Miss

The internet TV network added 2.7 million streaming subscribers in the June quarter, vs. its target for 5 million. In the U.S., it lost 126,000 subscribers when it expected to add 300,000. Netflix blamed recent price hikes and a lighter content release slate for the miss. It earned 60 cents a share, down 29%, on sales of $4.92 billion, up 26%, both beating. Netflix shares plunged nearly 16% for the week.

Microsoft Shows Cloud Strength

Microsoft earnings rose 21% as fiscal Q4 revenue grew 12% to $33.72 billion. Cloud-related revenue rocketed 39% to $11 billion, helped by Azure infrastructure services and Office 365 software. The Dow Jones software stock hit a record high Friday but then slash gains.

ASML, TSMC Cheer Chip Investors

Chip gear maker ASML and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing kicked off the second-quarter earnings season with better-than-expected reports. Dutch-based ASML and Taiwanese chip foundry TSMC topped EPS views. TSMC said the chip industry has bottomed. Chip stocks jumped.

Chipmaker Broadcom reportedly has broken off talks to buy cybersecurity software maker Symantec.

CrowdStrike Busts Higher

CrowdStrike met views for an adjusted loss while revenue shot up 103% to $96 million, edging past views. The cybersecurity IPO also raised guidance for the current quarter and 2019. Shares soared 15% Friday. Meanwhile, online pet food retailer Chewy reported a 45% revenue gain to $1.1 billion. It showed an adjusted loss of 8 cents. Chewy reversed lower Friday, closing down 6.5%.

Boeing 737 Max To Return In Q4

The Dow Jones aerospace giant expects the Boeing 737 Max to return to service in the fourth quarter. That eases concerns that the 737 Max would remain grounded into next year, though Boeing has been overly optimistic about the jet's return before. Boeing will book an after-tax charge of $4.9 billion in Q2 due to estimated 737 Max. Boeing stock rallied Friday.

Amazon Prime Day

Amazon said it sold more than 175 million items during this year's Prime Day shopping event, more than its sales for the past Black Friday and Cyber Monday combined. Amazon did not provide an actual sales figure, though an analyst from Baird estimated sales of about $6 billion. The event lasted 48 hours, vs. 36 hours for Amazon Prime Day last year. Amazon stock edged lower to just above a buy point.

Facebook Libra Under Fire

Facebook and hopes for its Libra cryptocurrency took a weeklong battering in two days of House and Senate hearings, as well as from Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and European financial regulators.

Following strongly critical tweets from President Trump the prior week and concerns raised by Fed chief Jerome Powell, Mnuchin highlighted money laundering and national security concerns. He said the Trump administration was "not comfortable" with Facebook's plan to launch a digital payment network.

Members of Congress from both parties flatly said they didn't trust Facebook to manage a new currency after years of criticism about violating users' privacy. Rep. Brad Sherman, D-Calif., called Libra "a godsend to drug dealers and tax evaders." House members also raised concern that Libra, which would track a basket of major currencies, could diminish the dollar's stature.

Meanwhile, French finance minister Bruno Le Maire said that "action is needed urgently" to guard against Libra's threat to national sovereignty.

The Facebook Libra cryptocurrency hearings came amid a House hearing on Big Tech antitrust concerns, with lawmakers going after Facebook, Amazon, Google parent Alphabet and Apple.

Rail Earnings Go North, South

It was a mixed week for rail stocks, with Union Pacific stock rallying after results topped views and Canadian Pacific Railway also powering higher after besting Wall Street earnings estimates. However, CSX stock gapped down on weak earnings as well as revenue guidance. Kansas City Southern reported better-than-expected earnings, lifting shares.

Bank Earnings See Margin Squeeze

Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase trimmed their full-year forecasts for net-interest income, as the prospect of interest-rate cuts from the Fed, along with lower Treasury yields, tempered banks' outlooks. Tame trading and falling rates hit Citigroup results. Lower rates and higher deposit costs hurt net interest income at Wells Fargo, which forecast higher expenses related to investments in risk management. Costs related to Goldman Sachs' newer, nontrading businesses weighed on its results. Morgan Stanley earnings beat, with gains in wealth management counterbalancing weak trading results.

IBM Breaks Out On Earnings

IBM reported adjusted earnings of $3.17, beating by a dime. The 3% year-over-year gain followed two straight declines. Revenue fell 4%, down for the fourth straight quarter. But IBM shares jumped into a buy zone.

UnitedHealth Beats, But Revenue Guidance Light

The nation's largest insurer reported 10% earnings per share growth, comfortably above estimates, while 8% revenue growth was roughly in line. But UnitedHealth gave revenue guidance that was just below the consensus. Shares fell Thursday after running up in the past three months.

UnitedHealth dodged a bullet earlier this month as the Trump administration shelved its drug rebate rule that could have dented profits at its OptumRx prescription benefit management unit. But the post-2020 outlook for the managed care group is clouded by Democrats' Medicare for All plans.

Mid-U.S. Hubs Lift United Airlines

United Airlines beat Q2 estimates and raised the low end of its full-year profit forecast. The company also approved a $3 billion stock buyback program. The airline said its plans to connect more flights to and from its mid-Continent airport hubs helped margins and profits.

EBay EPS Growth Accelerates

EBay reported 28% EPS growth, above views and the 5th straight quarter of accelerating gains. Revenue rose just 2% to $2.7 billion, above estimates. Gross merchandise volume of $22.6 billion was down 4%. Active buyers on eBay rose 4%. Shares reclaimed a buy point late in the week.

Retail Sales Solid

June retail sales rose 0.4% with or without autos, both well above views. The Empire and Philly Fed manufacturing index were much better than expected for July. June housing starts fell more than expected while building permits tumbled to their lowest level in more than two years.

Drug Earnings

Johnson & Johnson topped Q2 views, but the Dow Jones stock fell after keeping full-year EPS targets. Abbott Laboratories beat profit views with in-line sales, sending shares soaring. Novartis topped earnings forecasts with a 14% rise while sales rose 4% to $11.76 billion, in line. The Swiss drug giant, which raised some full-year targets spiked Thursday, nearly topping its July 2015 record high.

Online Brokers Results Mixed

Charles Schwab earnings rose 10%, meeting views, as revenue climbed to $2.68 billion. Interactive Brokers missed with a 25% EPS drop and revenue falling to $213 million. E-Trade Financial beat on earnings but missed on sales. Online brokers have suffered from trading fee cuts, roboadvisor competition and lower interest rates. Schwab is reportedly in talks to buy parts of USAA's businesses to expand its push into financial advice.

News In Brief

Auto lending specialist Ally Financial charged to a record high after posting better-than-expected Q2 earnings.

Blue Apron jumped 35.5% Tuesday after the meal-kit deliverer said it would introduce recipes featuring products from meat-alternative maker Beyond Meat. Shares of Blue Apron later gave up most of those gains. Tim Hortons, the Canadian coffee and doughnut shop owned by Restaurant Brands, expanded Beyond Meat products to lunch and dinner after a successful breakfast test.

Skechers earnings shot up 69% while revenue rose 11% to $1.259 billion, topping sales views for the first time in five quarters. The footwear maker gave upbeat Q3 guidance. Shares soared Friday.

Dover grew EPS 20% to $1.56, beating by a penny, and sales 1% to $1.81 billion, a modest miss. Dover tightened 2019 guidance to the upper end of its previous range.

Cintas reported a 17% jump in EPS to $2.07 on revenue of $1.79 billion. The uniform rental and office supplies company beat views and gave strong 2020 guidance. The stock hit a record high.

Intuitive Surgical earnings rose 18% to $3.25 a share, topping Q2 views. Revenue climbed 21% to $1.01 billion. Shares fell modestly Friday after testing a buy point.

American Express fell Friday even though the credit-card giant topped Q2 views and reaffirmed its full-year outlook. Management said the economy is growing at a steady but modest pace.

urn:contentItem:5Y6V-X2C1-DYTD-9295-00000-00Stock Market Rally Keeps Hitting Highs; Nvidia, Shopify, Alibaba, Dexcom, Applied Materials In Focus: Weekly Review2020-02-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisNEWSStock Market Rally Keeps Hitting Highs; Nvidia, Shopify, Alibaba, Dexcom, Applied Materials In Focus: Weekly ReviewIBD STAFF

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/stock-NYSE-exterior-03-adobe.jpg

The stock market rally shrugged off a spike in China coronavirus cases and an expanded Big Tech probe, with the Dow Jones, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite all hitting record highs. Nvidia, Applied Materials and Dexcom were among the big earnings winners. So was Shopify, along with several business and database names. But cybersecurity stocks and Cisco Systems were big losers. Alibaba earnings were strong, with shares finding key support.

Stock Market Rally Hits Highs

The Nasdaq composite rose 2.2% for the week, the S&P 500 index 1.6% and the Dow Jones 1%, all hitting record highs. The stock market rally shrugged off an expanded FTC Big Tech probe as well as a big increase in reported China coronavirus cases. Nvidia and Applied Materials leapt on earnings, leading a strong week for chip stocks, while Shopify headlined several software winners. But several cybersecurity stocks struggled. Dexcom skyrocketed. Alibaba delivered strong earnings, but said the coronavirus outbreak is a "black swan" event.

FTC Expands Big Tech Probe

The FTC broadened its antitrust probe of past Big Tech acquisitions beyond big deals, like Facebook acquiring Instagram. Now the FTC is looking at the scores of small fish scooped up by the likes of Amazon, Apple, Google-parent Alphabet and Microsoft over the past decade.

Although such deals didn't exceed thresholds that require pre-merger notification to antitrust regulators, the FTC plans to examine the transactions for anticompetitive behavior. The potential concern is that Big Tech companies buy startups to nip competition in the bud, before it can bloom. The giant fishing expedition could produce investigative leads or tighten scrutiny of small deals in the future. That might complicate a key venture-capital exit channel.

The Big Techs pared gains or reversed lower Tuesday but generally rose for the week.

Nvidia Crushes Q4 Targets

The graphics chipmaker reported a 136% EPS gain while sales jumped 41% to $3.11 billion, both easily beating. Nvidia earnings and sales had declined for four straight quarters. Nvidia also guided higher for Q1. Chip equipment maker Applied Materials reported a 21% EPS gain and an 11% sales rise to $4.16 billion, ending several quarters of declines. The chip equipment giant guided higher. Lattice Semiconductor topped views, while Diodes results were mixed.

Roku Adds 4.6 Million Users

Streaming video platform Roku finished Q4 with 36.9 million active accounts, up 4.6 million from the third quarter. That fueled better-than-expected advertising revenue in the December quarter. Roku lost 13 cents a share on sales of $411.2 million in Q4, better than views. Roku earnings have turned to losses as the company invests heavily in international expansion and its advertising-based video-on-demand business model. Shares gapped higher Friday but reversed lower in ugly fashion.

Alibaba Earnings Strong

Alibaba earnings rose 47% as revenue climbed 36% to $23.2 billion, both beating Q4 views. The Chinese e-commerce giant said that the coronavirus presents "near term" challenges to Alibaba's businesses. Shares dipped after earnings amid a spike in China virus cases, but rose slightly for the week.

Business Software

Shopify advanced after Q4 EPS jumped 59%, defying forecasts for a decline. Revenue leapt 47% to $505.2 million, easily beating. The e-commerce software maker also guided 2020 revenue targets slightly higher amid higher investments.

RingCentral earnings edged lower while revenue grew 34% to $253 million, both topping. The communications software maker guided Q1 sales estimates slightly higher. Shares leapt.

Akamai Technologies said adjusted earnings rose 15% while revenue climbed 8% to $772 million, both beating. Security product revenue jumped 29% to $238 million, also topping. Akamai stock popped.

HubSpot reported that EPS climbed 22% as revenue grew 29% to $186.2 million. The sales and marketing software maker gave upbeat 2020 revenue guidance but weak EPS targets on increased hiring and the dilutive impact of an acquisition. HubSpot stock broke out.

Avalara lost 10 cents a share, one cent worse than expected. Revenue climbed 40% to $107.63 million, modestly beating. The sales tax automation software maker guided slightly higher on revenue. Shares fell back on earnings to around a buy point.

Datadog earned 3 cents a share as revenue soared 85% to $113.6 million vs. views for a small loss and a $102.4 million in sales. The company guided higher for Q1 and 2020, though it plans to up spending on R&D and sales and marketing. Shares fell Friday in a wild session after hitting a record high earlier in the week.

Alteryx earnings came in at 64 cents a share vs. a 1-cent loss a year earlier. Revenue surged 75.5% to $156.45 million, marking the third straight quarter of accelerating growth. Both easily beat views. The database software maker gave somewhat mixed guidance. But shares soared.

Cadence Edges Q4 Views

Chip design software maker Cadence Design Systems edged analyst estimates for the fourth quarter but disappointed with its first-quarter earnings outlook. The company earned an adjusted 54 cents a share, up 4%, on sales of $600 million, up 5%, in the December quarter. Wall Street expected EPS of 53 cents on sales of $595 million. It was the company's slowest earnings growth in over five years. And it was the firm's slowest sales growth in three years. For the current quarter, Cadence expects to earn an adjusted 54 cents a share on sales of $615 million. Analysts were looking for 57 cents in EPS on $609 million in sales.

Cybersecurity Software

CyberArk earnings rose 9% while Q4 revenue climbed 19% to $129.7 million, both beating. But CyberArk guided low on Q1 EPS and sales and for full-year EPS. Rapid7 reported a Q4 profit, defying views for a loss, while revenue grew 33% to $91.7 million. But its outlook for annual recurring revenue disappointed. Mimecast reported fiscal Q3 profit up 56% while revenue climbed 26% to $110.2 million, both modestly beating. Revenue guidance for the upcoming fiscal 2021 was in line. Qualys said Q4 EPS rose 25%, topping estimates, while revenue climbed 14% to $84.7 million, meeting expectations. For the March quarter, Qualys guided EPS targets up and revenue in line.

CyberArk stock, Rapid7 and Mimecast sold off, while Qualys rose modestly for the week.

Dexcom Earnings Double

Dexcom handily beat fourth-quarter expectations with adjusted profit surging 105% as sales leapt 37% to $462.8 million. The continuous blood sugar monitoring device maker blasted higher on Friday. Insulet and Tandem Diabetes also rose Friday and were solid winners for the week.

Fed Rate Cut Odds Rise

Despite the risk that China's coronavirus outbreak could take a turn for the worse and slow U.S. economic growth, Fed Chair Jerome Powell told Congress this week that it would take a "sharp tightening" in financial conditions — meaning lower stock prices and a widening of credit spreads — or clear evidence of an economic toll to provoke a rate cut. Still, financial markets see nearly 60% odds of a Fed rate cut as early as July. Those odds rose slightly after Friday's retail sales report came in a bit spotty. The data matched forecasts of a 0.3% rise, both overall and excluding autos. But core sales were flat, after a downwardly revised 0.3% gain in December.

Cisco Earnings

Cisco Systems reported that fiscal Q2 adjusted earnings rose 5% as revenue fell 4% to $12 billion, both topping. But product revenue fell 6% to $8.67 billion, worse than expected. The networking giant guided in line for the current Q3. The Dow Jones tech giant fell. Arista Networks reported that Q4 earnings rose 2% as revenue fell 7% to $552.5 million, both beating lowered views. The network gear maker acquired Big Switch Networks for undisclosed terms. Arista declined to issue 2020 guidance citing low visibility on spending by internet companies on hyperscale data centers. Arista stock tumbled.

Tempur Sealy Wakes Up On Earnings

Tempur Sealy reported that fourth-quarter earnings jumped 52%, the best gain in years. Sales climbed 29% to $871.3 million, the seventh straight quarter of accelerating growth. The mattress maker also increased its stock buyback program by more than $190 million to $300 million. Shares jumped, hitting a record high. Shares have run up for more than a year as Tempur Sealy patched up a legal dispute with large customer Mattress Firm and focused on higher-end mattresses less prone to competition.

Burlington Stores Breaks Out

Burlington Stores broke out to a record high after raising forecasts for the just-ended fiscal Q4, above analyst views. The off-price retailer said earnings per share likely came in at $3.21-$3.23, with sales up 10.5%. Burlington also boosted its same-store sales outlook. Off-price rivals Ross Stores and TJX also rose.

Generac Stock Powers To High

Generac unexpectedly reported a modest earnings gain in Q4. Wildfires and power shut-offs due to other natural disasters have been stoking demand for the generator maker's products. Analysts believe the firm has solid prospects for ongoing revenue upside. Shares jumped to a new high, though most of the week's gains came on news that Generac will be added to the S&P 400.

Global Payments Earnings Growth Accelerate

The payments firm reported 22% EPS growth, the second straight quarter of accelerating growth. Global Payments guided low on 2020 but still sees accelerating constant-currency organic revenue growth in the second half of the year, as well as elevating synergy expectations from its Total System Services merger. Shares rose modestly to a new high. Meanwhile, Euronet Worldwide plunged after serving up mixed earnings and delivering poor guidance.

Coronavirus Forces Hotel Closures

Hotel giant Hilton Worldwide said the coronavirus outbreak in China had forced it to close around 150 hotels there, and it tempered growth expectations as the health crisis spreads to other nations and halts business and travel. Wyndham Hotels & Resorts said it had closed around 70% of its hotels in China. Hilton's fourth-quarter results topped estimates. Wyndham's earnings matched views as sales topped. Hilton stock rose from its 50-day line as Wyndham hit resistance at that level.

News In Review

Restaurant Brands International — the parent of Burger King, Tim Hortons and Popeyes Louisiana Kitchen — reported fourth-quarter results that beat expectations, boosted by the enduring popularity of Popeyes' chicken sandwich.

Tradeweb Markets earnings rose 44%, topping views. Sales growth slowed to 10%. The electronic bond trading site rose for the week, flirting with a buy point.

XPO Logistics reported that EPS jumped 42%, beating views, while revenue dipped 6% to $4.14 billion, a miss. XPO stock fell on earnings but rose for the week. Earlier this year, XPO said it might sell one or more units, to become a trucking pure play.

Zoetis reported adjusted earnings of 92 cents per share on $1.67 billion in sales. On a year-over-year basis, Zoetis earnings jumped 16% and sales increased 7%. Both metrics topped expectations.

Zebra Technologies, a maker of enterprise asset-tracking systems, missed Wall Street's targets for the fourth quarter and gave soft sales guidance for 2020. It earned an adjusted $3.56 a share on sales of $1.19 billion in the December quarter. Analysts expected $3.65 EPS on revenue of $1.2 billion.

Mastercard rose after news that it won approval to set up a bank card clearing business in China. While it will need further approvals once preparations are complete, it means it could gain access to the totalitarian state's $27 trillion payments market.

Under Armour plunged almost 20% on mixed Q4 results and weak 2020 guidance. The sportswear maker also warned of the impact that coronavirus could have on sales.

Chegg topped Q4 estimates and gave strong forecasts. But shares of the education technology leader, which broke out just before earnings, plunged after results.

MercadoLibre reported fourth-quarter results that beat Wall Street estimates on revenue but fell short on earnings. Revenue jumped 58% to $674.3 million, with a loss of $1.11 per share. The Latin American e-commerce giant initially tumbled on earnings but rebounded to record highs.

urn:contentItem:3TDD-RWX0-009B-G1FV-00000-00Stock Market Soars; Lockheed Martin Buys Northrop Grumman; Mississippi Makes Deal With Tobacco Company1997-07-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE WITH LOU DOBBS 19:00 pm ETNews; BusinessSHOW97070300V19Stock Market Soars; Lockheed Martin Buys Northrop Grumman; Mississippi Makes Deal With Tobacco CompanyJan Hopkins, Bill Dorman, Fred Katayama, James Q. Wilson, Bill Tucker

The stock market soared to new records in a shortened holiday session. Lockheed Martin is buying Northrop Grumman and the total value of the deal is $11 billion in stock and debt. The tobacco industry today agreed to pay Mississippi $3.6 billion. The fireworks industry is booming.

JAN HOPKINS, CNN ANCHOR: A hundred six billion dollars in new wealth created by today's record-setting Wall Street rally. Complete coverage tonight of the runup and the jobs report that triggered it. Plus, a view from the buy side. My guest, mutual fund manager Frank Cappiello. And a mammoth defense deal shatters the pre-holiday calm on the street. Lockheed Martin swallowing Northrop Grumman in an $11- billion buyout. And fireworks sales are heating up ahead of the 4th. We'll take a closer look at this $400-million not-always-legal business.

ANNOUNCER (voice-over): Live from the financial capital of the world, New York City, this is MONEYLINE WITH LOU DOBBS. Sitting in tonight, Jan Hopkins.

HOPKINS: Good evening. Fireworks on Wall Street today as the stock market soared to new records in a shortened pre-Independence Day session. A weaker-than-expected jobs report sending stocks and bonds into the stratosphere. The Dow Industrials tonight flirting with 7,900, rallying 100 points to 7,895.81, its 29th record of the year. For the week, the Dow is up 208 points. Today's blue-chip gains led by American Express as lower interest boosted financial shares. Proctor & Gamble up 2-3/8. General Electric up more than $1.75. AlliedSignal climbed nearly $1.50. And IBM added 1-3/8.

Most big tech names gained, helping the NASDAQ post its 19th record this year. after a gain of 12 points. The bond market also had a stellar pre-holiday session. Thirty-year issue gaining 1-1/8 points. The yield dropping to 6.61 percent. That is a four-and-a- half-month low.

Investor euphoria triggered this morning by the release of the June jobs report offering solid evidence of slowing growth. Unemployment rose slightly, job creation slowed, and wages stayed in check. Bill Dorman is in Washington tonight with more on the report that sparked the buying binge -- Bill?

BILL DORMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Jan, June's unemployment report is the government's first statistical look at how the economy did last month and, so far, economists and the markets are excited about the outlook for the summer.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DORMAN (voice-over): June's unemployment rate came as a mild surprise. The jobless rate moved up .02 percent to 5 percent. The Labor Department says 217,000 non-farm jobs were created last month, pretty much in line with expectations for new jobs.

DAVID BLITZER, DEUTSCHE MORGAN GRENFELL: It's generally speaking a healthy number. It's a bit better than last month. It's probably a little bit below the average of the last several months, but, in general, if we create 200,000 jobs every months, this economy will be in great shape over the long haul.

DORMAN (voice-over): Markets remain focused on inflation prospects over the long haul. Bonds soared on the news, the Treasury's 30-year bond jumping more than 1 point. Stocks also welcomed the figures, the Dow Jones Industrial Average pushing ahead to new highs. A key indicator of inflation prospects, wage growth, inched up 4 cents an hour in June.

ALEXIS HERMAN, LABOR SECRETARY: We've had the modest growth in wages, and we are seeing that employers are adding jobs to their payrolls, which is really continuing to keep the economy growing at a very steady and stable place.

DORMAN (voice-over): Most economists expect to see more evidence that the economy slowed gently during the second quarter, after roaring ahead by nearly 6 percent in the first three months of the year. Expectations now are in the range of 1-1/2- to 2-percent growth in the second quarter.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

And that should be just fine with the Federal Reserve Board, which just decided to leave short-term interest rates right where they are. The Fed's next round of decision-making on interest rates is in August -- Jan?

HOPKINS: And, Bill, there will be a lot more checks in the economy between now and that meeting in August, right?

DORMAN: It's true. You have everything from the GDP figures in the second quarter to inflationary figures such as -- consumer spending's going to get a close look, also, of course, consumer prices and producer prices as well.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Bill Dorman in Washington. And another mega merger today in the rapidly consolidating defense industry. What used to be five industry giants will soon just be one company. Lockheed Martin buying Northrop Grumman. Total value of the deal $11 Billion in stock and debt. Wall Street loved the deal, pushing Northrop's shares up 24 percent. Fred Katayama has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Northrop's stock flew faster and higher than its B-2 bombers as investors welcomed Lockheed Martin's $11.6-billion buy out. Northrop rocketed more than $21, and Lockheed fell more than $4. U.S. cutbacks in defense spending after the fall of communism spurred the merger.

NORMAN AUGUSTINE, CEO, LOCKHEED MARTIN: We really had a choice then of either trying to keep 10 or 12 weak companies in the market or

consolidate, combine, and have two or three very strong companies that could compete in the world market. We were encouraged by our government to do the latter.

KATAYAMA (voice-over): Lockheed will marry its strength in satellites and aircraft, like the F-22 fighter, with Northrop's know- how in surveillance systems. Combined, the companies will boast sales of $37 billion, producing the biggest U.S. defense contractor. Lockheed is paying a hefty premium for Northrop, but analysts say $1 billion in yearly cost savings will make the deal worthwhile. This will leave the U.S. defense industry with just two other big guns, Raytheon and BoeingMcDonnell Douglas.

ROGER THRELFALL AEROSPACE ANALYST, J.P. MORGAN: We believe this is actually the end of the big guns, and we're getting the government saying, "OK. We like it. We like the cost savings, but let's just make sure we haven't gone too far."

KATAYAMA (voice-over): Two years ago, Lockheed merged with Martin Marietta, itself the result of a merger. Last year, Lockheed Martin merged with Lowell's (ph) defense unit. Northrop Grumman brought Westinghouse's defense business last year. Northrop brought Grumman in '94.

(on camera): Analysts predict the Federal Trade Commission will approve the merger since the same regulators just approved Boeing's buy out of McDonnell Douglas. Fred Katayama, CNN Financial News, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HOPKINS: The tobacco industry today agreeing to pay Mississippi $3.6 billion, guaranteeing the state its share of a proposed nationwide settlement, even if it isn't approved by Congress. State Attorney General Michael Moore said the industry will immediately pay the state $170 million and continue making payments every year to cover healthcare costs caused by smoking.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL MOORE, MISSISSIPPI ATTORNEY GENERAL: Today, Mississippi has shown this nation and shown the rest of the world that the tobacco industry will and should be held accountable for the tremendous damage they've done in this country and across this world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HOPKINS: Checking tobacco stocks, Philip Morris up 1-3/8, RJR Nabisco up 1/8, Loews gained more $2, and UST added 1/4. The year- long breakfast cereal price war is over, and consumers will be the losers. General Mills today raising prices 2.6 percent. A box of Cheerios, Wheaties, and Lucky Charms will cost up to 10 cents more now. It's the first time that General Mills has raised prices in four years.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN McMILLIN, FOOD ANALYST, PRUDENTIAL SECURITIES: They've missed earnings for the last two years. I think they're trying to fund some of the promotional efforts, and maybe it does reflect the fact that lower prices alone do not help stimulate cereal demand.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HOPKINS: Plenty of demand for General Mills stock. It gained almost $2.50 today. Other cereal companies were fortified by the move. Kellogg jumped 4. Quaker Oats added more than 75 cents.

Up next, more on today's record gains on Wall Street. My guest likens the stock market to a happy household, with Papa Bull, Mama Bull, and Baby Bull all content, but what are the chances of a change to the three bears? I'll ask fund manager Frank Cappiello right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: Hong Kong stocks taking a surprise dive in the first day of trading after the hand-over to China. The Hang Sang Index down almost 1 percent. Analysts were expecting the Chinese government would see to an auspicious start by pressuring brokers to buy, but key property stocks were slammed after Hong Kong's new leadership promised to put a lid on real-estate speculation.

Back in the U.S., gold prices today plunked to a 12-year low on news that the Australian Central Bank is selling part of its gold reserves. The price of gold has been dropping for the past year and a half, pushed downward by low inflation and a strong dollar. At the New York Commodities Exchange, gold for August delivery fell $7.10 an ounce to $325.20 an ounce.

On Wall Street, July 4th fireworks started earlier as stocks and bonds soared on the June jobs report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rocketed 100 points to a new all-time high of 7,895.81, and volume on this pre-holiday session, which closed at 1:00, 374 million shares. Advancing issues beat out decliners by a 5-to-2 margin. New York Stock Exchange Composite Index closed at a record, up about 6 points. The S&P 500 also closing at a record, up about 13 points. The Dow Transportation Index gained about 10 points, also closing at a record. Dow Utilities up almost 2 points. The NASDAQ Composite closing at a new record, up 12 points. The American Stock Exchange Index also closing at a record, up more than 4 points.

Today's rally brings the value of U.S. stocks to $9-1/2 trillion, and it leaves the Dow just 104 points shy of 8,000. My guest tonight has predicted 8,000 on the Dow by year's end. Frank Cappiello manages $1-1/2 billion. He's president of McCullough, Andrews & Cappiello, and he joins us from Washington tonight. Frank, welcome back to MONEYLINE.

FRANK CAPPIELLO, PRESIDENT, McCULLOUGH, ANDREWS & CAPPIELLO: Thank you, Jan.

HOPKINS: Are you surprised that we're this close to 8,000 at this point in the year?

CAPPIELLO: Yeah. I thought it would take much longer. So this is a happy surprise, but, you know, everything is in sync. This is an amazing economy that's reflecting an amazing stock market. You have low inflation, low interest rates, rising corporate profits and capital gains. The capital-gains tax is now a sure thing, and this means that 36 percent earned on earned income -- tax on earned income now switches down to 20 percent for investment returns, and that's going to really be an incentive to invest from here on in.

HOPKINS: When we actually get an agreement, is it possible, though, that with this capital-gains tax cut that stocks could fall initially?

CAPPIELLO: Yes. I anticipate you'd get an early, you know, flushing out of people that are anxious to get out, but I don't think it's going to be as much as the gurus anticipate. I think the incentive here is the difference between the 36 tax on earned -- 36- percent tax on earned income and, of course, the 20 percent on capital gains. That's a huge difference.

HOPKINS: Let's look forward. We're only halfway through the year. We're already almost at your year's goal. Have you changed the goal for the year?

CAPPIELLO: Yeah. You know, probably I'd be nudged up to 8,500. This is a market that is probably going to be the greatest big market of the big stock markets in this century. It's going to rival the U.S. market of the '20s and the great Japanese market of the '80s. We're setting in place here one of the great stock markets probably of all time for quite a long time. When it ends, of course, it's probably going to end ugly, but there's no sign it's going to end anytime soon.

HOPKINS: And it -- this can continue for a while, in your view.

CAPPIELLO: Absolutely. It's going to take a great shock to knock this market or derail this market and, of course, you don't see these surprises, but it's very unlikely, looking at any foreign possibility, any political possibility. Maybe a fallout from Whitewater would correct the market but not send it down to a bear market.

HOPKINS: I guess a surprise would stay a surprise, but what things are you looking at that could kind of shock things?

CAPPIELLO: Well, of course, interest rates -- I mean, the Fed -- everyone thinks the Fed is in control of rates, but, actually, you can have the stock market reflecting over time a rise in interest rates, either through the Japanese refusing to buy any more of our bonds or the dollar plunging in which case we'd have to raise rates to protect the dollar. There are all sorts of things that could raise rates without the Fed intervention, but, here again, that's very unlikely, Jan.

HOPKINS: So what should investors do in the meantime -- enjoy it, jump in, what?

CAPPIELLO: Well, if they're invested, they should enjoy it. If they're not invested, there are a lot of very attractive stocks that still haven't run with the pack. This has been a -- what we call a ready-to-run market where most of the mutual fund managers have been getting in the big stocks, but they're really ready to run because they can get out of these stocks in a hurry. The smaller stocks that are growing faster -- small caps are still very attractive.

HOPKINS: You have been saying that small caps would catch up. They really haven't yet.

CAPPIELLO: No. No.

HOPKINS: You think that's still to come?

CAPPIELLO: Yes, I do, and there are a couple of attractive ones in retailing. For example, a company by the name of Paul Harris is an attractive small stock. There are some mid cap stocks, mid cap banks, like U.S. Bank Corp. that are still reasonably priced. You know, this market is only overpriced in the big Dow super blue chips.

HOPKINS: Your funds have actually underperformed the market. The growth fund up about 12 percent for the year, and the market up almost twice that. Have you been in some of those small caps that haven't caught up yet?

CAPPIELLO: Yes. , both the emerging growth and the growth fund have had a heavy layer of small caps. They haven't worked. And we've also been very successful in technology in the past year, but, this year, the technology stocks have been so volatile, it's very, very difficult to get a long run, but, here again, I think these are the stocks that, if you're patient, are going to make money for us.

HOPKINS: Thanks very much, Frank Cappiello, the president of McCullough, Andrews & Cappiello. Thanks for joining us from Washington.

CAPPIELLO: Thank you, Jan.

HOPKINS: And coming up, an update on our special MONEYLINE report, Hazardous Harvest. We'll tell you how one state senator is addressing the controversial practice of retreating sewage sludge and using it as fertilizer.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: Tonight's MONEYLINE movers, Inso plunging nearly $9.75. That's 46 percent of its value. The software maker warning second- quarter profits will be at least 66 percent less than Wall Street expected.

Duty Free International climbing 3-5/8. London-based BAA buying the retailer for $674 million.

LSI Logic gaining 2-1/8. Several Wall Street analysts saying rumors the company is losing a significant amount of business to Toshiba are simply untrue.

Wyle Electronics jumping $6.50. German conglomerate Vaba (ph) buying the semiconductor distributor for $810 million.

MCI Communications tacking on 2-3/8. MCI's new partner, British Telecom, getting a tax break from the British government. British Telecom's ADRs adding more than $5.50.

In other corporate news, Ford Motor reporting June vehicle sales rose 4.7 percent. Increased incentive programs driving the better- than-expected results. GM and Chrysler reported declines in sales earlier this week. Ford shares gaining 1/8.

Western Resources up $1. The security firm withdrawing its takeover bid for ADT allowing Tyco International to complete its merger with ADT.

Hormel, the maker of Spam luncheon meat, taking a stand against the other kind of Spam, junk E-mail, asking bulk E-mail giant, Cyberpromotions, to stop using the trademark Spam. The request was denied.

A follow-up on our special report last week, Hazardous Harvest. We told you about the growing controversy over the government policy of recycling sewage sludge as fertilizer for farm crops. Today, here in New York, a state senator called for special state legislation that will require warning labels on any food products grown with sludge fertilizer. The proposal from Democratic State Senator David Paterson.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAVID PATERSON, MEMBER, NEW YORK STATE SENATE: The reason for this is that we want consumers to know exactly and totally any information about the products that we use. The farm fertilizers, obviously, are involved in the growing of produce, fruits and vegetables, and also dairy products that come from animals that were raised on farms that have these potentially toxic substances in the sludge.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HOPKINS: One footnote to that proposal: Similar legislation has been proposed in Congress, but the EPA has already rejected a citizen's petition calling for special labels on food grown with sludge fertilizer.

The Supreme Court just wrapped up one of its busiest sessions ever, including several landmark decisions that will affect businesses and the way of life in America. MONEYLINE Contributing Editor James Q. Wilson has reached his own verdict on which of the rulings was most significant. That's tonight's MONEYLINE focus.

JAMES Q. WILSON, CNN CONTRIBUTING EDITOR: The Supreme Court session that just ended made some significant and, on the whole, laudatory decisions. It unanimously denied President Clinton's claim that he could avoid his civil suit, and it rejected the argument that

the Constitution can be read as banning doctor-assisted suicide. The Internet has a lot of salacious material on it, but the Court unanimously agreed that its view of freedom of the press does not allow Congress to ban anything in cyberspace that Congress calls vaguely indecent material.

The most striking decision, however, was the 5-to-4 ruling that the federal government could not order local law-enforcement officers to do background checks on people who wanted to buy guns. The 10th Amendment to the Constitution says that the powers not delegated to the United States are reserved to the states or to the people. A while ago, the Court said that the feds could not ban gun sales near schools because such sales, not being part of interstate commerce, were only subject to state control, and the Court has also held that Washington cannot require a state to adopt a certain regulatory policy.

All of this may have pleased people who would like to see federal power weakened and states' rights expanded, but I doubt this will happen. Congress can easily reach almost any state activity if it gives the states a choice: Accept our federal grant and the rules that go with it or reject our money. Not many states will turn down what they regard as free money. Most important, however, though people say they like states' rights, they also strongly support federal programs, whatever their effects on states. The Court like Congress will eventually have to accept that. This is James Q. Wilson.

HOPKINS: Up next, we'll take a look at the fireworks business, both legal and otherwise.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: Fireworks are a $400-million-a-year business, and that's just the legal sales. Despite bans in many states, the fireworks business is -- you guessed it -- booming. Bill Tucker has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BILL TUCKER, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The number of bangs, booms, and bottle rockets has doubled since 1990. Well over 290 million pounds of fireworks will be set off this year. That's nearly half a pound of fireworks blown off for every man, woman, and child in the United States. Most of them will be set off over the next couple of days to celebrate America's Independence Day. Ironically, except for sparklers, fireworks are banned in 10 of the original 13 colonies.

New York State has launched one of the toughest crack downs on fireworks. Busts like this one last month in Long Island net millions of dollars worth of illegal fireworks.

THOMAS VON ESSEN, FIRE COMMISSIONER, NEW YORK CITY: The first year we started this program, we collected 5,000 cases; the second year 10,000; this year 26,000. So I know it's become harder for the people to get them if they still want them.

TUCKER (voice-over): Perhaps nowhere is the evidence of a crack down on illegal fireworks more evident than here in New York City's Chinatown where once fireworks could be had for the asking and now are nowhere to be found. Public safety is behind the bans. Fires and explosions such as this one shown in the New York Fire Department demonstration video make the 4th of July its busiest day of the year. Officials say individuals often fail to follow safety precautions commonly practiced by professionals.

MARK DORNHEIM, CHIEF PYROTECHNICIAN, GRUCCI FIREWORKS: We really go through all kinds of procedures to make sure that we'll have a healthy distance from the audience and that everything's going to be fine as far as fallout, as far as the actual show.

TUCKER (voice-over): And the show, after all, is the point. Bill Tucker, CNN Financial News, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HOPKINS: That's MONEYLINE for this Thursday. I'm Jan Hopkins in for Lou Dobbs. Have a happy and safe July 4th holiday.
