Mnuchin agrees with DoJ, should look into Amazon - Jul 24 - 08:29 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -16.30.
The S&P 500 futures trade six points, or 0.2%, below fair value. 
Treasury Secretary Mnuchin recently had wide-ranging interview with CNBC. Regarding the planned trade talks with China, he said he will depart for Beijing with USTR Lighthizer on Monday, and negotiations will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday. Separately, he said the DoJ should look into Amazon's (AMZN 1973.00, -21.49, -1.1%) practices. 
In other earnings news, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG 762.34, +22.74, +3.1%) and Snap (SNAP 16.48, +1.65, +11.3%) have impressed investors with upbeat results and guidance. Telsey Advisory Group and Maxim Group raised their CMG price targets to $750 and $670, respectively. Snap was upgraded to Neutral from Sell at UBS and Buy from Hold at Summit Insights. 

Futures weighed down by big tech scrutiny - Jul 24 - 08:00 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.90.
U.S. equity futures have been weighed down this morning by the big technology stocks amid continued regulatory scrutiny. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.
The Department of Justice announced yesterday that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of the "market-leading online platforms." Big tech scrutiny is nothing new, but the latest action confirms serious efforts to check the influence of big tech companies. The regulatory overhang has weighed on shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1134.00, -12.21, -1.1%), Facebook (FB 199.55, -2.81, -1.4%), and Amazon (AMZN 1976.60, -17.89, -0.9%) in pre-market action. 
In earnings news, Dow components Visa (V 180.20, -0.70, -0.4%), Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57, -0.7%), and Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61, -3.3%) were some blue-chip companies to report since yesterday's close. Shares of Caterpillar are getting hit following disappointing results and guidance, while shares of Boeing slip after the company continues to not provide full-year guidance.
Elsewhere, the eurozone flash July Manufacturing PMI declined below expectations, coming in at 46.4, amid weakness in Germany. A reading below 50.0 denotes a contraction. In U.S. data, investors will receive New Home Sales for June (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) at 10:00 a.m. ET. The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.
U.S. Treasuries haven't reflected too much concern about the eurozone slowdown, as yields are little changed. The 2-yr yield is down two basis points to 1.81%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 2.06%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.61. WTI crude is up 0.4% to $56.99/bbl. 
In U.S. Corporate news:

Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57): -0.7% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates. Boeing reported an EPS loss, which was expected, but the company continues to not provide full-year guidance.   

Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61): -3.3% after missing earnings expectations and lowering its FY19 EPS guidance.  

Visa (V 180.20, -0.70): -0.4% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates and slightly raising its FY19 EPS guidance. 

Texas Instruments (TXN 126.33, +6.26): +5.2% after beating top and bottom-line estimates. 

AT&T (T 31.53, -0.56): -1.8% despite releasing in-line results and raising its free cash flow guidance. 

UPS (UPS 108.00, +2.73): +2.6% after beating profit expectations. 


Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. Japan's Nikkei +0.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng +0.2%, China's Shanghai Composite +0.8%, India's Sensex -0.4%, South Korea's Kospi -0.9%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries +0.7%.In economic data:Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3).Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6).New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).In news: People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own.Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.

Major European indices are mixed. STOXX Europe 600 UNCH, Germany's DAX +0.4%, U.K.'s FTSE 100 -1.0%, France's CAC 40 -0.3%, Italy's FTSE MIB +0.4%, Spain's IBEX 35 +0.3%.In economic data:Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%).Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8).France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102).Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)In news:The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit.Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

Futures Update - Jul 24 - 07:27 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.60.

Early Levels - Jul 24 - 05:51 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -11.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -42.40.

Asian Market Data - Jul 24 - 05:51 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] Nikkei...21709.57...+88.70...+0.40%.  Hang Seng...28524.04...+57.60...+0.20%.

European Market Data - Jul 24 - 05:51 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] FTSE...7484.95...-71.90...-1.00%.  DAX...12504.5...+13.80...+0.10%.

Wall Street lifted by trade news, positive earnings reports - Jul 23 - 16:15 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 increased 0.7% on Tuesday, bolstered by encouraging trade news and positive earnings reports from widely-held companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.7%), Nasdaq Composite (+0.6%), and Russell 2000 (+0.7%) advanced in-line with the benchmark index. 
It had been a tight-ranged session for a good part of the day despite positive earnings results and guidance from a diversified group of companies like Coca-Cola (KO 54.33, +3.11, +6.1%), United Technologies (UTX 134.94, +1.99, +1.5%), Sherwin-Williams (SHW 490.23, +35.64, +7.8%), and Biogen (BIIB 243.88, +11.40, +4.9%). Travelers (TRV 147.50, -2.21, -1.5%), however, did come up short of expectations. 
Unsurprisingly, a positive trade headline helped energize the slow-moving market. Bloomberg reported that USTR Lighthizer and other senior officials will head to China next week to continue trade talks from Monday to Wednesday. Although this possibility had been reported earlier and many high-level talks in the past have yielded little progress, the good mood in the market flowing from earnings seemed to sway the market. 
The news pushed the S&P 500 back above the 3000 level, where it would stay above on a closing basis. Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by the trade-sensitive materials (+2.0%) and industrials (+1.2%) sectors. The utilities sector was the lone holdout, finishing lower by 0.6%. 
Qualcomm (QCOM 74.12, -1.83, -2.4%) was also left out of the advance after The Wall Street Journal reported that Apple (AAPL 208.84, +1.62, +0.8%) is considering buying Intel's (INTC 51.75, +0.40, +0.8%) smartphone-modem chip business for around $1 billion. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index finished up 1.2%.
Separately, Congress reached a deal to increase the budget deficit and suspend the debt ceiling for two years. The news provided some relief for investors, but market reaction was mostly muted as the dilemma never appeared to hinder the market beforehand and it was reported yesterday that a deal was close.
U.S. Treasuries finished on a lower note, pushing yields higher across the curve. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.83%, and the 10-yr yield increased three basis points to 2.07%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.5% to 97.74, helped by some weakness in the euro. WTI crude rose 0.9% to $56.72/bbl.
Reviewing Tuesday's economic data, which included Existing Home Sales for June and the FHFA Housing Market Index for May:

Existing home sales decreased 1.7% month-over-month in June to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million (Briefing.com consensus 5.30 million) from an upwardly revised 5.36 million (from 5.34 million) in May. Total sales were 2.2% lower than the same period a year ago.The key takeaway from the report is that the drop in mortgage rates has failed to spur a meaningful pickup in existing home sales, which continue to be constrained by the lack of available supply at lower price points.

The FHFA Housing Price Index for May increased 0.1% after advancing 0.4% in June.


Looking ahead, investors will receive New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index on Wednesday.

urn:contentItem:5W87-R3H1-DYRK-92N7-00000-00Stock Market Update2019-06-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisStock Market Update


Shares of Alphabet (GOOG), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), and Apple (AAPL) drop on antitrust and regulatory concerns 
ISM Manufacturing Index for May disappoints; global PMI data also showed slower or flat growth
Lingering trade and growth concerns underpin strength in Treasuries
Growing expectations for the Fed to cut rates to address slower growth and muted inflation; 2-yr yield drops 12 basis points to 1.83%

Big tech leads broader market lower on antitrust concerns - Jun 03 - 16:15 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.3% on Monday, as shares of big tech companies fell on various reports that heightened antitrust concerns. Lingering trade and growth concerns also helped curb risk sentiment and underpin the strength in U.S. Treasuries. A swarm of buyers in the last 30 minutes of action, however, helped the broader market close off its session lows. 
The tech-sensitive Nasdaq Composite fell 1.6%. The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.02%) finished fractionally higher, and the small-cap Russell 2000 increased 0.3%.
Facebook (FB 164.15, -13.32, -7.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1036.23, -67.40, -6.1%), Amazon (AMZN 1692.69, -82.38, -4.6%), and Apple (AAPL 173.30, -1.77, -1.0%) were all singled out in various reports indicating that the companies could face antitrust scrutiny by the Department of Justice and/or Federal Trade Commission.
These companies represent some of the most widely-held stocks in the U.S., and their out-sized losses weighed heavily on the Nasdaq and on the S&P 500 communication services (-2.8%), information technology (-1.8%), and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. The other eight S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by materials (+3.4%), to provide offsetting support.
Persisting concerns about trade and growth helped restrain buying conviction throughout the day. China blamed the U.S. for the setback in trade talks, which reinforced fears that a protracted trade war will squeeze global growth, and earnings, prospects. Global manufacturing PMI data, including in the U.S., revealed slower or flat growth in May.
On a related note, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC Voter) said that slower economic growth could be sharper-than-expected due to the trade uncertainty. Mr. Bullard added that a rate cut may soon be warranted to boost inflation. 
Growing expectations for a rate cut, and general growth concerns, helped send the 2-yr yield down 12 basis points to 1.83%. The 10-yr yield declined six basis points to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.5% to 97.22. WTI crude decreased 0.5% to $53.25/bbl, giving up an intraday rebound effort.
In other corporate news, German company Infineon announced plans to acquire Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.07, +4.25, +23.9%) for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85 per share, in cash. The offer represents a 33.8% premium to CY's Friday closing price. Humana (HUM 250.32, +5.46, +2.2%) said it will not make a competing bid to acquire Centene (CNC 51.82, -5.93, -10.3%).
Reviewing Monday's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.

Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending.


Looking ahead, investors will receive the Factory Orders report for April on Tuesday.

[BRIEFING.COM] Crude Oil futures closed at a four-month low as concerns over demand and global growth stem from trade disruptions. The Saudis said they will continue to work to avoid oversupply. July crude oil settled $0.25 lower (0.5%) to $53.25/barrel.
July Natural Gas settled $0.05 lower (-2.3%) at $2.403/MMBtu.
Precious metals rose as they tend to do in a flight to safety. June gold futures broke out to a four-month high, settling the session $16.90 higher (+1.3%) at $1322.70/oz. July silver settled $0.173 higher (+1.2%) at $14.74/oz.

Apple also subject to antitrust probe - Jun 03 - 14:55 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades lower by 0.5%, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.5%.
Apple (AAPL 172.45, -2.61, -1.5%) has been a new drag on the market after it joined the list of companies comprising of Facebook (FB 164.30, -13.30, -7.4%), Alphabet (GOOG 1030.25, -73.85, -6.7%), and Amazon (AMZN 1685.29, -89.66, -5.1%) today that have been singled out in antitrust investigation reports.
Reuters reported that Apple could be subject to a probe by the Department of Justice as part of a broader review of the tech giants' practices. Apple's weakness has sent contributed to the 1.8% decline in the information technology sector.

Majority Of S&P 500 Names Post Gains, Index Does Not - Jun 03 - 14:30 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages have drifted somewhat higher in the last 30 minutes with the Dow Jones Industrial Average returning to positive territory, while the Nasdaq Composite still sports losses north of 1.3%, and the S&P 500 nearing breakeven at -0.2%.
Action within the S&P 500 is mostly higher with about 75% of the components in the index showing gains, led by names like Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR 34.76, +3.44, +10.98%) which gains on an ASCO update, Capri Holdings (CPRI 34.45, +1.97, +6.07%) which recoups the majority of losses from the last few days following an insider purchase by the CEO & PVH (PVH 89.21, +4.02, +4.72%) which moves higher after announcing a Calvin Klein deal with G-III (GIII 25.95, +0.22, +0.86%) in the U.S. and Canada.
Conversely, declines from blue chip names like Centene (CNC 53.00, -4.75, -8.23%), Facebook (FB 165.41, -12.06, -6.80%) & Alphabet (GOOG 1,032.27, -71.36, -6.47%) rein in what should otherwise be a higher affair.

Gold Posts Another Session Of Gains, Moves To Three Month Highs - Jun 03 - 14:00 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] After an initial pop higher following comments from St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC voter) the broader market returned to its modestly lower move with the Dow Jones Industrial Average now back in negative territory.
Gold futures settled 1.3% higher on Monday at $1,327.90/oz, their best levels since February, as ongoing global trade tensions pushed investors toward bonds and precious metals.
Meanwhile, the U.S. Dollar Index slips -0.5% at 97.30, near session lows at this point.

Dow Jones Industrial Average Scoots Higher On Bullard Comments - Jun 03 - 13:30 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages were holding a negative move as of the last few minutes, but comments from the Saint Louis Fed President James Bullard that a rate cut may be warranted soon in order to lift inflation provided a modest lift.
The modestly lower move, ahead of the commentary from the last half hour, in the Dow Jones Industrial Average is helped by weakness in names like Microsoft (MSFT 120.61, -3.07, -2.48%), UnitedHealth (UNH 237.83, -3.97, -1.64%) & Visa (V 158.69, -2.64, -1.64%) being offset by equally decent gains at the top of the index.
Verizon (VZ 55.66, +1.31, +2.41%) takes top marks in the DJIA today with Chevron (CVX 115.41, +1.56, +1.37%) and NIKE (NKE 78.10, +0.96, +1.24%) close behind.
The DJIA scoots into positive territory in the last half hour after being down as much as 0.45% this morning.

Wall Street down on trade, growth, and regulatory concerns - Jun 03 - 13:00 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is down 0.4%, as familiar trade and growth concerns suppress investor sentiment while heightened regulatory concerns send shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1030.72, -72.91, -6.6%), Facebook (FB 164.37, -13.10, -7.4%), and Amazon (AMZN 1030.45, -77.87, -4.4%) noticeably lower. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.2%, and the Russell 2000 is down 0.3%.
The steep losses in these widely-held shares have contributed to the underperformance in the Nasdaq Composite (-1.3%), and the S&P 500 communication services (-3.2%) and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. Reports indicate that Alphabet, Facebook, and Amazon are facing new antitrust and regulatory threats from the Department of Justice and/or the Federal Trade Commission. 
The broader market, meanwhile, has been digesting disappointing manufacturing PMI data from around the world and China blaming the U.S. for the setback in trade talks. The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), which was its lowest since October 2016. 
In turn, the confluence of trade, growth, and regulatory concerns has outweighed early calls that the market was due for a bounce from short-term oversold conditions. The S&P 500 materials (+1.7%), energy (+0.7%), and consumer staples (+0.6%) sectors, however, have provided some offsetting support.
The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+0.8%) has also been a notable standout, helped by the 24.8% gain in shares of Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.21, +4.38). Germany's Infineon said it will acquire the company for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85/share, in cash. The offer represents a 34% premium from CY's Friday closing price.
Nevertheless, investors remain steadfast in buying U.S. Treasuries amid the negativity and uncertainty in the market. Increased demand has pushed the 2-yr yield down six basis points to 1.88% and the 10-yr yield down three basis points to 2.11%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.3% to 97.46.
Reviewing today's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.

Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending.

NASDAQ - 1441 - 1537 - 1.3 bln

NYSE - 1669 - 1147 - 314.7 mln

DJ30 - -27.77 - 24787.27

NASDAQ - -96.21 - 7356.91

SP500 - -14.44 - 2737.62

Antitrust worries send mega-cap stocks lower - Jun 03 - 12:25 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has descended to near session lows with a loss of 0.5%, as the widely-held FAANG stocks underperform.
Outside from Apple (AAPL 175.53, +0.43, +0.3%), Facebook (FB 164.97, -12.47, -7.0%), Amazon (AMZN 1699.05, -76.34, -4.3%), Alphabet (GOOG 1035.94, -67.67, -6.2%), and Netflix (NFLX 336.10, -7.18, -2.1%) have taken a hit. Facebook, Alphabet, and Amazon have all been singled out by separate reports that they are facing new antitrust threats. 
Separately, shares of Tesla (TSLA 180.44, -4.47) have dropped another 2.6%, as the stock continues to be pressured by demand and manufacturing concerns. The Drive reported that Tesla failed to secure air quality permits for new production lines as it ramped up its Model 3 production.

Growth concerns underpin the resiliency in the Treasury market - Jun 03 - 11:55 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades lower by 0.1%. Investors weren't too convinced by the bounce back into positive territory earlier, considering the persistent flight for safety in the U.S. Treasury market.
The 2-yr yield is down five basis points to 1.89%, and the 10-yr yield is down two basis points to 2.12%. At its low, the 2-yr yield touched 1.84%, which was also reflective of growing expectations for the Fed to cut rates to combat a slower growth environment. 
Manufacturing PMI data around the world, including the U.S., showed slowing or flat growth for the month of May. 
Overseas, the major European indices closed on a higher note. Germany's DAX gained 0.6%, UK's FTSE gained 0.4%, and France's CAC gained 0.7%. The Europe Stoxx 600 advanced 0.2%.

Balancing growth concerns with calls the market is due for a bounce - Jun 03 - 11:25 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages have experienced some volatility as the market tries to balance growth concerns with calls that the market is due for a bounce from short-term oversold conditions. The S&P 500 is up 0.1%, the Dow is up 0.2%, and the Nasdaq is down 0.4%.
Apple (AAPL 176.92, +1.85, +1.1%) has shown relative strength today ahead of its annual Worldwide Developers Conference, which will kick off at 1:00 p.m. ET. The company is expected to update its software products.
In other corporate news, shares of Centene (CNC 52.38, -5.38) have dropped 9.3% after Humana (HUM 252.06, +7.20, +2.9%) said it will not make a competing bid for the company. Boeing (BA 336.40, -5.14, -1.5%) notified the FAA of improperly manufactured parts on the 737 Max and 737 NG.

Alphabet drops on antitrust worries - Jun 03 - 10:55 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has climbed back into positive territory with a gain of 0.3% despite the lingering trade and growth concerns. 
Shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1034.03, -69.60, -6.3%), though, have been a huge drag on the broader market after The Wall Street Journal cited sources stating that the Department of Justice is preparing an antitrust investigation of Google. Shares of Facebook (FB 170.49, -6.98, -3.9%) and Amazon (AMZN 1718.48, -56.59, -3.2%) have also undereperformed on antitrust worries. 
The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.0%) has shown some strength today, bolstered by the 24.6% gain in shares of Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.19, +4.38). Germany's Infineon Technologies (IFNNY) said it will acquire the company for $23.85/share, or $10.1 billion, in cash.

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages begin the day on a mixed note after trading lower in pre-market action. The S&P 500 is up 0.3%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.1%.
Looking at the S&P 500 sectors shows health care (+0.8%), energy (+0.8%), and information technology (+0.6%) leading the broader market higher. The communication services sector (-1.4%) has been dragged lower by shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1052.74, -50.96, -4.6%), as the Department of Justice reportedly prepares an antitrust investigation on Google. 
Demand for U.S. Treasuries remains strong, driving yields even lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield is down five basis points to 1.89%, and the 10-yr yield is down three basis points to 2.11%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.2% to 97.61. WTI crude is up 1.5% to $54.30/bbl.

Wall Street headed for slight lower start as investors remain cautious - Jun 03 - 09:14 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -4.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -23.50.
Wall Street is on pace for a slightly lower start to begin the week, as the S&P 500 futures trade four points, or 0.2%, below fair value. 
Disappointing manufacturing PMI data out of Europe and Asia, coupled with China blaming the U.S. for the setback in trade talks, has contributed to today's negative disposition. The trade and growth narrative remains the same, but given the lack of good news, investors have adopted a cautious tone in front of the first trading day of June. 
The ISM Manufacturing Index for May (Briefing.com consensus 52.6), which will be released at 10:00 a.m. ET, will give investors a better feel for the economic environment in the U.S. 
Investors continue to seek safety in U.S. Treasuries, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield is down five basis points to 1.89%, and the 10-yr yield is down two basis points to 2.12%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.2% to 97.60. WTI crude is up 2.1% to $54.59/bbl.

Asia closes mixed, Europe trades slightly lower - Jun 03 - 08:50 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -4.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -25.50.
The S&P 500 futures trade five points, or 0.2%, below fair value.
Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region started the week on a mixed, and cautious, note with trade worries hanging like a wet blanket on investors. Lots of attention this morning on a White Paper out of China that places blame on U.S. for the negotiations unraveling. Nothing particularly new there, although the paper reasserts China isn't going to compromise on its key principles, which adds to sense this trade dispute could persist for some time. The increased tariff rate on the $200 billion tranche of Chinese exports to the U.S. and the $60 billion tranche of U.S. exports to China went into effect June 1. Separately, the U.S. has ended India's designation as a beneficiary developing nation, which means it is likely to lose ability to exports products to U.S. without tariffs. Manufacturing PMI data out of the region, including China's Caixin Manufacturing PMI, reflected softer growth environment in May.

Major European indices are starting the week on a cautious note, pinned down by growth concerns that stem from trade worries and a batch of manufacturing PMI data for May that was roundly disappointing and reflective of relatively weak manufacturing activity. Political matters are garnering some increased attention today with President Trump making an official state visit to the UK, German SPD Leader Nahles announcing her resignation, and Italy standing its ground with EU over budget matters and specter of disciplinary action. Separately, Germany's Infineon announced ~$10 billion cash deal to acquire U.S.-based Cypress Semiconductor (CY).

S&P 500 still holds a decent gain in 2019 - Jun 03 - 08:29 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -8.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -36.50.
The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value. The benchmark index holds a yearly gain of 9.8% as it enters the first trading session of the month. 
Reviewing the S&P 500 sector standings for the year shows real estate (+17.0%), information technology (+15.7%), and communication services (+13.5%) as the best-performing groups in 2019. Conversely, the health care (+0.6%), energy (+1.9%), and materials (+4.0%) sectors underperform.
Despite the negative disposition in the futures trade amid the familiar slowing growth narrative, investors haven't shown too much interest in hedging against further downside. The CBOE Volatility Index (18.74, +0.03, +0.2%) is up fractionally. 

Futures extend last month's losses as investors continue to de-risk - Jun 03 - 07:58 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -8.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -36.40.
The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value as investors follow through on last month's efforts to de-risk from trade and growth concerns. 
Regarding the U.S.-China trade front, China published a white paper on Sunday blaming the U.S. for the setback in trade talks. Although it was not entirely surprising, the news continues to support the market's view that the trade dispute will not be over soon.
Separately, manufacturing PMI data out of Europe and Asia indicated slower or flat growth last month, adding to the concerns that slower economic growth will lead to lower earnings prospects. 
In U.S. data, investors will receive the ISM Manufacturing Index for May (Briefing.com consensus 52.6) and Construction Spending for April (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%) at 10:00 a.m. ET. Auto and truck sales will be released throughout the day.
Persisting trade and growth concerns have also heightened the flight for safety in U.S. Treasuries, driving yields even lower across the curve. 
The 2-yr yield is down seven basis points to 1.87%, and the 10-yr yield is down three basis points to 2.11%. The noticeable drop in the 2-yr yield is also reflective of the market's view that the Fed may cut rates to address slower growth. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.64. WTI crude is up 1.5% to $54.32/bbl after falling nearly 9% last week on concerns that slower growth will weaken demand.
In U.S. Corporate news:

Alphabet (GOOG 1072.00, -31.63): -2.9% after The Wall Street Journal indicated sources that said the Department of Justice is preparing an antitrust investigation of Google.

Boeing (BA 336.94, -4.67): -1.4% after the company notified the FAA of improperly manufactured parts on the 737 MAX and 737 NG. 

Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.30, +4.48): +25.1% after Germany's Infineon Technologies (IFNNY) said it will acquire the company for $23.85/share, or $10.1 billion, in cash.

Apple (AAPL 174.62, -0.45): -0.3% ahead of its Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC).


Reviewing overnight developments:

Nothing particularly new there, although the paper reasserts China isn't going to compromise on its key principles, which adds to sense this trade dispute could persist for some time.The increased tariff rate on the $200 billion tranche of Chinese exports to the U.S. and the $60 billion tranche of U.S. exports to China went into effect June 1. Separately, the U.S. has ended India's designation as a beneficiary developing nation, which means it is likely to lose ability to exports products to U.S. without tariffs.Manufacturing PMI data out of the region, including China's Caixin Manufacturing PMI, reflected softer growth environment in May.

Major European indices are starting the week on a cautious note. STOXX Europe 600 -0.3%, Germany's DAX -0.2%, U.K.'s FTSE 100 -0.3%, France's CAC 40 -0.2%, Italy's FTSE MIB -0.3%, Spain's IBEX 35 -0.5%.In economic data:Eurozone's revised May Manufacturing PMI 47.7 (expected 47.7; last 47.7)Germany's revised May Manufacturing PMI 44.3 (expected 44.3; last 44.3)France's revised May Manufacturing PMI 50.6 (expected 50.6; last 50.6)Italy's May Manufacturing PMI 49.7 (expected 49.7 (expected 48.6; last 49.1)Spain's May Manufacturing PMI 50.1 (expected 51.3; last 51.8)UK's May Manufacturing PMI 49.4 (expected 52.0; last 53.1)In news:Growth concerns have stemmed from trade worries and a batch of manufacturing PMI data for May that was roundly disappointing and reflective of relatively weak manufacturing activity.Political matters are garnering some increased attention today with President Trump making an official state visit to the UK, German SPD Leader Nahles announcing her resignation, and Italy standing its ground with EU over budget matters and specter of disciplinary action. Germany's Infineon announced ~$10 billion cash deal to acquire U.S.-based Cypress Semiconductor (CY).

European Market Data - Jun 03 - 06:55 ET

[BRIEFING.COM] FTSE...7133.71...-28.00...-0.40%.  DAX...11701.24...-25.60...-0.20%.

Stocks, yields, and oil drop after Mexico tariff threat - May 31 - 16:15 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] U.S. stocks, Treasury yields, and oil prices all dropped on Friday after President Trump surprised the market by threatening to impose a 5% tariff rate on all goods imported from Mexico. Friday's 1.3% decline in the S&P 500 sent it below its 200-day moving average (2776) and extended its weekly decline to 2.6%.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average (-1.4%), the Nasdaq Composite (-1.5%), and the Russell 2000 (-1.4%) extended their weekly losses to 3.0%, 2.4%, and 3.2%.
The 5% tariff rate will go into effect on June 10 and will increase incrementally during the summer to reach 25% on Oct. 1. The White House could remove these tariffs altogether if Mexico makes a concerted effort to curb the flow of undocumented migrants entering the U.S. 
The news catalyzed de-risking efforts, leading to eight of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finishing with losses over 1.0%. The utilities (+0.5%) and real estate (+0.8%) sectors finished higher amid a steep drop in U.S. Treasury yields.
Another trade dispute on top of a U.S.-China trade war with no clear end in sight fueled ongoing concerns that trade tensions will lower economic, and earnings, growth prospects.
China added to these fears after it announced that it is drafting a list of unreliable foreign entities that harm the interests of its firms, increasing speculation about Chinese retaliation against the U.S. On a related note, China's manufacturing sector slipped into contraction in May.
Global growth concerns were transparent by the 5.2% drop in WTI crude ($53.48/bbl, -$2.92) and by investors seeking safety in a crowded U.S. Treasury market. The 2-yr yield dropped 12 basis points to 1.94%, and the 10-yr yield dropped nine basis points to 2.14%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.4% to 97.76. 
In corporate news, shares of General Motors (GM 33.34, -1.48, -4.3%) underperformed on the Mexico tariff threat. Dell Technologies (DELL 59.55, -6.86, -10.3%), Gap (GPS 18.68, -1.92, -9.3%), and VMware (VMW 176.98, -14.11, -7.4%) disappointed investors with their earnings results, while Uber (UBER 40.41, +0.61, +1.5%) pleased investors with its results.
Reviewing Friday's economic data, which included Personal Income and Spending data for April, the PCE Price Index for April, the final University of Michigan Index of Consumer Sentiment for May, and the Chicago PMI for April:

Personal income increased 0.5% in April (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) on top of a 0.1% increase in March. Personal spending rose 0.3% (Briefing.com consensus 0.2%) on top of an upwardly revised 1.1% increase (from 0.9%) in March. The PCE Price Index was up 0.3% m/m, as expected, while the core PCE Price Index, which excludes food and energy, jumped 0.2%, as expected.The key takeaway from the report is that real PCE was unchanged in April. That will be another data point that leads to forecasts calling for much slower real GDP growth in the second quarter than the 3.1% real GDP growth seen in the first quarter.

The final May reading for the University of Michigan Index of Consumer Sentiment checked in at 100.0 (Briefing.com consensus 101.5) versus the preliminary reading of 97.2.The key takeaway from the report was the acknowledgment that "confidence significantly eroded in the last two weeks of May" on account of concerns about the tariff actions.

The Chicago PMI for May increased to 54.2 from 52.6 in April.


Looking ahead, investors will receive the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April on Monday.

urn:contentItem:5W8F-P871-DYRK-94JV-00000-00Stock Market Update2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:09ZLexisNexisStock Market Update


Stock market rallies from short-term oversold conditions, has its best day since early January
Fed Chair Powell said the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansion, assuring the market the Fed is still on its side
Demand for U.S. Treasuries cools off, sending yields higher, amid the view that Treasuries were overbought on a short-term basis
The S&P 500 closed back above its 200-day moving average (2775)

Stocks rebound from short-term oversold condition, helped by Fed comments - Jun 04 - 16:25 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market had its best day since early January, boosted by gains across most sectors and by the prevailing view that the market was due for a bounce from short-term oversold conditions. Each of the major averages rose at least 2.0%, led by the 2.7% gain in the Nasdaq Composite, and the S&P 500 (+2.1%) climbed back above its 200-day moving average (2775). 
Tuesday's advance was rooted in yesterday's ability in the broader market to withstand heavy losses from Apple (AAPL 179.64, +6.34, +3.7%), Amazon (AMZN 1729.56, +36.87, +2.2%), Alphabet (GOOG 1053.05, +16.82, +1.6%), and Facebook (FB 167.50, +3.35, +2.0%), which all fell on antitrust concerns.
The turnaround in these mega-cap stocks ensured there was little to impede the rebound effort, especially when given the seemingly supportive comments from the Fed. 
Fed Chair Powell and Chicago Fed President Evans, both of whom are FOMC voters, acknowledged the trade uncertainty and the persistently low inflation levels. Although no rate cut was promised, Mr. Powell said that the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansion, assuring the market that the Fed is still on its side.
Cyclical sectors led the rally with the S&P 500 information technology (+3.3%), materials (+2.8%), financials (+2.7%), consumer discretionary (+2.6%), and industrials (+2.4%) sectors all finishing with gains over 2.0%. The defensive-oriented utilities (unch) and real estate (-0.6%) sectors were left out of the rally. 
Favorable trade headlines were pointed as having an early effect on the market. China said it wants dialogue and mutual respect in talks with the U.S. while speculation arose that President Trump's Mexico tariffs could be blocked by Congress. However, China's comments were largely in-line with prior rhetoric, and The Hill reported that President Trump is weighing a national emergency to implement new tariffs on Mexico.
Counter to the view that the stock market was oversold on a short-term basis, the Treasury market exhibited weakness on the view that it had gotten overbought on a short-term basis. The 2-yr yield increased five basis points to 1.88%, and the 10-yr yield increased four basis points to 2.12%. The U.S. Dollar Index declined 0.1% to 97.10. WTI crude increased 0.5% to $53.53/bbl.
Separately, Uber (UBER 42.75, +1.50, +3.6%) was rated positively by a host of firms on Tuesday. According to data from Briefing.com, 16 firms initiated the stock with the equivalent of a Buy rating. 
Reviewing Friday's lone economic report, Factory Orders for April: 

Factory orders declined 0.8% m/m in April (Briefing.com consensus -0.9%) following a downwardly revised 1.3% increase (from 1.9%) in March. Excluding transportation, orders increased 0.3%.The key takeaway from the report is the understanding that business investment was weak in April, evidenced by the 1.0% m/m decline in nondefense capital goods orders excluding aircraft.


Looking ahead, investors will receive the ADP Employment Change report for May, the ISM Non-Manufacturing Index for May, the Fed's Beige Book for June, and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index for May on Wednesday.

Midday Summary - Jun 04 - 13:00 ET


[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market has made a nice run so far today, bolstered by broad-based buying interest and an opportunistic trade rooted in the idea that it was primed to rebound from a short-term oversold condition. The major indices, led by a 2.3% gain in the Russell 2000, are all up at least 1.8% and trading at session highs.
Today's move began in earnest at the sound of the opening bell, as market participants reacted favorably to headlines that seemingly cooled down the temperature surrounding the trade dispute with China, and provided some cover to think the tariff on imported goods from Mexico could be averted, either due to a deal with the U.S. ahead of the June 10 deadline or a possible vote in Congress to forestall the action, according to the Washington Post.
In reality, the mood of the market had been lifted on Monday when the S&P 500 exhibited some relative strength in the face of large losses suffered by Alphabet (GOOG 1051.22, +14.99, +1.5%), Facebook (FB 166.54, +2.39, +1.5%), Amazon.com (AMZN 1723.80, +31.11, +1.8%), and Apple (AAPL 178.68, +5.37, +3.1%), which fell prone to some regulatory angst on the part of investors.
Those mega-cap stocks have managed to bounce back some today on the belief that any investigation into their business practices is likely to be a drawn out one; moreover, there is some underlying hope that none of the companies would eventually be broken up by the government.
Their gains today have helped bolster the broader market, yet the buying interest has been widespread. The information technology (+2.6%), financials (+2.3%), industrials (+2.1%), and consumer discretionary (+2.1%) sectors are all up at least 2.0%. The only sectors not participating today are the defensive-oriented real estate (-1.1%) and utilities (-1.0%) sectors.
Some of the fallout for the latter two sectors hearkens back to the Treasury market, where yields have risen noticeably across the curve on a counter-trade rooted in the idea that Treasuries were primed for a pullback from a short-term overbought condition.
The 2-yr note yield has spiked seven basis points to 1.90% while the 10-yr note yield has jumped five basis points to 2.14%. 
The losses in the Treasury market have unfolded despite some softening CPI data out of the eurozone and a 0.8% decline in U.S. factory orders for April.
The non-response in the Treasury market to otherwise disappointing economic data and some seemingly supportive remarks from Fed Chair Powell and Chicago Fed President Evans, both of whom are FOMC voters, underscores how the Treasury market is succumbing to the overbought perspective.
Neither Mr. Powell nor Mr. Evans promised a rate cut soon while speaking at a conference in Chicago, yet both paid heed to the risks of undershooting the 2.0% inflation target and the risks of the trade uncertainty, which has been construed by some today as a dovish policy leaning.
Separately, there was no mistaking the leaning in the analyst community with respect to Uber (UBER 42.17, +0.92, +2.2%). No fewer than 20 firms initiated coverage of the stock after its IPO, 16 of which had the equivalent of a Buy recommendation.

A swarm of buyers in the last 30 minutes of action, however, helped the broader market close off its session lows. 
The tech-sensitive Nasdaq Composite fell 1.6%. The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.02%) finished fractionally higher, and the small-cap Russell 2000 increased 0.3%.
Facebook (FB 164.15, -13.32, -7.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1036.23, -67.40, -6.1%), Amazon (AMZN 1692.69, -82.38, -4.6%), and Apple (AAPL 173.30, -1.77, -1.0%) were all singled out in various reports indicating that the companies could face antitrust scrutiny by the Department of Justice and/or Federal Trade Commission.
These companies represent some of the most widely-held stocks in the U.S., and their out-sized losses weighed heavily on the Nasdaq and on the S&P 500 communication services (-2.8%), information technology (-1.8%), and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. The other eight S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by materials (+3.4%), to provide offsetting support.
Persisting concerns about trade and growth helped restrain buying conviction throughout the day. China blamed the U.S. for the setback in trade talks, which reinforced fears that a protracted trade war will squeeze global growth, and earnings, prospects. Global manufacturing PMI data, including in the U.S., revealed slower or flat growth in May.
On a related note, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC Voter) said that slower economic growth could be sharper-than-expected due to the trade uncertainty. Mr. Bullard added that a rate cut may soon be warranted to boost inflation. 
Growing expectations for a rate cut, and general growth concerns, helped send the 2-yr yield down 12 basis points to 1.83%. The 10-yr yield declined six basis points to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.5% to 97.22. WTI crude decreased 0.5% to $53.25/bbl, giving up an intraday rebound effort.
In other corporate news, German company Infineon announced plans to acquire Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.07, +4.25, +23.9%) for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85 per share, in cash. The offer represents a 33.8% premium to CY's Friday closing price. Humana (HUM 250.32, +5.46, +2.2%) said it will not make a competing bid to acquire Centene (CNC 51.82, -5.93, -10.3%).
Reviewing Monday's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.

Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending.


Looking ahead, investors will receive the Factory Orders report for April on Tuesday.

Nasdaq Composite +10.5% YTD

S&P 500 +9.5% YTD

Russell 2000 +9.0% YTD
