<xhtml:span id="h2" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... no. The Congress has the ultimate authority under the Constitution to <xhtml:span class="hit">regulate</xhtml:span> immigration. And I don't think that anyone would have a successful ...</xhtml:span>

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5HX6-1BG1-DXH2-61SV-00000-00Stock Market Volatility Examined; Hillary Clinton E-Mail Server Reportedly Contaimed Information Beyond Top Secret; Whoopi Goldberg Claims She Might Leave the Country if Trump Elected President; Leonardo DiCaprio Rips Coal and Oil Industries; Denmark Reports Refugees Brought Bacterial Infection; Student Debt Examined2016-01-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:10ZLexisNexisRISK & REWARD5:00 PM ESTAndy Puzder, Doug Collins, Ralph Peters, Troy Slaten, Crystal Wright, Jim Douglas, Marc Siegel, Charlie KirkNEWSFinancial012101cb.233Stock Market Volatility Examined; Hillary Clinton E-Mail Server Reportedly Contaimed Information Beyond Top Secret; Whoopi Goldberg Claims She Might Leave the Country if Trump Elected President; Leonardo DiCaprio Rips Coal and Oil Industries; Denmark Reports Refugees Brought Bacterial Infection; Student Debt ExaminedJo Ling Kent

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

DAVID ASMAN, AFTER THE BELL SHOW HOST: That does it for us. Risk & Reward starts right now.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: The bulls and bears are out with heavy volatility shocking the markets all week including today.

Welcome to Risk & Reward. I'm Jo Ling Kent in for Deirdre Bolton.

It has been a wild ride with the Dow ending higher today as the European central banks says it's ready for new stimulus. We've got you covered from the markets to oil and everything in between.

We have Lori Rothman on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Lori, help us makes sense of this going into Friday. Where do we leave it today>

LORI ROTHMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes. Say to make sense of this market they be extraordinarily rich and they won't be carrying their hair out struggling with all of this volatility.

So, this is it where we stand right now. It was a rally today. We closed off best levels. You know, stocks fell off so deeply yesterday. We fell below those the late August lows and that left a lot of traders believe in the market was oversold that they came back. And then of course, you got to talk about the price of oil.

So, oil came back above $30 for a time. It faded but still managed to snap a three-session losing streak to close at $29.73 a barrel. That was critical. So, a lot of these oil names that had been absolutely clobbered over the last year came up big time. You got names like CONSOL energy up 19 percent. Southwest energy, up almost 19 percent today. So, that's really the story here.

So, between the technical and the oil story people come back to stocks here today. The Dow will close at 15,882. After the bell earnings, Starbucks is the headliner. Kind of a disappointment. Shares down in the extended session, 4 percent at moment. Stocks revenue from Starbucks.

The things were great here in the U.S. despite that whole big to do about the plain red coffee cups over the Christmas season. But everything was fine there. And of course, the problem as we've been reporting month after month now with Asia, the sales locations in Asia and the whole region were a little bit soft.

And so, of course investors are concerned with all these companies with exposure to that part of the world. Back to you, Jo Ling.

KENT: Lori, thank you so much for joining us. And now to Arizona republican Senator, John McCain saying voters will associate the plunge in the stock market with President Obama and the democrats.

With me now to break this down the CEO of CKE, the parent company of Hardee's and Carl's Jr., he's the former Mitt Romney economic advisor, Andy Puzder. Andy, what do you think of McCain's comments? Did that crash in 2008 scar him to think that it will happen again?

ANDY PUZDER, HARDEE'S & CARL'S JR. CEO: Well, it clearly it scared him. But there were a lot of other things going on in the economy at that time that also made that decline in the stock market more significant.

We're 10 years or 10 months from the election so a lot can happen in 10 months. If the stock market is still in big trouble in 10 months I would say democrats will have a real problem. But that's a -- 10 months is a long time from now.

KENT: Well, you know, Andy, we see the latest GOP polls or polls of the GOP race, Donald Trump widening his lead to over 20 points over Senator Ted Cruz in New Hampshire, very important early voting state. So, do you think this means that Trump will actually be able to carry a win and how much does that matter after Iowa and going in to South Carolina?

PUZDER: Well, the Iowa and New Hampshire are very, very important states and if Donald Trump can win both of those states I think it could be very significant. The interesting thing about the Iowa poll for me was that, Ted Cruz, after his comment about New York values and such, he actually went from 6 percent to 14 percent in the polls.

So, he had more than, you know, more than doubled the percentage of vote that he was getting. So, I think there is still a lot -- there's a lot of moving pieces out there. This is very, very difficult election to predict. Donald Trump looks very strong now.

KENT: Yes.

PUZDER But nobody's voted yet. So, we really need to have some people out there voting. And the big -- for me, the poll I look at is, how does each republican candidate do against Hillary Clinton. Because there is one issue.

(CROSSTALK)

KENT: Right. Well, we see in the Monmouth poll that Trump is able to carry it for the republicans at least as of now. But, Andy, I have to ask you who are you going to be supporting in these primaries?

PUZDER: Sure. I wish I knew. At the moment I'm not -- I'm not committed to anybody. I think we have a great slate of candidates I could get behind any of them for president. But again, I become a one issue candidate, or one issue voter, which is who can win? And if I felt positive about who had the best chance to win I'd be out there supporting that person because we really need to win.

KENT: All right. So, they are still trying to earn your vote.

PUZDER: Yes.

KENT: Well, what about Donald Trump making headlines by saying he wants to force Apple to manufacture all of its products including the iPhone in the U.S. if elected president. Listen to what he had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We're going to get things coming. We're going to get Apple to start building their damn computers and things in this country instead of in other companies.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: All right. For the record, Apple does make its MacBook pros in Austin, Texas. But looking at broader point, Andy, does this work?

PUZDER: Well, when he says he's going to get them do. If you offer them incentives that make it economically rational for them to manufacture those products in the United States I think they would be glad to do so. The president can't force them to do that. You know, it would take an act to Congress. You really couldn't discriminate against Apple in particular.

KENT: Right.

PUZDER: So, I'm not sure why he is singling Apple. I mean, Ford makes cars or GM makes cars in Asia. Are we going to require that they make all their cars here? Are we going to tell Toyota and BMW that, you know, we're not going to allow our car manufacturers to manufacture in their country?

You know, it's a -- it's a very, very difficult thing for him to do.

KENT: Right.

PUZDER: But he is appealing to these blue-collar voters...

KENT: That's exactly it.

PUZDER: ... who feel like the economy is coming at him in two ways. One is that jobs are going to China. And the other is that the jobs that stay here are being taken by people that are here illegally.

So, I think what he is doing is he's appealing to this base that is risen up for him that really is concerned about their jobs, and their families and their income.

KENT: Right.

PUZDER: And part of that is jobs going to China. The other part is jobs going to people that aren't -- that aren't here legally. So, I think that he is appealing to his base. I don't know -- I don't -- I'd love to see him do things that made, that incentivized companies to manufacture in the United States, any president should do that.

KENT: Andy, I want to ask you. You have some news today. Hardee's and Carl, Jr.'s is they are going to put out $4 menu for people. You want to compete with Wendy's and other fast-food chains in a really tough fast-food environment.

PUZDER: Yes.

KENT: Why go in that direction and not stick with the cheaper items on the menus like the dollar menu type of thing?

PUZDER: Well, we've never had a dollar menu. What we're doing is we're bundling products. So, it's a $4, for $4 you get really great double cheeseburger, you get a great spicy chicken sandwich, a soda and fries. So, it's a really -- I think it's a superior deal to what any of our competitors are offering.

But when your competitors are bundling and selling a lot of products for a set price, if you don't -- if you don't respond to that you're going to lose customers. And, you know, we want to keep people coming into the restaurants. And we think this is a good deal for them. We'll do fine with it. I'm real happy with this. No dollar menus, though. Dollar menus are a bad idea.

KENT: Al right. You heard it here. Andy Puzder, he's a CEO of Hardee's and Carl's Jr. at CKE and a former Mitt Romney economic advisor. Your endorsement up for grabs. We'll be watching for that. Thanks for joining us.

PUZDER: Thanks, Jo.

KENT: A new Fox report saying some of Hillary Clinton's e-mails on her private server contained information that was so secret that even senior lawmakers involved in oversight could not even read them or access them.

One of those lawmakers is here with us right now, judiciary committee member, which has oversight of the Department of Justice and the FBI. Representative Doug Collins. Representative, thanks for coming on.

DOUG COLLINS, GEORGIA STATE REPRESENTATIVE: Jo, glad to be here today.

KENT: So, I'm told you have military clearance to access lots of classified information. What does it feel like not to be able to access this sensitive data?

COLLINS: Well, I think it's interesting for those of us in the military who dealt with classified information on various levels in our careers, but also as members of Congress, it is just mystifying to me why the former Secretary of State is having such a problem trying to frankly, trying to explain a way something she should not be explaining away.

There is nothing that the Justice Department now should not do to get to the bottom of this Congress whatever it takes, this was a malfeasance of law. And it's one frankly where I'm calling on Mrs. Clinton to suspend her presidential campaign.

She needs to be straight with the American people. And if she's mishandled classified information that could put people's lives in danger. That is disqualification for a Commander-in-Chief and I'm just shocked that she is taking it so lightly.

KENT: All right. So, does this then obviously, for you in your opinion, undercut Clinton's claim that the material was innocuous and basically fully contradict that?

COLLINS: It totally contradicts that. When you deal with these special access kind of programs, these are deals that deal with current ongoing operations that are -- that are so classified that they require even a more disclosure notice past the top secret clearance on which normally members can have.

That is not someone not even is mentioned remotely to be unclassified setting that should throw off alarms all over the system. And for her just to cavalierly say, oh, there is nothing but innocuous stuff on here, is frankly at this point she is being disingenuous.

She is I think she is lying to the American people because something she doesn't want to talk about.

KENT: Representative, one quick question for you, because you can't access it, what do you think are in those emails? What do you presume in them?

COLLINS: Well, I'm not going to presume because at this point in time those were -- they're classified the way they were classified because of significance of the national security and world implications.

KENT: OK.

COLLINS: And to say any different, I mean, that's just something that should make her to have to answer this. And the Department of Justice needs to be all over this even more than they already are.

KENT: Congressman Doug Collins, good to talk with you. Thank you for joining us.

COLLINS: Jo, I appreciate it. Thanks so much.

KENT: And Judge Napolitano weighing in on Hillary's predicament saying last night this could be Clinton's down fall.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: The case against her is overwhelming, damning and from her perspective grave.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: Coming up, Hillary Clinton responds. Hear what she had to say.

And first, sexual assault and now some German refugees are suing. Find out why. We have an attorney who says the U.S. could face a similar situation.

And bringing new meaning to the phrase, "killing them with kindness." Facebook chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg saying likes can help fight terrorists. Colonel Ralph Peters weighing in on Sandberg's counterterrorism strategy after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHERYL SANDBERG, Facebook COO: They launch what think called a like attack on the Facebook page of the NPD.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: This is the continuation of an interagency dispute that has been going on now for some months. As the State Department has confirmed, I never sent or received any material marked classified. And that hasn't changed.

NAPOLITANO: And when she says she never sent or received anything marked classified it's a word game. Nothing is marked classified. It's marked confidential, secret, top secret or SAP.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: Former Secretary of State, Hillary Clinton continues to brush off reports that her private server contained highly classified intelligence.

Attorney Troy Slaten is joining me to break this down. So you think, Troy, that he -- that Hillary is playing a word game here? Are we talking about just vocab is different?

TROY SLATEN, ATTORNEY: I mean, she is. I mean, Jo, anybody that understands what the secret service does, and that's what her main defenses, is that the secret service was protecting the server, knows that they're not looking at the traffic that's going in and out from this server.

She is playing a word game. Just because it wasn't marked classified at that moment doesn't mean it that it didn't contain classified information. And she should know. And the I.G. report confirms what everybody already widely knew. And that's that she had some of our nation's most secret stuff on that personal, unsecured server.

KENT: All right, Troy. We also have some sound hit that we want to play for you, that some say Hillary Clinton had an ulterior motive when she praised President Obama in the last debate over the weekend. Listen to what she said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: That is one of the greatest accomplishments of President Obama. Thanks goodness, President Obama vetoed it. President Obama has led our country out of the great recession.

TRUMP: You notice how positive she is about the president? You know why, right? You know why. Because she wants to stay out of the clink.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: All right, Troy, do you think that Hillary is appealing to President Obama here, especially as some of his surrogates go out and essentially campaign for her or do you think that trump is incorrect?

SLATEN: No. I think it might even be more nefarious than that, Jo. The person that decides whether or not she'll be indicted is the Attorney General of the United States. The Attorney General is like the D.A. for the United States. She is the one, Loretta Lynch, who will decide whether or not Hillary is indicted.

And Loretta Lynch was appointed by President Obama. Now it would be the scandal of all scandals if it turned out that the president or the White House was putting any pressure on the Justice Department to stop an indictment from coming out just because she is running for president or that this is an election year.

KENT: All right. Well, we have some other developing news, Troy. Under new changes to the U.S. Visa waiver program, nationals who've been in Iran, Iraq, Sudan, or Syria since March 2011, can no longer visit the United States under the visa waiver program.

And then over in Germany you also have developments there. Refugees that were welcomed by Chancellor Angela Merkel are now suing the government, some of them are, for taking too long to process their claims for asylum.

My first question is, do you think the U.S. is going to face any sort of backlash like that from refugees? Are they entirely different situations here?

SLATEN: I mean they are different situations. It looks like the people in Germany are really fighting back against this onslaught of what was unfettered migration of people that they weren't really able to properly vet. Now I think that it's good that the United States has put the brakes on this, but, no.

The Congress has the ultimate authority under the Constitution to regulate immigration. And I don't think that anyone would have a successful lawsuit to say that the United States is taking too long to vet them and decide whether or not they could have entry into the United States.

But in Germany, we're seeing that the people that are coming in that are not having a chance to assimilate because there are too many people coming in, I mean, they're having mass sexual assaults and rapes in Cologne which happens to be the same city where they're filing lawsuits for taking too long to grant them asylum status.

KENT: All right. Well, there is a lot to debate there but we have to move on to another lighter topic.

A snowboarder who survived an avalanche at Lake Tahoe's Sugar Bowl Resort in California is facing a very serious matter now. It's a lawsuit for criminal trespassing. And you can see this GoPro camera captioning Christian Michael Mares tumble down the slope.

He was really lucky narrowly dodging all those trees you see there, finally landing half buried in the snow. He is pretty lucky to be alive at this point. But a lawsuit filed by the resort is alleging he triggered the avalanche in an area that was clearly marked as closed.

So, Troy, even though he says he didn't know it was an area that was off limits. How do you think the case is going to proceed here? The sheriff's office got a -- has in the sense right now?

SLATEN: So, he is facing two potential legal problems. First is a criminal action by -- initiated by the sheriff, will be prosecuted by the D.A. that alleges that he was trespassing. He was in an area on private property without permission.

But he is also facing a potential lawsuit by the operators of the ski resort who had to mount a response to rescue him, and it place a lot of lives in danger because by him going into that off-limits area he triggered this avalanche.

And 27 people die every year from avalanches. And this is an area has been off limits since the 2010-2011 season. So, he's got a lot of explaining to do. And it may ultimately be up to a jury to decide whether it was clearly marked, and whether an average, reasonable person would know that you're not supposed to go there.

The fact that he had a GoPro camera mounted to his helmet may lead people to believe that he was an extreme sports advocate, and therefore looking for some danger.

KENT: Well, either way, it is very well-documented. Troy Slaten, thank you so much for joining us tonight.

SLATEN: Thanks for having me, Jo.

KENT: Whoopi Goldberg threatening to leave the United States.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WHOOPI GOLDBERG, ACTRESS & HOST: I don't think that's America. I don't want it to be America. Maybe time for me to move?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: Find out what Donald Trump said that has her potentially packing her bags. And Facebook COO, Sheryl Sandberg is trying to kill ISIS with kindness.

Coming up, Colonel Ralph Peters talking to us about if Facebook -- if a Facebook-like attack would actually work.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDBERG: They launch what they called a like attack on the Facebook page of the NPD.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: Facebook executive, the COO, Sheryl Sandberg believes that Facebook likes can help counter ISIS recruitment. Listen to what she had to say at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDBERG: The best antidote to bad speech is a good speech. They launch what they called a like attack on the Facebook page of the NPD. So, the NPD is the new Nazi party. That page is filled with intolerance.

And rather than scream and protest, they got 100,000 people to like the page who did not the like the page and then put messages of tolerance on the page.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: Retired U.S. Lieutenant Colonel and Fox News military analyst, Ralph Peters joins me now. Colonel, can we really kill ISIS and their recruitment an propaganda with kindness there?

RALPH PETERS, FOX NEWS MILITARY ANALYST: Well, we should start by sending cupcakes. I like cupcakes. They must like cupcakes too, right? Now, truly Ms. Sandberg's remarks in Davos are one of the most remarkable combinations of naivet‚ and cynicism that I have ever encountered.

The cynicism is obviously Facebook doesn't want to block sites. It wants track. They doesn't want a reputation of blocking sites. So, this is seems to be an immaculate solution. Don't block a terror sites just get people to like them but then write nice things instead of bad things terrorists write.

Well, then you get the naivet‚.

(CROSSTALK)

KENT: So, how do you think this plays in, Colonel, to the broader discussion that the White House has been trying to have with Silicon Valley and big tech companies to hand over information that they believe they need without a search warrant?

PETERS: Well, Silicon Valley does not take terrorism seriously as you saw in the case of Ms. Sandberg. They're all fine with disrupting the way we communicate. But they don't see how the terrorists are disrupting the world.

But if I may just say about, you know, what she wants to do is get people to write nice things. Our State Department and others have been trying to counter ISIS on the web and it doesn't work. It doesn't work because people who graduated from MIT or Harvard or Yale, they have no idea how these terrorists think.

And what we offer, our counteroffer is crazy. Islamic state offers the, you know, dysfunctional young basement dwellers revenge, a chance to torture and kill males. To rape and enslave women. And if you get killed you get the bullet train to paradise. What is our counteroffer? Our counteroffer is a job at Wal-Mart.

(CROSSTALK)

KENT: And that's what they're trying -- that I think that's what, if you look at what Sheryl Sandberg is attempting to say here, regardless of what you think of her argument, is that a counter speech and counter propaganda is something that needs to be done. And what you see actually is...

(CROSSTALK)

PETERS: You can't do it.

KENT: ... the White House saying that they want to do, who knows if they actually agree on this. But I want to move on to Google...

(CROSSTALK)

PETERS: No, but truly they cannot do it. We can't do it because we have nothing to offer those guys.

KENT: But, Colonel, with all due respect if you look at who controls the pipelines and the ability of the terrorists to actually communicate it happens on those platforms. So, that is...

PETERS: Yes.

KENT: ... being able to work with these companies and actually convince them to do something more, perhaps you could argue is one of the ways to counter what is happening in terms of recruitment, right?

PETERS: We, of course we want them to block their -- yes, we want them to block their sites. We want -- we need some back door de-encryption capability at certain points. But when you get into these ideas that, no, we just have to say nice things to counter their bad things, the example she used about neo-Nazi Party, the NPD in Germany. Bad example because since Cologne, their numbers are actually increasing.

This doesn't work. When you have the overeducated trying to convince the undereducated that if you really, you just need to be nicer and everything will go your way, it does not work. Your upper class can never convince to love it.

(CROSSTALK)

KENT: So, you're looking for more out of them? You're not looking to abandon cooperating or collaborating?

PETERS: Oh, of course not. We want them, we need Silicon Valley to do far more but then they are lacking to do it.

(CROSSTALK)

KENT: Well, speaking of Silicon Valley, Colonel, I want to ask you about Google. They're also coming out and saying ISIS must be blocked out of the open web. And Donald Trump, the frontrunner had said something relatively similar. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We're losing a lot of people because of the internet and we have to do something. We have to see Bill Gates and a lot of different people that really understand what's happening. We have to talk to them, maybe in certain areas, closing that internet up in some way.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: It could be argued that Google and Trump may be on the same page here. What do you think, colonel?

PETERS: Well, I think Google is much closer to the truth than Ms. Sandberg was. The internet is without question the greatest tool for spreading hatred since the invention of moveable type plates for the printing press in the 15th century.

It's just remarkable how effective it is. The point I am trying to make is, you know, if you can't outthink your enemy symmetrically you do it asymmetrically. And our attempt to argue with them on the internet we cannot win the argument on with speech with arguments with rhetoric.

(CROSSTALK)

KENT: So, it has to be mechanical and technical.

PETERS: You have to kill them. Yes, you have to kill them.

KENT: All right. Colonel Ralph Peters talking about asymmetric warfare. We always like talking about that. Thank you for joining us.

PETERS: Thank you.

KENT: Whoopi Goldberg threatening to pack her bags and leave the United States.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOLDBERG: I don't think that is America. I don't want it to be America. Maybe it's time for me to move?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: Find out what Donald Trump said that has Whoopi packing her bags.

And there could be trouble in paradise.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LENA DUNHAM, ACTRESS: Do you consider yourself a feminist?

CLINTON: Yes. Absolutely.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: A new report saying that actress Lena Dunham a very avid Hillary supporter, has some misgiving how the candidate treats women. Those details are coming up next.

WHOOPI GOLDBERG, ACTOR: I have been part of that when they just use a blanket statement to talk about black people or when they use a blanket statement to talk about white people or women or any other group. I don't think that's America. Maybe it's time for me to move. I can afford to go.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Where would you go?

GOLDBERG: I don't know. You know I have always been an American. This has always been my country, and we have been able to have discussions. And suddenly now, it's turning into -- not them. I need all the candidates to get it together. Get back to American values.

JO LING KENT, RISK AND REWARD HOST: That was Whoopi Goldberg saying she might leave the country if GOP frontrunner Donald Trump is elected President. The View Co-Host saying Trump needs to stop blaming other people for the problems in America. With me right now to break this down is Crystal Wright. She is the Editor of the Conservative Black Chick Blog and Author of Con Job, the book on your screen right now. So what do you think about Whoopi Goldberg's comments?

CRYSTAL WRIGHT, CONSERVATIVE BLACK CHICK BLOG: Go, Whoopi, leave. You already said you have enough money to leave America. You don't like Donald Trump's discussion. Finally, we have a candidate who is not talking in political correctness code. Muslims are the ones that are trying to kill Americans. Illegal immigrants are the ones who are criminals. They come here, they steal our jobs and they murder us. Whoopi, what is wrong with what Donald Trump said. We have a candidate sticking up for Americans, too bad for you.

KENT: He certainly has very blunt things to say. But one of Hillary Clinton's supporters, Lena Dunham, according to her. She was disturbed about the women sexually assaulted by former President Bill Clinton. So Dunham interviewed Hillary last year and asked about a topic -- feminism which is close to the actress' heart.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do you consider yourself a feminist?

HILLARY CLINTON, PRESIDENTAL CANDIDATE: Yes, absolutely.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: Could Hillary's past come back to hurt her? How do you take a surrogate like Lena Dunham seriously when there are two different opinions that are contradictory?

WRIGHT: Lena Dunham alleges she was raped in college. Yet, she is going to stand by Hillary Clinton who says she is the poster child for feminism which couldn't be further from the truth. She stood by a man who has disrespected her when he was Governor of Arkansas over and over again -- when he was the governor of Arkansas. They tried to shut down the allegations when they said Bill molested them. Lena Dunham is a farce, she is a joke, and she is a surrogate.

KENT: What contradictory feelings represent younger women just learning about these issues for the first time?

WRIGHT: They look to Lena Dunham, and they don't do their homework. They say if Lena likes Hillary, I'll like Hillary.

KENT: Where do they go? Do they go to Bernie?

WRIGHT: Bernie is getting a lot of millennial votes. Women look up to Lena Dunham. She is a powerful figure. She is powerful in Hollywood and college students are poisoned on college campuses with a liberal agenda. They are not getting the other side. I just think that Bernie is pulling off some of the millennials but sadly a lot of young women in America are misinformed. We are not doing a good job as Republicans getting our message out. Hillary's message to women everywhere is the on way you can be President of the United States is stand by a philandering whore monger man.

KENT: She's one candidate of several that the Democrats choose from. Very interesting to talk to you about -- Leonardo Dicaprio ripping the coal and oil and gas industry, says he received the World Economic Forum's Crystal Award on Tuesday. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LEONARDO DICAPRIO, ACTOR: We simply cannot afford to allow the corporate greed of the coal, oil, and gas industries to determine the future of humanity. Those entities with a financial interest in preserving this destructive system had denied and even covered under the evidence of our changing climate. Enough is enough. You know better. The world knows better. History will place the blame for this devastation squarely at their feet.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: Well, Dicaprio himself has reportedly taken 20 trips across the United States and around the world, mostly on private planes in 2014 alone. So Crystal, is he being hypocritical here?

WRIGHT: Let's talk about emissions on those private jets you are flying around the world. It's ok for Leonardo have corporate greed in Hollywood and to make millions upon millions of dollars for films, but it's not ok for gas and oil companies who employ people around the world, their greed isn't ok. This is once again liberal Hollywood hypocrisy.

KENT: Do you have think you can count all of his campaigning about climate change as basically a neutral?

WRIGHT: I don't know how he could give that speech with a straight face, frankly. I don't. Like he said, talk about his carbon footprints. You know.

KENT: All right, Crystal Wright, Conservative Black Chick Editor, Author of the book Con Job, always fun to see you. Thank you for your perspective.

WRIGHT: Thanks.

KENT: All right, Denmark announcing unvaccinated refugees has sudden illness into their country that hasn't been seen in 20 years. Coming up, Dr. Siegel on if we should be worried about the 10,000 refugees coming in to United States. Also, several other health stories in the news. Dr. Siegel's going to tell us the side effects of led in your water -- and how China's smog can affect your health after this.

KENT: Denmark reporting that refugees have brought in a highly contagious and sometimes fatal bacterial infection into their country. Dr. Marc Siegel is here with us now. Dr. Siegel, explain what this infection does to the body and what some of the symptoms are.

MARC SIEGEL, MEDICAL TEAM: First of all, Jo, I have always been one of the people saying let's not be politically correct when it comes to refugees and diseases, because they may not be screened the way other people are screened. We are not screening for diphtheria. It's a dangerous disease. The worst thing about it, it gives respiratory symptoms. It's highly contagious. A lot of us had the vaccine for this but it wears often with 10 years. It could easily re-emerge in Denmark.

I would encourage everybody to get the booster vaccine. Everyone should have it every 10 years.

KENT: How does it spread and can you see a scenario where refugees being accepted into a country getting treated for it in a timely fashion.

SIEGEL: It spreads by coughing and sneezing, sometimes by touch. It's really easy to get if you haven't been -- been immunized to it, but it wears off.

KENT: How do you think public health can prevent that from happening and still allowing refugees to come in? Is that possible?

SIEGEL: No, it's not possible. You can treat it with an antibiotic. Everybody around this cluster will have to be vaccinated for it right now. If I were practicing medicine in Denmark, I would say to my patients let me give you a booster shot.

KENT: What do you do to refugees who have been accepted who need this vaccination?

SIEGEL: You have to give them the vaccination. So who is going to pay for that? You will have to give them the vaccine.

KENT: How much would that cost?

SIEGEL: That's costs over $100.

KENT: For each person?

SIEGEL: That's right.

KENT: All right, breaking it down for us, Dr. Marc Siegel.

(CROSSTALK)

SIEGEL: And I'm not against that. We used to do that with tuberculosis, that wasn't a good vaccine. This is a very good vaccine.

KENT: All right, good to know. So we know the cost, we know it's happening, thank you so much for getting us the details, Dr. Marc Siegel.

All right, over 7,000 students trying to get the government to forgive millions of dollars in debt because they couldn't get jobs after college. Coming up, a guest who says getting a job is their own problem.

And another Biden slip up, a jump in the polls for Bernie Sanders has Biden on the attack on behalf of Hillary Clinton. Here the V.P. calls out socialism in Bernie Sanders after this.

BERNIE SANDERS, PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We are 50 points behind the inevitable democratic nominee. Well, guess what? That inevitable candidate ain't so inevitable today.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Why are young people drawn to Bernie? Perhaps an explanation lays an answer rapper Killer Mike gave earlier this week.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: How does a rapper supporting Senator Sanders?

KILLER MIKE, RAPPER: Smoking a joint and reading his tweets.

SANDERS: We were 50 points behind the inevitable democratic nominee. Well, guess what? That inevitable candidate ain't so inevitable today. All over the country, we are seeing huge turnouts of people who are sick and tired of establishment politics.

KENT: Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders continues to jump in the polls, Vice President Joe Biden takes what appears to be a jab at the nominee in Davos.

JOE BIDEN, VICE PRESIDENT: We need a more progressive tax country not none my country, but other countries, not confiscatory policy, not socialism, a tax code. Everybody pays proportionally a fair share.

KENT: With me is the Former Republican Governor of Vermont, Jim Douglas. You have known Bernie Sanders for 40 years. Are the mainstream democrats officially worried about Bernie? He is beating Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire by 27 points.

JIM DOUGLAS, FORMER REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR OF VERMONT: I think they are concerned. It's hard to know at this point what will happen ultimately, remember, 12 years ago at this point Howard Deen was leading in the polls. Howard had huge crowds as well. We'll have to see how it plays out. But there is no question the establishment democrats are feeling the burn.

KENT: I want to show you some highlights from Bernie's last democratic debate over the weekend. See what you think.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDERS: Bernie Sanders who has fought for universal healthcare my entire life. He wants to end Medicare and Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program. That's nonsense. I don't take money from big banks. I don't get personal speaking fees from Goldman Sachs. We are not going tear up the Affordable Care Act, I helped write it. But we'll move on top of that to care for all.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KENT: Governor Douglas, you have known Bernie Sanders for 40 years. What do you think is not coming across that the voters should know about him as they go into these early-voting contests?

DOUGLAS: On the positive side, what you see is what you get. He's very transparent and his message hasn't changed. The only difference is he substituted millionaires for billionaires. And I admire someone who has the courage of his convictions. But he's out of the mainstream. He believes in free college and free healthcare and taxing the rich regardless of the consequences. He's pretty much an isolationist in terms of foreign trade policy. But he has a certain appeal as you can see from the crowds he's been drawing.

KENT: Governor Jim Douglas, what do you think the final outcome will be from where you sit in the northeast?

DOUGLAS: Well, obviously New Hampshire is our next door neighbor and there is a home court advantage there. But this is a long road to the nomination. As I mentioned, we have been through this before, candidacies rise and fall very quickly. He would seem to be enough out of the mainstream that American voters would probably want someone more centrist. But ironically, Joe, he's appealing to a lot of the same people Donald Trump is.

KENT: A lot of the swing voters looking for something out of the mainstream. Governor Douglas, we are out of time. I'm so sorry. Thank you so much for joining us.

DOUGLAS: Thanks, Joe, take care.

KENT: Thanks. Now people are asking, dude, where's my job? Over 7,000 students are trying to get the government to forgive millions of dollars in debt because they couldn't get a job after immediately college. Coming up, a guest who says getting a job is their own -- the students' responsibility.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Scott, things aren't at happy as they used to be down here at the unemployment office. Joblessness is no longer just for philosophy majors. Useful people are starting to feel the pinch. I have five years of modern dance and six years of tap.

KENT: In the past six months, more 7,500 borrowers owing $164 million have applied to have their student debt wiped out. They are able to do that because an obscure federal law forgives debt for borrowers who can prove their schools used illegal tactics to recruit them, say promising them a job or something like that. (Inaudible) Charlie Kirk is here with me now. So I want to give some context here, the U.S. Education Department already agreed do cancel $28 million for 1,300 former students of Corinthian because that college went bankrupt last year. So how does this particular claim compare?

CHARLIE KIRK, POINT USA FOUNDER: Yeah, it's not as strong an argument as the Corinthian. If the Department of Education agrees to forgive the student loans in this current pool, it could start a slippery slope. It's $164 million in the aggregate. There might be other students who say wait a second, they got their student loans forgiven, I was sold a bill of goods.

KENT: Is it a qualifying claim to say I couldn't find a job because my school promised so I can make that argument. Does that actually work?

KIRK: In this particular instance, I really don't think. If a school goes bankruptcy and they were being deceiving and illegal in their recruiting tactics, they are saying they were deceiving. They weren't necessarily being as strong to the message. They are a college trying to recruit students. They are going to try to market their school as best they can.

KENT: That was Charlie Kirk, thank you so much, coming up next, Making Money with Charles Payne.

urn:contentItem:60YS-2HB1-JB4F-Y0GY-00000-00Stock Monthly: Alphabet Class A (GOOGL:$1,465.60) drops 10% on high volatility Wednesday September 30, 2020 16:00 EDT2020-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:10ZLexisNexisStock Monthly: Alphabet Class A (GOOGL:$1,465.60) drops 10% on high volatility Wednesday September 30, 2020 16:00 EDT

AMERICAN MONTHLY STOCK REPORT

Alphabet Class A (NASDAQ:GOOGL), the NASDAQ's 2nd largest Internet company by market cap, traded between an intra-month high of $1,726.10 and a three-month low of $1,402.15. In September its volatility (highest price minus lowest price/lowest price) of 23.1% was 1.42 times average monthly volatility of 16.2%, up from 13.7% in August and 12.2% in July.

The share price plummeted $163.93 (or 10.1%) in the past month to close at $1,465.60 on Wednesday September 30, ending a two-month streak of rises. Compared with the NASDAQ-100 Index which fell 692.6 points (or 5.7%) in the month, this represented a relative price change of -4.3%.

The price ranged between a low of 1409.4 on Wednesday, 23 Sep and a high of 1717.4 on Wednesday, 2 Sep. In the past month the market cap has plunged by $49.3 billion to $440.4 billion.

The volume in the month equalled the average trading of 43.7 million shares.

Alphabet Class A (GOOGL) has been issued 37 new patents by the USPTO & EPO. To view details, click on link shown below

Wednesday's price drop
Alphabet Class A decreases on slipping relative strength
Alphabet Inc decreased 42.0c (0.03%) from Tuesday's close of $1,465.60. Compared with the NASDAQ-100 Index which rose 95.1 points (0.8%) in the day, the relative price change was -0.9%. In the NASDAQ market, the stock's relative price strength percentile is slipping at 33 for 6 months, 26 for 3 months, and 10 for 30 days. A price fall combined with a slipping relative strength is a bearish signal. There were 1,798,927 shares worth $2.6 billion traded today. The volume was 0.9 times the average daily trading volume of 2.1 million shares.

The past month
Alphabet Class A underperformed the NASDAQ-100 index on 11 days and outperformed it on 10 days.

July 31, 2020
Quarterly Report Analysis Q2 2020: Alphabet Class A reports 1.8% sequential rise in Quarterly Net Profit
Alphabet Class A (NASDAQ:GOOGL), announced net profit of $US7.0b for the quarter-ended 30 June 2020 [Q2/2020], up 1.8% from the previous quarter [Q1/2020] and down 30% from the year-earlier period [Q2/2019]. Earnings per share (EPS) were up 2.5% sequentially from $US9.96 in Q1/2020 to $US10.21 in Q2/2020.
Compared with the previous corresponding period [PCP; Q2/2019], year-over-year [y.o.y.] EPS was down 28.8%, Revenue was down 1.7% and Net Profit was down 30%.
Read more in SECTION 11 on Financials

1.3 Press Releases
July 31: Alphabet Announces Second Quarter 2020 Results
Alphabet Inc. (NASDAQ: GOOG, GOOGL) today announced financial results for the quarter ended June 30, 2020. "We're working to help people, businesses and communities in these uncertain times," said Sundar Pichai, Chief Executive Officer of Google and Alphabet. "As people increasingly turn to online services, our platforms - from Cloud to Google Play to YouTube - are helping our partners provide important services and support their businesses." "In the second quarter our total revenues were $38.3B, driven by gradual improvement in our ads business and strong growth in Google Cloud and Other Revenues," said Ruth Porat, Chief Financial Officer of Alphabet and Google. "We continue to navigate through a difficult global economic environment."
Source: SEC

1.5 Recent Business News Round Up: CNBC
September 25: Alphabet settles shareholder lawsuit over alleged mishandling of sexual misconduct by execs
Alphabet has reached a settlement on a shareholder lawsuit that accused the board of allegedly mishandling sexual misconduct by its executives.
Execs will not be able to receive severance or amend their stock sale plans while they are while they are subject to investigations or a lawsuit for sexual misconduct, according to a summary of the settlement provided by the plaintiffs' attorneys. The settlement also eliminates mandatory arbitration and limits Google's use of non-disclosure agreements for employees involved in these cases.
It also includes a $310 million commitment to fund and create a diversity, equity and inclusion advisory council comprised of outside experts.
In a post announcing the settlement, Google's head of people operations Eileen Naughton said the company is committing to five new guiding principles and a list of detailed changes.
Source: CNBC

September 28: Google to enforce 30% take from in-app purchases next year
Google said on Monday that it will enforce rules that require app developers distributing Android software on the Google Play Store to use its in-app payment system.
The move means developers have until Sept. 30, 2021 to use Google's billing system, which takes a 30% fee from payments, instead of independent payment systems. The announcement brings Google Play's policies in line with Apple's App Store policies, which have come under fire from developers and regulators over several issues, including its own 30% cut.
Apple has argued against scrutiny of its App Store by pointing out that other app stores, like Google Play, also take a 30% fee from in-app purchases.
Google's existing policy said developers have to use Google's billing system on in-app purchases made within the Google Play Store, but it had not been enforced, Google said on Monday in a blog post.
Google didn't name apps that had been skirting the rule. It said 97% of developers selling digital goods already comply with its policies. Netflix and Spotify prompt users inside their Android apps to use a credit card to pay them directly.
"We want to be sure our policies are clear and up to date so they can be applied consistently and fairly to all developers, and so we have clarified the language in our Payments Policy to be more explicit that all developers selling digital goods in their apps are required to use Google Play's billing system," Google said in the announcement, signed by Sameer Samat, a VP of product management.
Source: CNBC

September 25: Google will pause ads referencing election after polls close on Nov. 3
Google said in a letter to advertisers on Friday that it will pause election-specific ads on Nov. 3 after polls close.
"Given the likelihood of delayed election results this year, when polls close on November 3, we will pause ads referencing the 2020 election, the candidates, or its outcome," Google told CNBC. "This is a temporary measure, and we'll notify advertisers when this policy is lifted."
The restrictions apply to Google Ads, DV360, YouTube and AdX Authorized Buyer, according to an email sent from Google to advertisers obtained by CNBC. The letter says Google expects "an unprecedented amount of votes will be counted after election day."
Source: CNBC

September 25: Alphabet Class A
Alphabet's Google services experienced a brief shutdown Thursday evening, with users reporting issues with services like Gmail, YouTube, Google drive and the flagship search engine. Google is investigating the cause of the disruption, but a person with knowledge of the situation told The New York Times the company has ruled out a cyberattack.
Source: CNBC

September 25: Cloud gaming battle heats up as Amazon enters the ring to take on Microsoft and Google
LONDON - As Microsoft battles it out with Sony in this year's edition of the console wars, it's now got another rival to worry about.
Amazon announced Thursday that it would launch its own cloud gaming service, a kind of "Netflix for games" that forgoes the need for consoles or dedicated hardware to play video games. Called Luna, the platform comes with a library of 100 titles and users can play with a special Luna controller.
The entry of Amazon into the raft of companies developing such game-streaming services has long been rumored. The company's announcement now marks an official challenge to the likes of Microsoft and Google, which have both recently launched their own respective cloud gaming products.
But Amazon is taking a slightly different approach to those companies. Instead of going for an all-access subscription - like Microsoft is with Xbox Game Pass - Amazon is launching so-called "channels" for a range of publishers, for which users have to pay a monthly fee. Only Ubisoft and Amazon itself have been confirmed as companies included in that offering so far, with Amazon's Luna+ channel priced at $6 a month.
Source: CNBC

September 24: Google will help employees pay off student loans amid 'debt crisis'
Google's latest employee perk to attract talent is help with student loans.
Starting in 2021, Google will match up to $2,500 per full-time employee per year toward their student loan payments, John Casey, Google's director of Global Benefits told employees Thursday, according to an internal email viewed by CNBC.
"College degrees are out of reach for too many people around the world, and the soaring student loan debt crisis has widened an already pervasive wealth gap, globally," Casey said in Thursday's email. He added that Americans, in particular, face a student loan deficit upward of $1.5 trillion dollars, which he said is twice what it was a decade ago.
The company's new perk aims to help students save the extra money so they can do things like purchase a home or start a family, Casey said in a Thursday blog post.
Google will roll out the new benefit in the U.S. first, but plans to expand to employees globally. During Q4, the company will "collect additional information to inform the rollout," Casey said in the email. "It gets complicated with different lenders country by country," he added.
The new perk comes as the company, whose famous in-office perks aren't available during remote work, competes against tech companies like Facebook and Apple for young tech talent. The cost of living is particularly expensive in the San Francisco Bay Area, where the bulk of tech companies and employees are headquartered.
Casey told employees the latest announcement is an expansion of its education reimbursements for employees, and that it partnered with Google's employee resource groups Black Googler Network and Black Leadership Advisory Group, which he credited for "helping us to get this done."
"Because the burden of student loans weighs disproportionately on communities of color and women, this is a step toward building a more equitable Google too," Casey said in Thursday's email.

September 24: Google explores offering flexible work-from-home options after the pandemic
Google is re-thinking its long-term work options for employees after a survey revealed that most of them don't want to come back to the office full-time. CNBC's "Squawk Box" crew reports.
Source: CNBC

September 23: United turns to interactive Google map to help travelers unsure of where to go in coronavirus era
United Airlines is turning to a Google-powered interactive map to help still-scarce travelers find destinations that fit the coronavirus era.
The map, which launched on United's website Wednesday, allows travelers to punch in the most they want to spend on a ticket and filter airports by their destination activities or descriptions: beaches, beer and breweries, culture, food and drink, hiking, national parks, outdoors, romantic, skiing and snowboarding, and snorkeling and scuba.
For example, a search for a return trip from Newark, New Jersey, the first week in November with a preference for national parks and hiking yielded a $117 flight to Denver, a $97 flight to Las Vegas, a $207 flight to Portland, Oregon, all in basic economy, among other destinations.
Air travel demand is stuck at less than a third of the same levels a year ago and airlines are scrambling to come up with ways to encourage travelers to book. Executives have noted that travelers are waiting much longer to book than last year, a result of so much uncertainty surrounding the virus as well as work, school and child care.
United's new booking tool, which uses Google's flight search engine, also allows travelers to browse flights without set dates.
"Where in the past, more people would look for flights to specific destinations on specific dates, we're seeing that today, travelers are often more open about the destinations that they would like to visit," United spokeswoman Christine Salamone said in an email. "They know they'd like to get away, but they're not exactly sure where they want to go."
United executives and those at other airlines have said they've seen relatively good demand for destinations that allow travelers to physically distance, such as those near national parks and others that offer outdoor activities.
Earlier this month, United launched a map on its site that lists state travel restrictions and is considering to expanding that to international destinations, many of which remain off-limits to U.S.

September 23: Apple, Amazon and Google will emerge as winners from a major market shift, tech analyst Gene Munster predicts
Long-time tech analyst Gene Munster believes big tech is on the cusp of a major shift: It's becoming a stock pickers' market.
The Loup Ventures founder and managing partner expects FAANG stocks, otherwise known as Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google, will fail to collectively rally like they did during most of 2020′ s record run.
"There's going to be a fracturing of the performance within FAANG," Munster told CNBC's "Trading Nation" on Tuesday. "Think of that group of haves being Apple, Amazon and Google, and the have nots being Netflix and Facebook."
Munster sees the split coming down to adapting to the coronavirus - as well as evolving and thriving in a post-pandemic world.
"The companies that are the haves are ultimately going to be involved in much bigger businesses," said Munster.
He's most bullish on Apple's prospects, and highlights its innovation in the health and wellness space.
"It's very simple. Cash is king, and that will ultimately will be driven even higher with wearables," he said.
Munster speculates newer Apple watches and AirPods will be designed to attract more health-conscious consumers. He also predicts the 5G upgrade cycle will boost the bottom line.
"This company should earn close to $6 [a share] in earnings in just a couple of years," he noted. "Put a 35x multiple on that, and you have a $200 stock."
According to Munster, it's a good time to consider buying shares. Apple shares, which had a 4-1 stock split on Aug. 31, have soared 52% so far this year. But they're off 19% from the all-time high.
He sees Amazon reaping long-term benefits from its logistics investments during the pandemic rush to buy online. In Google's case, it's more of a innovative play independent of the virus.
"Think about what's going on with Verily around health and wellness - also what they're doing with Waymo around autonomous transportation," said Munster.

September 23: Google will try 'hybrid' work-from-home models, as most employees don't want to come in every day
Google is rethinking its long-term work options for employees, as most of them say they don't want to come back to the office full-time.
Sixty-two percent of Google employees want to return to their offices at some point, but not every day, according to a recent survey of employee office preferences the company released this week. So Google is working on "hybrid" models, including rearranging its offices and figuring out more long-term remote work options, Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai said in an interview with Time magazine on Wednesday.
"I see the future as being more flexible," Pichai said in the interview. "We firmly believe that in-person, being together, having a sense of community is super important when you have to solve hard problems and create something new so we don't see that changing. But we do think we need to create more flexibility and more hybrid models."
The long-term planning comes as Google, which has been looked at as a model for Silicon Valley workplaces, slowly reveals more details of its plans to return its employees back to the office while also competing with other tech companies for top talent. Earlier in the summer, the company gave staffers the option to work from home through July 2021 amid the global pandemic. That came as Facebook announced a similar timeline, while other companies, such as Twitter, said employees can work remotely "forever."
Google began preparations early on in the pandemic and more recently made changes including to its internal communication forums, CNBC first reported. However, employees have missed the in-office perks such as food offerings and personal chefs.
Ten percent of Google employees - down from 20% surveyed in May - said they don't want to come into the office at all in the future, according to the recent survey.

2.1 Activities
Alphabet Inc maintains an index of Websites and other online content, and makes this information freely available through its search engine to anyone with an Internet connection. The Company's automated search technology helps people obtain nearly instant access to relevant information from its online index. The Company generates revenue primarily by delivering online advertising. Businesses use its AdWords program to promote their products and services with targeted advertising. In March 2008, the Company acquired Click Holding Corp. (DoubleClick), a company that offers online ad serving and management services to advertisers, ad agencies and Web site publishers. In August 2008, the Company sold the search marketing business of Performics, a division of DoubleClick. In September 2008, Google Inc. bought Korea-based blogging software developer Tatter and Company.

John L. Hennessy
Chairman & Director
John L. Hennessy has served as a member of our board of directors since April 2004, and as Lead Independent Director since April 2007. John has served as the President of Stanford University since September 2000. John has also been a member of the board of directors of Cisco Systems, Inc., a networking equipment company, since January 2002, and serves on its nominating and governance committee and acquisition committee. He also serves as a trustee of the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation. From 1994 to August 2000, John held various positions at Stanford, including Dean of the Stanford University School of Engineering and Chair of the Stanford University Department of Computer Science. John co-founded and served as the chairman of the board of directors of Atheros Communications, Inc., a wireless semiconductor company, from 1998 to 2010. John holds a Doctoral degree and a Master of Science degree in computer science from the State University of New York, Stony Brook, and a Bachelor of Science degree in electrical engineering from Villanova University.

L. John Doerr
Director
John Doerr joined Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers in 1980 and has since backed some of the world's most successful entrepreneurs, including Larry Page, Sergey Brin and Eric Schmidt of Google; Jeff Bezos of Amazon.com, and Scott Cook and Bill Campbell of Intuit. John's passion is helping entrepreneurs create the "Next Big Thing" in mobile and social networks, greentech innovation, education and economic development. Ventures sponsored by John have created more than 200,000 new jobs. John serves on the boards of Amyris, Google, and Zynga, as well as several private technology ventures. He also led KPCB's investment in Twitter.
John's technology career began in 1974 at Intel, just as the chipmaker was inventing the groundbreaking 8080 microprocessor. During his Intel years, he held roles in engineering, marketing, management and sales. John also learned about operating excellence from Intel co-founder Andy Grove - insight that he continues to share with entrepreneurs today. He later founded Silicon Compilers, a VLSI CAD software company, and co-founded @Home, the nationwide broadband cable Internet service.
Outside of KPCB, John supports entrepreneurs focused on the environment, public education and alleviating global poverty. These include NewSchools.org, TechNet.org, the Climate Reality Project and ONE.org. John earned B.S. and M.S. degrees in electrical engineering from Rice University and an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School. He also holds several patents for computer memory devices. John is a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and a member of U.S. President Barack Obama's Council on Jobs and Competitiveness.

Alan R. Mulally
Director

Alan served as President and Chief Executive Officer of Ford Motor Company, a global automotive company, from September 2006 through June 2014. From March 2001 to September 2006, Alan served as Executive Vice President of the Boeing Company and President and Chief Executive Officer of Boeing Commercial Airplanes, Inc. He is a member of the U.S. National Academy of Engineering and a fellow of England's Royal Academy of Engineering. Alan holds a Bachelor of Science and Master of Science degrees in aeronautical and astronautical engineering from the University of Kansas, and a Master's degree in Management from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology as a 1982 Alfred P. Sloan fellow.

May 13: Alphabet Class A Alphabet's Loon and Vodacom partner to increase rural internet access in Mozambique
Loon and Vodacom partner to bring network access to previously uncovered populations via stratospheric internet balloons
Mountain View, CA, May 13, 2020 -- Alphabet's Loon and Vodacom have signed a deal to use Loon's balloon-powered internet solution to expand the Vodacom network in Mozambique. In terms of the agreement, Loon will help Vodacom provide service to un-served and under-served parts of the country with a network of floating cell phone towers that operate 20 kilometres above Earth.
Using the Loon solution, Vodacom will expand mobile network access to Cabo Delgado and Niassa provinces, two regions that have proven hard to cover in the past due to the vast and logistically challenging geographical areas, together with low population density. The Loon solution will provide a 4G service that supports Data, Voice, SMS and USSD, which will also enable mobile financial services. The service will be available to any Vodacom subscriber with a standard 4G-VoLTE enabled handset and SIM card. Users will not need to do anything special to connect to the service; they will connect just as they would to a normal cell tower. In fact, it's unlikely that a user will know that they are connected to the service provided by a high altitude balloon, except for the fact that they may have a signal in a location where it previously did not exist.
Vodacom Group CEO Shameel Joosub says "Vodacom's partnership with Loon is a perfect example of how technological innovation can connect the most rural communities in Africa. We are pleased to be part of this initiative in Mozambique, which is helping to bridge the digital divide. This is even more pertinent in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic, where more Mozambicans will now have access to healthcare information through our Loon partnership.

April 29: Alphabet Class A HAPS Alliance Members Outline Commercial Opportunity in Earth's Stratosphere
Mountain View, CA, April 29, 2020 -- Loon LLC, Airbus Defence and Space, HAPSMobile Inc., Intelsat US LLC, and Nokia Corporation see a rare, untapped commercial opportunity in the skies above Earth's atmosphere. All members of the recently-formed HAPS Alliance, the companies outlined in a White Paper published today a multi-billion dollar market opportunity in Earth's stratosphere, spanning telecommunications, high-resolution earth observation, and weather prediction and modeling.
Earth's stratosphere - which spans from just above the lower atmosphere to the edge of space - has long been deemed unsuitable for commercial operations because of its harsh conditions. However, advances in technology over the last decade have made operating in the stratosphere possible, making the region ripe for commercial activity going forward.
The White Paper outlines significant opportunity in the telecommunications sector, with the ability of stratospheric technologies to drive significant growth in the $3.9 trillion mobile technologies and services business by bringing millions of people online, reconnecting people after disasters, building out the next generation of 5G networks, and connecting the future of Internet of Things (IoT) devices.
Another area of commercial opportunity outlined in the White Paper is earth observation (EO) and weather prediction and modeling. The $3 billion satellite segment of the EO market is growing steadily, as is the $4.4 billion drone service market. As stratospheric technologies develop, they will tap into portions of both markets, while stimulating new market demand due to their unique capabilities. Potential use-cases include: collecting data around natural and man-made disasters to enable more effective responses to wildfires, oil spills, floods and more; tracking meteorology to improve weather forecasts; monitoring natural resources, agriculture and infrastructure; and tracking large stretches of oceans for illegal fishing, pollution, or piracy.

Markets continued to slip again leading into Thursday after the U.S.-China trade tensions arose once again. Beijing officials told the U.S. that it would need to correct its "wrong actions" in order for the two negotiate trade talks, especially after the U.S. blacklisted Huawei. May 02 2019: Wireless Innovation Forum Congratulates Members Google, CommScope and Federated Wireless Upon FCC Approval of CBRS Environmental Sensing Capability Equipment and Systems
Approval Brings CBRS One Step Closer to Commercialization
WASHINGTON---- The Wireless Innovation Forum (WInnForum) today congratulates member organizations CommScope (NASDAQ:COMM), Federated Wireless and Google (NASDAQ:GOOGL) for FCC approval of Environmental Sensing Capabilities (ESCs) for use in the 3.5 GHz band. The ESCs will be used to detect the presence of federal incumbent radar transmissions and communicate that information to one or more certified SASs. Glossary
ADVT: Average Daily Volume of shares Traded
Annual Return: Dividends Paid In a 12-Month Period/Price at the Beginning of the Period + Capital Gain or Loss over 1 Year/Price 1 Year Ago (%)
Capital Gain/Loss from n Years Ago to n-1 Years Ago: Capital Gain or Loss over 1 Year/Price 1 Year Ago (%)
Cash/MCap: Cash plus Liquids/Market Capitalisation (times)
Current Ratio: Current Assets/Current Liabiliites (times)
Debt/Equity: Net Debt/Net Assets %
EBIT Margin : Earnings Before Interest and Tax/Revenue (%)
Earnings Yield: Earnings Per Share/Share Price (%)
Moving Average Price (n periods): Sum of Prices for each Period/Number of Periods
PCP: Previous Corresponding Period
PV1000: Present value of 1000 invested 1 year/'n' years ago
Price/Earnings: Share Price/Earnings Per Share (times)
Price/NTA: Closing Share Price/Net Tangible Assets Per Share (times)
Price/Sales: Share Price/Sales Per Share (times)
Relative Price Change [RPC]: Relative price change is price change of stock with respect to Benchmark Index
Relative Strength (6 Months): Price close today/Price close 6 months ago, then ranked by percentile within the entire market.
Return on Assets: Net Profit/Total Assets (%)
Return on Equity (Shareholders' Funds): Net Profit/Net Assets (%)
TSR: Total Shareholder Returns is expressed as an annualized rate of return for shareholders after allowing for capital appreciation and dividend
TTM: Trailing 12 Months
Total Liabilities/Total Assets: Total Liabilities/Total Assets
Turnover Rate: value of annual trading volume as a percentage of market capitalisation
Volume Index (VI): Number of shares traded in the period/Average number of shares traded for the period
Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP): The Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is the summation of turnover divided by total volume in the same period.

urn:contentItem:60H5-5Y21-DXKH-N23S-00000-00Stock Monthly: Alphabet Class A (GOOGL:USD1,487.95) rises 3% on high volatility Friday July 31, 2020 16:00 EDT2020-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:11ZLexisNexisStock Monthly: Alphabet Class A (GOOGL:USD1,487.95) rises 3% on high volatility Friday July 31, 2020 16:00 EDT

AMERICAN MONTHLY STOCK REPORT

Alphabet Class A (NASDAQ:GOOGL), the NASDAQ's 2nd largest Internet company by market cap, traded between an intra-month low of USD1,414.18 and a five-month high of USD1,587.05. In July its volatility (highest price minus lowest price/lowest price) of 12.2% was 0.84 times average monthly volatility of 14.5%, up from 9.2% in July and 11.5% in May. The share price lifted USD45.95 (or 3.2%) in the past month to close at USD1,487.95 on Friday July 31. Compared with the NASDAQ-100 Index which rose 749.0 points (or 7.4%) in the month, this represented a relative price change of -4.2%. The volume was 0.9 times average trading per month of 43.1 million shares. In the past month the market cap has risen USD21 billion. The price ranged between a low of 1469.9 on Thursday, 2 Jul and a high of 1564.8 on Wednesday, 22 Jul.

1.3 Press Releases
May 13: Alphabet Class A Alphabet's Loon and Vodacom partner to increase rural internet access in Mozambique
Loon and Vodacom partner to bring network access to previously uncovered populations via stratospheric internet balloons
Mountain View, CA, May 13, 2020 -- Alphabet's Loon and Vodacom have signed a deal to use Loon's balloon-powered internet solution to expand the Vodacom network in Mozambique. In terms of the agreement, Loon will help Vodacom provide service to un-served and under-served parts of the country with a network of floating cell phone towers that operate 20 kilometres above Earth.
Using the Loon solution, Vodacom will expand mobile network access to Cabo Delgado and Niassa provinces, two regions that have proven hard to cover in the past due to the vast and logistically challenging geographical areas, together with low population density. The Loon solution will provide a 4G service that supports Data, Voice, SMS and USSD, which will also enable mobile financial services. The service will be available to any Vodacom subscriber with a standard 4G-VoLTE enabled handset and SIM card. Users will not need to do anything special to connect to the service; they will connect just as they would to a normal cell tower. In fact, it's unlikely that a user will know that they are connected to the service provided by a high altitude balloon, except for the fact that they may have a signal in a location where it previously did not exist.
Vodacom Group CEO Shameel Joosub says "Vodacom's partnership with Loon is a perfect example of how technological innovation can connect the most rural communities in Africa. We are pleased to be part of this initiative in Mozambique, which is helping to bridge the digital divide. This is even more pertinent in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic, where more Mozambicans will now have access to healthcare information through our Loon partnership.
